PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

This humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that they are totally opposed to any change in the present Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change in any way the Australian National Flag.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Brumby (from 39 citizens), Mr Ian Cameron (from 10 citizens), Mr Holding (from 17 citizens), Mr Peacock (from 186 citizens) and Mr Rocher (from 52 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble Petition of the undersigned Electors showeth:

That any proposed redistribution of funds for Nursing and Personal Care staff costs in Nursing Homes will detrimentally affect the quality of care given in Nursing Homes in South Australia and the quality of life of the residents in those Nursing Homes. The Outcome Standards for Nursing Homes, so recently established, will not be achieved and elderly people will not receive the standard of care or quality of life that they need.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will raise the funding level for Nursing and Personal Care staff hours for all States to enable at least the number of hours of care for Nursing Home residents in South Australia to be achieved by all States.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Blewett (from 945 citizens), Mr Porter (from 3,142 citizens), and Mr Wilson (from 49 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Identification Numbering System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we strongly oppose the introduction of the ``Australian Card'' or any other form of National Identification Numbering System.

We believe that the introduction of a National Identification Numbering System is not only totally unnecessary but is a severe threat to our civil liberties and privacy. We condemn the Government's actions on this matter, particularly as no reasonable nor responsible justification for the proposal has been forthcoming from the Government.
We humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should reject any proposal for a National Identification Numbering System.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Fife (from 84 citizens), Dr Hewson (from 69 citizens) and Mr Ruddock (from 43 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That there is a general dissatisfaction in the community at the levels of road funding made available by the Federal Government.
While noting the commitment of the Government to maintain a high standard of roads in Australia, we are specifically concerned at the real cutbacks for road funding in the Local Government area.
We especially note that roadworks are a labour intensive industry and cutbacks will create unemployment and hardship in rural areas.
Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, give due consideration to increasing the amount of funds available to Local Government authorities for roadworks.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Brumby (from 12 citizens) and Mr Lloyd (from 30 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the electorate of Murray respectfully showeth that:
Australians living in rural and non-urban areas rely to a great degree on the local road network for all facets of their lives.
Funding for roads is an essential part of the Commonwealth's responsibilities for the maintenance of the transport infrastructure.
Road funding under the Hawke Government has decreased significantly in real terms and local government is particularly disadvantaged by this decline.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Immediately address the serious problem of a rapidly deteriorating road network which is confronting local government by allocating more resources to local road funding.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker of the House of Representatives and the honourable members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Australian families are highly dependent upon telephone communications.
2. The Australian community needs an extensive and reasonably priced telephone system.
3. For many Australians, especially the aged and infirm, the telephone provides a ready means of communication especially at times of illness.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House of Representatives will take measures to ensure that the aged, infirm, and other fixed-income groups that are dependent on telephone communication are in no way disadvantaged by any changes to the system of charging for local telephone calls.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cross (from 17 citizens) and Mr Johns (from 188 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
The irradiation of food by any means degrades the nutritional value of food and is potentially harmful to the health of all consumers and to the environment.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House:
1. Withdraw from the Asian Regional Co-operative Project on Food Irradiation and from the International Consultative Group on Food Irradiation.
2. Take all possible steps to prevent and disallow the irradiation of food in Australia.
3. Ban the export and importation of irradiated foods and animal feeds.
4. Take steps to obtain a testing device to make possible the identification of irradiated foods, as soon as one becomes available.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Punch (from 247 citizens) and Mr Webster (from 90 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain residents of the State of South Australia draws to the attention of the House that:
We, the undersigned, strongly object to the Commonwealth Government planning to reduce the hours for Nursing Homes to allow for an Australia-wide re-distribution.
We, like the Voluntary Care Association are vitally concerned about the continued well-being of Nursing Home residents.
We believe plans to phase in a State-wide reduction of staff hours from July 1st, 1988, will have an adverse effect on the quality care in most Nursing Homes, resulting in:
(1) Fundamental nursing needs only being provided.
(2) Minimal rehabilitation.
(3) Reduction of choice with subsequent reduction in residents' rights.
(4) Reduction in therapy.
(5) Loss of valued staff.
We are determined to maintain the existing standards of care for South Australia and in doing so force the Federal Government to change its position in this vital issue.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will:
Voice strong objections to the Commonwealth Government over plans to reduce the staffing hours for Nursing Homes.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain Northern Region Careproviders Association Inc. draws to the attention of the House Part III Division III Section 33 of the Children's Services Act which states: A person who proposes for monetary or other consideration to care for not more than ``Three Children under the Age of Six Years''.

Your petitioners therefore pray that this be changed to ``Three Children under the Age of Five years''. Careproviders feel that once a child begins school we should be able to take another full time child in their place otherwise our earning potential is cut by a third.

PETITION.TITLE: Public Release of Confidential Medical Information
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:

That we express grave concern about the public release of confidential medical information by the Federal Government, sufficient to enable the public identification of Doctors and their patients, and call upon the Parliament to censure all those involved in this gross abuse of the privacy of all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Public Release of Confidential Medical Information
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned electors of the Division of Corangamite, respectively showeth:

That we are gravely concerned about the public release of confidential medical information, sufficient to enable the public identification of doctors and their patients, and call upon the House to censure all those involved in this gross abuse of the privacy of all Australians.
Your petitioners, therefore, pray that the House ensures that there will be no further public release of such private confidential medical information.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petitions of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:

Any proposals to time local telephone calls gravely concerns all people. Isolation and communication was the second biggest problem facing rural women according to the ``Survey of Rural Women'' questionnaire and any attempt at timing local calls will add to this problem, not decrease it.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Parliament to:
Ensure that Telecom do not proceed with the timing of local telephone calls.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Pornography: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled. We, the undersigned, being appalled that the Government has set no penalty for importing unclassified child pornography, do ask that Parliament urgently legislate to:
make the importation of child pornography, and the possession of child pornography, and all tapes and goods banned by Customs, to be a criminal offence, with deterrent penalties, and
close the Customs barriers to pornography in the A.C.T., in respect of X-rated videos (and ER), and end the shameful Canberra trade, and the Mafia connections.
Because 98% of Australians in other States have banned X-rated videos.
Because the trade is still flourishing, and its availability escalates sexual crime.
Because importers of child pornography face only a fine for lying.
Because child pornography pedlars are safe if they cross a border, and cannot be extradited for a summary offence.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
An $8 million wealth inquiry will give the Hawke Labor Government the information it needs for a wealth tax and the reintroduction of death duties.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject any wealth inquiry or new wealth taxes or death duties on the Australian people and businesses already struggling under 16 new Hawke Labor Government taxes.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth that:
We are opposed to the proposed restructuring of the A.B.C. We believe that the A.B.C. is one of the most important public services in Australia and a mainstay of democracy.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House of Representatives will take measures to ensure that the A.B.C. is permitted to continue to offer ``comprehensive'' broadcasting services under its present charter.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Self-Government
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain residents or persons employed in the Australian Capital Territory points out to the House that:
it is appropriate that State and local government policy and administrative functions should be managed by persons accountable to ACT residents,
and that all Australian residents would agree that there should be no taxation without representation,
and that the Commonwealth Parliament should give just and equitable consideration to redressing the wrongs afflicting the ACT.

Your petitioners therefore request urgently that Members agree to provide the ACT with an elected form of self government which will be responsible for all the functions of the ACT Office of Administration and, in addition, for those of local law enforcement and the administration of justice.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Murray electorate respectfully showeth that:

They strongly oppose the introduction of timed local telephone calls in regional and rural areas as they are already severely disadvantaged in comparison with telephone users in the major metropolitan areas in their ability to contact other people on an untimed local call basis.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:

Correct the problem created in the major metropolitan areas, do not alter the present untimed local call policy in regional and rural areas and reinstate the ability for those living in remote areas to have an untimed local call.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Benefits Rebates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Murray electorate respectfully showeth that:
The August 1st changes to Medicare Benefit rebates are unfair to patients, such as those with chronic disabilities requiring consultant physician or after hours consultations.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Amend the Health Insurance Act and the National Health Act to restore the original rebates.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the House to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That there is widespread concern about the proposal to irradiate food in Australia
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should:
1. Block the introduction of Food Irradiation into Australia and;
2. Ban the import of cobalt-60 and cesium-137 and cesium-134 to be used to irradiate food products,
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide, independent radio and television service and should therefore remain intact and continue to provide the same comprehensive range of services;
that the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia;
that the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will oppose the dismantling of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programs of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:

The introduction of time-charging for local telephone calls by Telecom Australia would seriously disadvantage thousands of elderly and disabled people and families, and would add a further burden to the already prohibitive cost of living borne by every Australian.
Time-charging for the business sector is also unfair and unreasonable as any charge increase to business will be borne by consumers in the end.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:

Reject out of hand any plans by Telecom to time-charge local telephone calls and prevent both Australian people and Australian business from being seriously disadvantaged by yet another ludicrous charge.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the electorate of Gwydir respectfully showeth that:

The introduction of time-charging for local telephone calls by Telecom Australia would seriously disadvantage thousands of elderly and disabled people and families, and would add a further burden to the already prohibitive cost of living borne by every Australian.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to;
Reject out of hand any plans by Telecom to time-charge local telephone calls and prevent Australian people from being seriously affected by yet another ludicrous charge.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain electors of Australia shows:

that the introduction of time-charging for local telephone calls by Telecom Australia would seriously disadvantage the sick, elderly and disabled people as well as counselling and community services, particularly Lifeline.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Parliament will reject the present proposal by Telecom to time-charge local telephone calls as being an unfair cost burden on private individuals.

PETITION.TITLE: Unemployment Benefit and Austudy Allowance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of certain Port Augusta citizens (citizens of Australia) (Electors of the Division of Grey)

Respectfully showeth (here circumstances of case stated) that the unemployed in trying to better themselves by full-time study, lose $17 per week, which is the gap between unemployment benefits and Austudy.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that (here terms of action petitioned stated) Supporting parents do not lose any money under the same circumstances.
Why should unemployed be discriminated against?
Humbly pray that there be no loss of money between unemployment benefits and Austudy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Agencies
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of Australia in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Borough of Wonthaggi respectfully showeth:
That the Government's decision to terminate an existing agreement with Latrobe Health Insurance for the provision of facilities for the receipt and limited processing of Medicare claims will:
Deny ready access to cash reimbursements of Medicare Claims;
Deprive citizens of a personalized reliable claims payment service;
Reduce job opportunities in the area;
Not effect the savings to Government as stated within the Budget papers.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will reconsider their previous decision to discontinue Medicare Agency arrangements.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Agencies
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectively showeth-

That the action of those of the Federal Government and/or decision makers of the Medicare structure, to close the Medicare agency office at Wonthaggi, is of grave concern to the residents of the South West Gippsland sub-region.

The closure of this office will mean all claims will require to be forwarded by mail for processing, which means a delay of at least one to two weeks for the receipt of their refunds. Current service provides immediate payment for normal consultations and delays occur for more specialized services.

Many low-income and benefit recipients will suffer genuine hardship if the closure of this office is allowed to proceed, there will be those that may refrain from seeking medical attention as required because of the delays envisaged.

Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, address this matter and trust appropriate intervention will allow the continuation of this vital service within the South West Gippsland sub-region.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitution Alteration (Electors Initiative) Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectively showeth:

that while having some reservations on individual aspects of the Constitutional Initiative (Electors Initative) 1987 your petitioners wish to express our strong support for the concept of people's democracy implied in that Bill.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will refer the abovementioned Bill to the appropriate Parliamentary committee and will examine the operation of direct democracy procedures overseas with the intention of passing legislation granting such facilities to your petitioners during the Bicentennial year.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
The fringe benefits tax will cause hardship to business throughout Australia, especially in the already severely-depressed rural sector and in the motor vehicle industry.
The fringe benefits tax will be a disincentive to employment and worse, will result in additional unemployment.

The economy of this country would best be served by policies that lightened the tax burden, not increased it, that encouraged enterprise, not stifled it and stimulated growth, development and jobs, not prevented it.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will repeal this Legislation and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Advertising of Alcohol
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows: We oppose the advertising of alcohol in any form.

Alcohol is recognised as Australia's number one drug problem which is responsible for at least 50% of all road fatalities; a high percentage of serious crime and vandalism. Hospital beds are filled with sufferers of the many alcohol related diseases including: cirrhosis of the liver; heart disease; stomach ulcers; various forms of cancer and mental illness. Alcohol also causes much family unhappiness and marriage breakdown, as well as being involved in some cases of child abuse and molestation.

Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should ban all advertising of alcohol on television and radio because of its persuasive effect on children and young people.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia (representing all the employees of Rheem Australia Limited, North Rocks Plant) respectfully showeth that persistent rumour suggests that the present Federal Government intends to place further taxes on the Superannuation system.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled urge the Parliament to ensure that no further tax in any form, either on Superannuation Benefits or on accumulated Superannuation Funds, be imposed.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Excise on Beer, Wine and Spirits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The Humble Petition of the undersigned members of the Wynnum R.S.L. Services Memorial Club and concerned citizens respectfully showeth:-
``That the automatic increase in Excise Duty on beer, wine and spirits at six monthly intervals on a C.P.I. basis would increase prices to what is an exorbitant level.

Secondly, in the interests of road safety and Club viability, consideration be given to lowering the Excise Duty on low alcohol beer to a level where it will be more financially advantageous to drink in preference to full strength beers.''

Now, therefore, your Petitioners request that The House of Representatives and Parliament assembled pass appropriate legislation to reverse the decision of the Government which have brought this six monthly automatic excise duty increase.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's I.D. card proposal is the most far reaching and intrusive piece of Australian legislation yet introduced, and that on all the evidence available it will not tackle in the most cost-efficient and effective manner tax and social security fraud.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject Labor's I.D. card proposal to prevent a gross waste of taxpayers' money and a significant infringement of civil liberties.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows:
We object to Telecom's past decisions to alter the time period for cheaper rates for STD telephone calls and to introduce a fee for local call inquiries.
We further oppose any proposal to introduce a time charge on local telephone calls.

These changes in Telecom's charging policy seriously disadvantages the elderly, poor, disabled, and distressed persons in our community as well as unfairly increasing costs to telephone counselling services. They place further cost burdens on already tight family budgets.
Your petitioners therefore humbly seek your consideration of the serious consequences of these changes and humbly pray that you use your influence to reverse such decisions.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled:
The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth concern:
about the evil caused by the fact that x-rated videos with their depiction of unnatural sex and often horrible violence, are allowed to circulate around Australia from Canberra.
And Your Petitioners, therefore humbly pray that such circulation be prevented.
The laws regarding obscenity in the media should also be revived and enforced.
Any your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Agencies
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we strenuously object to the proposal to deny Western District Health Fund Medicare Agency rights in the Blue Mountains and to deny Springwood the availability of a Medicare Agency altogether.
The Agency has provided an important service to a community characterised by its large number of young families and aged persons and by its public transport difficulties.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the termination of the Medicare Agency rights for Western District Health Fund and the withdrawal of Medicare services in Springwood in particular.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mountford Mr J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Procedure, I present the second report of the Committee, entitled The ringing of the bells and the Chamber precincts in the new Parliament House and certification of petitions not in the English language, together with the minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report, the second report of the Procedure Committee for this Parliament, makes three recommendations to the House. Two of the recommendations relate to our impending move to the new Parliament House and the other relates to the certification of translations of those petitions that are in languages other than English. Honourable members who have already visited the new Parliament House will have been struck by the many ways in which it differs from this our home for the past 61 years. The sheer size of the building alone is daunting, apart from other aspects of the new environment which in the long run may effect significant changes to our operations. Whatever long term changes may evolve, the Procedure Committee is committed to resolving anticipated needs and monitoring the adjustment of current procedures in the new environment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee believes that there are two specific aspects of the House's quorum and division procedures that need to be addressed prior to the move. These are the duration of the ringing of the bells and the definition of the precincts of the chamber. It has been anticipated that the size of the building may affect the ability of honourable members to respond in time to bells calling them to divisions or to form quorums. The Committee conducted trials in the new building and concluded that, for an initial period at least, it will be necessary to extend the current times for the ringing of bells. The Committee recognises that, due to unfamiliarity with the building and, for some honourable members, longer distances to walk, there should be a trial period of three sitting weeks when bells will ring for four minutes rather than the current three. During this time the Committee will monitor the situation and, if necessary, submit another recommendation to the House on the duration of the ringing of bells.

Honourable members may be aware that the floor of the chamber in the new House is different from this one in that there are no galleries for senators, diplomats or guests and the bar of the House is located at the rear of the last row of members' seats directly opposite the Speaker. Also, there are no alcoves. There are seats allocated for officials, as is the case in this chamber.

Standing order 46a defines in some detail certain areas on or adjacent to the floor of the chamber where members may not be counted for the purposes of determining whether a quorum is present. I understand that this precise definition was adopted as a direct result of a 1971 count-out and a resulting inquiry by the Committee of Privileges. As there are no alcoves or special galleries on the floor of the new chamber the Committee has recommended that for the purpose of determining whether a quorum of members is present all members who are within the physical limits of the chamber should be counted. As set out in the report, the Committee's understanding of the term `physical limits' is that it includes all areas on the floor of the chamber, including officials' seats.

The Committee has concluded, however, that there is no need to change the standing orders relating to the boundaries for divisions to accommodate changes to the layout of the chamber. It is proposed that to be counted in a division members should still remain within the seats allotted to members. Should a member wish to withdraw from a division, he or she may do so by withdrawing from the area within the seats allotted to members while remaining in the chamber. The Committee has recommended, therefore, that standing orders 46a and 47, relating to the calling of quorums, be omitted and replaced with a new standing order 47 indicating that the boundaries of the floor of the chamber be the boundaries within which members can be counted for the purposes of a quorum.

There is another issue, one relating to our petitioning procedures, that has been brought to the attention of the Committee. Since 1901 the Standing Orders have required members to certify the translation of petitions that are not in the English language. The Committee was made aware of the potential difficulties this may cause, in that many members would not be in a position to certify accurately such translations. The Committee concluded that members should not be required to certify translations of non-English petitions, although they may do so should they so wish. It is proposed that petitions that are not in the English language should continue to require a certified translation, and that those who certify the translations be required to affix their name and address to those translations. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Deputy Chairman of the Standing Committee on Procedure may I express the hope that the Opposition, of which I am also a member, will see fit to accept these very sensible recommendations. Having been to the new Parliament House and having been part of the stopwatch exercise undertaken to see how long it takes to walk to the new chamber, I can assure honourable members that some will have to undertake an exercise of fitness when we shift up on to the hill. All honourable members will finish up with lean, hungry looks, just having to respond to the bells. This probably will not be a bad thing anyway; it may remove some of the excess weight.
—Speak for yourself.

—I am very lean and also I am not hungry. Probably it is a little ridiculous that in the past the practice that any member who was seated in a chair outside or in the back seats of this chamber was not regarded as being in the chamber for the purposes of a quorum. The Committee is recommending that, if a member is in the House, he or she will be deemed to be in; if he or she is out, he or she will be deemed to be out. It is an uncomplicated recommendation. The recommendation relating to petitions I do not think is exactly earth shattering. The present procedure has been in place for a long time. It is totally unrealistic to expect members of this chamber to be able to read the many written forms of language that now exist in Australia as the result of the migration to this country of people from all over the world.

SPEECH.PARA: I inform the Manager of Opposition Business, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife), that from my point of view, as Deputy Chairman of the Committee and as an Opposition member, the recommendations have my total support. I hope that the honourable member for Hume will be able to agree to the recommendations on behalf of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting the second report from the Standing Committee on Procedure I share the hope of the honourable member for Banks (Mr Mountford) and the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) that the report's recommendations will be looked at very seriously and given support by the Opposition and by the Government. There are two observations that I think are relevant from the point of view of those who may be listening to this debate. This move to the new Parliament House, the Australian people's new Parliament House, is quite significant. It is significant obviously because it is a much larger and more sophisticated building than this one. It will also, I believe, afford a greater opportunity for members of the public to witness parliament in process and, I would hope, to enjoy the procedures and the precincts of parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to those who feel that this has been a major and very costly step for the Australian community that when people experience the new Parliament House they will agree with most people here that, in fact, it will be a place to be proud of. It will also serve an important purpose in affording the opportunity for the Australian community to witness very directly the procedures of parliament. One of the difficulties with the current arrangement is that it is not always possible for people to get into the galleries, particularly during Question Time. In the new Parliament House that opportunity will be more readily available, and I think the Australian community will find that that will be a great boon.

There is another aspect which I ought to emphasise. The Committee is very conscious of the need to modernise the procedures of parliament and it is continuing to do that. I believe that Parliament will continue to be relevant and effective. However, one concern I have about the new Parliament House is that, because of its physical size, there may be a separation of the parliamentary members from the members of the Government and the Executive. I think that is of concern to all of us because one of the strengths of this Parliament is, if I can use the term, the rubbing of shoulders, the fact that people from the Opposition and the Government can get together and talk. That is a regular process and debate is facilitated by the fact that we are mixing together on a regular basis. As members we should be conscious, in the new Parliament House, of not becoming separated from one another so that the process of discussion is not diminished. That is a very important role and one we must all play. The Committee is conscious of that and that is why it is making these sorts of decisions. If members of parliament and members of the Executive are equally conscious of that, parliament will continue to serve the Australian people as well as it has done to date.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, and I think I can presume to speak on behalf of all members of the House, I thank the Standing Committee on Procedure for this second report and for the work it is doing in relation to the procedures of this House. Obviously, when we move to the new Parliament House there will be a need for some changes in the procedures because of the changes in the physical layout and the distances that will have to be travelled by members to get from their offices and other parts of the building to the House of Representatives chamber and the Senate chamber. I say to the House, and particularly to the Chairman and the Deputy Chairman of the Committee, who have both spoken, that the Opposition will very carefully examine the report. I have not had an opportunity to read it but I will do so. We will make an official response to that report. As I said earlier, I thank the Committee for the work it is doing. Many new procedures will be required. It is a very important time as we move from one building to the other because many of the decisions we take will be followed by parliaments well into the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House expresses it deep concern at the negligent way the Government has conducted Australia's relations with the South Pacific nations since 1983.

I have moved this motion because, as a member of the Australian Parliament, I have a very real concern about the lack of proper regional focus in Australian foreign policy, about the lack of any coherent foreign policy strategy for this country. All of this is symptomatic of the obvious lack of long term planning and thought in Australian foreign policy. This is not a personal view; this is the view not only of many members on this side of the House but, sadly, of a large number of members of our Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

The Pacific, as I think all members of this House would be well aware, is vital to Australia in two ways-in terms of the economic development of this country and in terms of our security. In economic terms, the Pacific taken as a whole, not just specifically the South Pacific, will be the future of economic power in the world. There is no doubt that in the next 50 years Japan, China, some members of the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) and one or two others such as South Korea will be the economic engines of this globe. With that in mind it is enormously important for us to be deeply involved in that region because there is so much from which we can benefit if the region is to be economically successful-as I believe it will.

An important part of economic success is trade and an important part of trade is that it can pass unhindered through a region-in this case through the Pacific, including more specifically the South Pacific. One of the reasons this region has grown economically so effectively over the years is simply that trade has passed unhindered. That has been achieved through a policy of what one could describe as strategic denial, making the region an area of strategic denial to the Soviet Union in particular and making the region free from the debilitating superpower rivalry that has plagued other parts of the world.

We have managed to achieve a zone of strategic denial particularly through the vehicle of the ANZUS alliance but we have also been able to build on that through countries such as ours and New Zealand developing extremely close relations with many of the Pacific island states-perhaps one could say all of the Pacific island states. These achievements were reached above all by governments such as the Menzies Government and the Fraser Government. But in the world in which we live today, in 1988, the South Pacific-and the Pacific region generally-is not so simple. It is a region that has gone through an enormous process of change. First, there has been a very significant change in the domestic politics of many of the countries in our region. We have seen, in some of the Pacific island states, very significant changes; for example, in such countries as Vanuatu and the Solomon Islands-and I hardly need to remind the House of the significant changes that have taken place in Fiji. Papua New Guinea as well is undergoing a certain amount of political instability at the moment which certainly causes me-and I know causes the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar)-some considerable concern.

One of the phenomena that we have seen in our region is, to put it simply, an upsurge in Melanesian chauvinism. But we have also seen some very significant changes in the politics of New Zealand. What these two things have done is significantly change also the foreign policy attitudes of those countries. We have seen in New Zealand a push towards unilateralism which has led to the demise of the ANZUS alliance. We have seen throughout the region a growth in opposition to the role of the United States and greater emphasis on what is sometimes described as moral equivalence, where people regard the Soviet Union and the United States as equally evil. That is an attitude that I think is extraordinarily unfortunate.

We have also seen a significant growth in opposition to the presence of France in the region. I remain a strong opponent of the French policy of nuclear testing at Mururoa and the new place to which it is moving its tests. However, the Government's position in particular on French involvement in New Caledonia has been motivated more by traditional Anglo-Saxon francophobia than by rational analysis of the very real difficulties and conflicts which exist within that country. So we are seeing in our region generally a very significant change in its domestic environment. We are also seeing a very significant change in the strategic environment of our region. Not least, we have seen a great deal of interest in our region coming from the Soviet Union and an increase in its involvement. The Soviet Union's approach is, of course, to bring to an end the policy of strategic denial, which, as I have already explained, has been so beneficial to Australia and to the region as a whole over so many years. If one goes back to 1984 one can see that the Soviet Union has wanted to achieve that. Moscow Radio said on 15 July 1984:
The Lange victory-
the victory of the Lange Government in New Zealand-
could set off a chain reaction leading to the collapse of the ANZUS bloc.

That is what Moscow Radio said and, of course, in a sense Moscow Radio turned out to be right. Since 1984 we have had the collapse of ANZUS; we have had the encroachment of the Soviet Union, admittedly on commercial grounds, into a number of the Pacific islands-and perhaps one cannot blame those islands for that; we have the famous Vladivostok speech of Mr Gorbachev, emphasising the growing role for the Soviet Union in our region; and we had the very significant Soviet military build-up both in Cam Ranh Bay and Vietnam generally, and also the growth of the Soviet Pacific fleet which now constitutes something like 32 per cent of all Soviet Union surface ships. This sort of development is hardly conducive to increased stability or the maintenance of stability in our region, because what is happening increasingly is that the phenomenon of superpower rivalry is arriving on our doorstep. Some, in response to this, would say that the Soviet Union has completely changed; it is now a benign nation; that we have to look at things in terms of moral equivalence; that I am just Red baiting; and all this sort of thing. But I believe that the wise members of this chamber-and I know there are many of them-will be concerned that things can change, and change quickly, in the Soviet Union and the phenomenon of Soviet involvement in our region is certainly leading to a degree of superpower rivalry that most members of this House, but certainly not all, would regard as unpalatable.

Madam Speaker, when you look at the way the Government has reacted to these very significant changes in the strategic and domestic environments within our region, you, and other members of this House have a right to be deeply concerned. The Government's approach to the South Pacific and the Pacific generally in terms of foreign policy has been overwhelming an approach of benign neglect. It has been frightened to shore up Australia's role, and to shore up the role of the Western alliance in our region, because its whole argument is built on a false premise of not wanting to be involved and appearing to be overbearing and imperialistic. We saw, for example, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) turn his back on the region for the first three years of his period in that portfolio. It took him about three years before he made any formal visit to the South Pacific region. We have seen the Australian Government reduce the aid budget in our region, particularly to Papua New Guinea, where it breached an agreement with that country, which inevitably led to significant resentment within both the Government and the bureaucracy of Papua New Guinea.

The Government has closed down the Commonwealth Heads of Government regional meetings (CHOGRM) because the Foreign Minister, I suspect, for reasons unbeknown to any other members of this House, has some sort an antipathy towards the institution of the Commonwealth. The Government has sat by and watched the ANZUS alliance collapse without going to New Zealand, simply on the grounds that the issue is too hard and it would not want to interfere with New Zealand in any way at all. On the defence side we have the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities report and the Defence White Paper, which again turn their backs on the region and on the defence of the region generally, withdrawing into a mentality of fortress Australia. It is not true to say that the Government has launched no initiatives at all in the region. It has actually launched three initiatives. The first was to create-and it was the Australian Government that created it because if Australia had opposed it, it would not have come to much-the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. This was a treaty of which the Soviet Embassy said on 12 August 1986:
The creation of a nuclear free zone would contribute to the formation of a multilateral system of security in the Asia-Pacific region.

I am sure that is right, but that is shorthand for saying that the Soviet Union sees it as the first step towards the superpower rivalry which it wants to bring to our region. What that treaty effectively does is to deny a role for the United States in the event of the worst possible scenario-let me emphasise that: the worst possible scenario-and God forbid it should ever happen. It denies the United States a role as a player in providing nuclear deterrence in our region. I think that that is an extraordinarily short-sighted and political thing to do. It is not something that this nation should be involving itself in. We should have a broader and more long term perspective than that.

As I have explained, the Government has done more than just introduce the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), on behalf of the Government, has called for the constructive involvement of the Soviet Union in our region. The Prime Minister made that call recently in Singapore on his way to the Soviet Union. I suppose that he did that in order to ingratiate himself with his putative hosts. But where in the world have we seen the Soviet Union being constructively involved in any region, constructively involved from the point of view of the democracies and the Western alliance? Fancy an Australian Prime Minister coming out and calling for that kind of involvement! Honourable members can rest assured that I have found from talking with diplomats from various countries that they have been as alarmed as this Opposition by that quite extraordinary and indefensible statement by the Prime Minister.

Of course, we also have as a third initiative by this Government the rather childish slanging match with France, which has proved to be completely unproductive. I think that what we need to do is to develop a strategy in this country which shores up our security and increases the sense of regional consciousness. I think we can do four things to achieve that. First of all, in terms of security, Australia should develop its defence cooperation within the region. That would be an important initiative. Already we have a degree of defence cooperation within our region but we ought to offer further cooperation wherever it is willingly accepted. I doubt whether there would be much opposition to that proposition from the other side of the House.

Secondly, I have argued that Australia, as one of the major powers of this region, should promote a regional trading initiative which would lead to the creation of an ASEAN-South Pacific common market. In one sense this common market would be similar to the European Community-perhaps only in one sense-in that it would provide for common external tariffs and a free trade zone within that region. I have very little optimism about the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade round of negotiations. I do not think that we are going to get the sort of multilateral trade agreement which will overwhelmingly benefit Australia. We have to look regionally and think regionally. The development of free trade in our region is the way to stimulate regional economic growth and regional consciousness. Such a regional trade initiative is an important way of doing that.

Thirdly, we should revitalise the Commonwealth Heads of Government regional meetings. As honourable members may know, Malaysia is due to be the next host of CHOGRM. Malaysia is simply waiting for the Australian Government to say that it is happy to go ahead with the CHOGRM meeting. Malaysia has not called the meeting, because it is aware of opposition from our Foreign Minister to such a meeting. CHOGRM is yet another important way of improving regional consciousness and regional cooperation.

Finally, I think it is important that we restore in real terms the budget that we had originally under the Fraser Government for aid to our region instead of deflecting $100m over a three- to five-year period to the front line states of southern Africa. I strongly urge the House to support this motion. It is a matter of great concern to me that our South Pacific strategy has no coherence or direction. I believe that this side of the House offers that coherence and that direction.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I second the motion at this stage and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harvey Mrs E.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The content of this motion put up by the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), namely, the alleged neglect of the South Pacific by this Government, has been a recurrent theme in Opposition foreign policy statements over the past couple of years. For example, this year the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) and no doubt many others have belaboured this erroneous point in numerous statements both inside and outside this chamber. As late as 7 December last year, Senator Hill raised this issue as a matter of public importance in the Senate. At the time his claims of neglect were refuted most ably and definitively by Senator Gareth Evans. I cannot do better than refer the honourable member for Mayo and any other honourable members who are interested to Senator Evans's excellent speech on that occasion. However, not to be outdone, the honourable member for Mayo who, like many of his Opposition colleagues, is always loath to let the facts get in the way of a good argument, has chosen to waste the time of this House by putting us through this tedious procedure once more. Knowing as I do that the honourable member for Mayo fancies himself as a bit of an expert on foreign affairs, I must say-and I am sure I speak also for the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney)-that we are rather disappointed that he could not have come up with something more original on this occasion.
—You wrote this before I spoke.

—I am talking about the motion itself, not what the honourable member said. I would have thought that the motion could have been a little more original and novel and not something that has already been done to death in the Senate and various other forums. However, I do not mind getting up and telling the House about our foreign affairs record and our present policies in the South Pacific because these polices are something of which this Government can be proud and for which this Government receives the respect and approval of South Pacific nations.

SPEECH.PARA: I will concentrate on refuting the claims of the honourable member for Mayo that this Government lacks any coherent strategy or any long term plan as far as the South Pacific is concerned. This Government has a strong five-year record of sympathetic response and leadership in the South Pacific. When we came to power in 1983, Australian attitudes were still characterised by a sense of post-colonial complacency. Since that time we have responded flexibly and with imagination to a new assertion of values and interests by the countries of the region.

Our dealings with the South Pacific region have not, as the honourable member for Mayo claimed, been piecemeal or unplanned. We have had the foresight to conduct careful planning activities related to the region. For example, in 1983 a thorough review of the ANZUS Treaty checked and confirmed its validity. This was the first and essential ingredient in a stocktake of the welfare of the region and of the condition of our policy towards it. This clarification and confirmation of our position has enabled us to respond promptly and with confidence to issues such as port visits.

Other planning activities which have been undertaken over the past two years include a review of Australia's South Pacific options in early 1986; a major policy speech by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) in May 1986 at the University of the South Pacific in Suva, setting out basic Australian approaches to the region; and a preparation of detailed submissions on the South Pacific to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade-or to its subcommittee inquiring into the South Pacific. In the light of Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities and the subsequent Defence White Paper, there has been an assessment of regional security implications. There have also been reviews of Australian policy on Papua New Guinea and meetings of Pacific heads of missions in 1986 and 1987. The Government has also shown leadership in the South Pacific at a time when there was an urgent need to respond rapidly to growing concerns about nuclear arms testing and dumping.

In the area of multilateral relations, Australia has taken steps to encourage Western countries, such as France and Japan, to develop constructive relations with governments of the South Pacific nations. In regard to relations between the island states and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR), Australia recognises the island states' sovereign authority. It would be hypocritical for Australia to tell the island governments that it is improper for them to enter into economic relations with the USSR when Australia itself enjoys the benefits of a constructive economic relationship with the Soviet Union. However, Australia has alerted island governments to prospects that the USSR may endeavour, through these arrangements, to develop a presence which goes beyond normal diplomatic and commercial relationships. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade drew Australia's concerns in this regard to the attention of the Soviet Foreign Minister, Mr Shevardnadze, during his visit to Canberra last year.

As regards regionalism, the Australian Go-vernment has played a full role within the South Pacific Forum in the development of regional positions on significant issues affecting the region as a whole. At the 1987 Apia Forum, Australia proposed the establishment of a committee of officials to look at the evolution of regional institutions. Australia's relations with Papua New Guinea are entering a new phase following the signing of the joint declaration of principles by the two Prime Ministers last December, and meetings of Ministers and officials will take place over the next few months.

Australian aid to the South Pacific is something that the honourable member for Mayo mentioned at the end of his speech. He claimed, as many members of his Party have before, that we have our aid priorities wrong, that we are not giving as much as we should to the South Pacific, and that we are diverting aid to other areas. Australia is still currently the major bilateral donor of aid to the South Pacific. If we look at aid to the South Pacific countries, excluding Papua New Guinea, we find that in 1970-71, Australian aid to the region totalled approximately $1m. In 1987-88, the allocation of bilateral funds to the region was $68.2m. At the 1982 Rotorua South Pacific Forum the then Liberal Government announced a pledge to the region of $300m to be provided as development assistance over a five-year period. This commitment was confirmed by the present Labor Go-vernment and is due to expire at the end of the current financial year. During the five-year currency of the pledge it is expected that approximately $312m will be given. If other aid expenditure such as disaster relief is taken into account, it will mean that Australia's total aid expenditure during the five-year period will be of the order of $360m-$60m more than the Liberal Government pledged back in 1982.

Australian aid to Papua New Guinea accounts for some 85 per cent of that country's aid receipts and currently represents 30 per cent of Australia's aid program. The 1987-88 Budget provides $301.8m in aid to Papua New Guinea, the vast majority of which takes the form of untied budget support. A new treaty of development cooperation is being negotiated with Papua New Guinea in accordance with the aims of the joint declaration of principles. It must be remembered that issues such as Papua New Guinea's declared intention to achieve fiscal self-reliance, as well as a diversification of its sources of aid, will influence the outcome of these new arrangements. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) recently informed Prime Minister Wingti that Australia will maintain the level of Budget support to Papua New Guinea at $275m for each of the next three years. Over this period, project aid is expected to increase. Mr Wingti has welcomed this commitment of increased levels of Australian aid in helping Papua New Guinea to achieve self-sustaining development.

Claims by the honourable member for Mayo of neglect in the South Pacific are not borne out when one looks at the number of visits to the region by Australian Ministers over the last five years. Since 1983, no fewer than 22 ministerial visits to the South Pacific have taken place, including four by the Prime Minister and four by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. The honourable member for Mayo should know all this because one of the more trivial and nitpicking exercises of his much vaunted, but not very effective, Waste Watch Committee was to count up ministerial visits and claim that they were a waste of taxpayers' money. Does the honourable member claim that these trips were a waste of money or is he, for the purposes of this argument, shifting ground and saying that there should have been more?

As well as increasing direct contacts between the Australian Government and the governments of the South Pacific nations, we have strengthened our diplomatic representation in the area. We have accredited representation to the Federated States of Micronesia and the Marshall Islands and we have put additional personnel in Port Moresby, Apia, Suva and Vila. We are represented in all the independent South Pacific countries-nine of them by resident representatives and five by non-resident representatives. We also have representatives in Honolulu and Noumea.
To sum up, our policy and programs in the South Pacific do not indicate neglect, as the honourable member for Mayo claims.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite the reverse.

—On the contrary, as the honourable member for Kingston says, they indicate a great degree of commitment. More importantly, they indicate a more mature, consistent and flexible approach to South Pacific aspirations and events. This Government can only be commended for its firm and sensible handling, for example, of the Fijian situation.
—I think that was a bad example to take, actually.

—I will give the honourable member another example. In contrast, one has only to recall the extraordinarily naive, clumsy and insensitive actions and performance of the former Opposition foreign affairs spokesman-the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown)-when he was in Fiji at the time of the first coup.
—And the present one.

—And the present one. That is evidence of the ignorance and lack of understanding on the part of the Opposition of political changes which have taken place in the region since it left government. I reject the motion put forward by the honourable member for Mayo and I urge honourable members to do the same.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In considering this important motion, which I am pleased the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) has brought up, we should go back in time a little. We need to remember and consider that it was the advance of Japan in the Second World War to Australia's shores, through Papua New Guinea and the south-west Pacific nations, which brought home to Australia that the future security of the Pacific region is absolutely vital to this country's interests. That point was brought up by the honourable member for Mayo. Speaking at that time, the then Foreign Minister, Dr Evatt, made that abundantly clear in a number of speeches. In San Francisco on 6 December 1945 he stressed the need for a Pacific security zone which would be largely dependent `upon the relationship between the United States on the one hand and Australia and New Zealand on the other'. The foreign policy principles established at that time, which have remained largely intact to the present, were to balance the needs of Australian security against the economic and political aspirations of the island peoples. Above all, this meant the creation and maintenance of goodwill between a diverse and widely scattered group of Polynesian and Melanesian islands on the one hand and a European oriented Australia and New Zealand on the other. That is the point I start with.

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge that the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Harvey) is a recent member of this House and has not had the opportunity, I guess, to travel widely in the South Pacific region. When I hear speeches such as the one she has just made I recognise that they come from a background of looking at the matter solely from Australia's point of view, without having the opportunity of travelling to the islands, talking to the people involved and getting an impression from them as to Australia's capacity and the proper direction of Australia's foreign policy as it affects them. When we deal with South Pacific nations it is not as if we are dealing with more sophisticated groupings such as occur in western Europe and North America. The fact is that the people of the South Pacific live in small nations, with very small populations in many cases, and their attitudes are coloured very much more by their capacity to meet, talk to, get to know and build relationships on a personal basis than would be the case in our other foreign policy relationships.

The apparently impressive statement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) recently that half of his departmental overseas policy staff work in the Asian-Pacific region takes on an entirely different complexion if we remove the Asian component and examine the number of foreign affairs officers actually located in South Pacific nations, excluding Papua New Guinea. We find that 30 officers are physically located in the whole of the South Pacific and that almost half of those are in Suva, Fiji. Similarly, the Foreign Minister's claim of significantly increased aid to South Pacific nations is not correct; it is simply wrong. It would have been much more honest of the Foreign Minister if he had acknowledged that, after increases in total aid to the region for several years, the August 1987 Budget not only reduced overall allocations in 1987-88 but also imposed significant cutbacks to nations such as Vanuatu, Tonga, Kiribati, the Cook Islands and the South Pacific Commission. So the claim cannot be defended in terms of aid to the region because the reality is that aid has been cut back.

As I have said, goodwill is the key to our relations with these nations, for it is this which will ultimately determine the effectiveness of Australia's security objectives. So the key question in this debate might well be: has the Hawke Government maintained and extended Australia's goodwill with its Pacific island neighbours? Looking at the situation in those terms, I think the answer has to be no. Apart from the superficial listing of the Government's achievements, when we actually go to the places and talk to the people there we find a disturbingly high level of cynicism and disillusionment amongst those nations of the South Pacific and their leaders at the manner in which the Hawke Government has conducted its foreign policies in the Pacific area. In particular, that all important goodwill has been eroded to a point where there is a very real danger that many Pacific nations will cast their attentions beyond Australia for the leadership and support which are so necessary for their economic and political circumstances.

It is instructive to recall that a previous Labor government also found itself in difficulties in the Pacific region. The very authoritative work Australia in World Affairs 1971-75 states that in that period Canberra disappointed the expectations of the island peoples, Australia had an ambivalent record and our ostentatious presence at the 1983 South Pacific Forum meeting was handled so badly as to be `generally viewed by the islands as a gauche reminder of Big Brother'. At that meeting it was also very embarrassing for Australia to have to receive a complaint from the Fijian Prime Minister against the activities of Australian trade unionists in Fiji. There is a long history of interference by Australian trade unionists in Fiji. What happened in the Whitlam years was nothing compared with what happened in the 1980s. Australian trade unionists such as Mr Halfpenny and Mr Clancy were closely associated with the formation of the Fijian Labor Party in 1985 and with agitation for Fijian workers to receive remuneration and working conditions commensurate with those of their Australian counterparts, regardless of local considerations.

Is it any wonder that when the Fijian coup subsequently occurred, and the Australian trade union movement imposed black bans on shipping and airline movements into and from Fiji, the Hawke Government's inability or disinclination to stop those bans caused a serious and totally understandable breakdown in relations between Fiji and the Australian Government? The coup was wrong. It was proper to condemn the coup, but the subsequent handling of the situation by this Government was totally inept. Colonel Rabuka has been quoted as saying--

TALK.START.PARA: —He is no authority.
—He had something to do with the coup and he has something to do with what is subsequently occurring in Fiji. Whether we like it or not, Australia has to take that into consideration. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It (the coup) has affected our standing somewhat adversely, but those who understand the region and who are members of it, understand our situation. I'm talking about the true members of the region-the Asians, Far East, Indonesians, the Filipinos, the Micronesians, the Melanesians, the Polynesians. I can't say the same for Australia and New Zealand, which are European communities in a Pacific environment. They are isolated from the European community they identify with, and they are trying to impress upon us their values and expectations.

All the leaders of the Pacific islands, if asked about the Fijian coup, will say that they understand it and have a certain sympathy with it. We say, quite properly, that it was wrong. Many of the Fijians will say that they did not like it, but to pretend that we can impose our values upon that situation, which this Government tried to do, is simply to be out of touch with the reality and to put us in a very difficult position in our relationships with other nations in the area. It is just one example of an increasing flow of evidence from the Pacific region that the Hawke Government's handling of the Fijian coup has left us in a less than perfect position. Obviously, the Government was not well prepared for the situation, despite the very obvious instability which had been caused by the election in May 1987 of a coalition of labour and Indian based parties. Unfortunately, the Government had no inkling of the coup beforehand and the record shows that it misinterpreted events in the days and weeks immediately afterwards.

These are the signs of a government which has neglected its responsibilities. Whatever carefully selected facts might be placed before the Parliament by the Foreign Minister to deny the claim of negligence, the reality in the region speaks for itself. The south-west Pacific is one of our most important neighbourhood regions, yet the Foreign Minister visited that region only once in the first three years of his tenure of the office. In the meantime, ANZUS has collapsed, the situation in New Caledonia has become explosive, the Soviets are stepping up their political and commercial activity in the region, Libya is stirring the pot, democracy needs to be rebuilt in Fiji, aid is being cut back throughout the region and Australia's handling of aid to Papua New Guinea is disturbing, to say the least, and comes at a time when that country's economic and political stability is deteriorating. I would be very interested to hear the Hawke Government's response to the present situation in Papua and New Guinea, because this is an utterly important part of the region in terms of Australia's strategic situation. The atmosphere there causes me a very great deal of concern. I hope to hear something from the Government on that matter before too long.

This region is of vital importance to Australia, as was acknowledged by Dr Evatt as far back as 1945 and has been acknowledged by all successive governments. It has been treated badly, wrongly and ineptly by the Hawke Government. It is certainly not in Australia's interests that that treatment should continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bilney Mr G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is difficult to know where to begin in opposing such a confused presentation as we have had from the Opposition of what I suppose it laughingly calls its point of view on developments in the South Pacific. The motion moved by the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) reads:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House expresses its deep concern at the negligent way the Government has conducted Australia's relations with the South Pacific nations since 1983.

He accused the Government of lacking a coherent strategy, of benign neglect, of not taking initiatives and so forth. It is very difficult to work out whose point of view one is to debate here-that of the honourable member for Mayo, which I found either outrageous or amusing, or that of the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), whose contribution was a good deal more thoughtful. This brings out the tension in the Opposition between its wish, on the one hand, to interfere in the affairs of countries in the South Pacific-we should have done this, that we should have done that and we should have done the other thing, according to the honourable member for Mayo, the former Opposition spokesman, who conveyed the feeling that we should have sent a division or two into Fiji to sort out the Fijians- and, on the other hand, the idea that we should allow these countries to determine their own destinies. Australia has been pursuing in the South Pacific a policy of keen and close interest, a coherent policy which has been developed over the years and which has been remarkably successful.

I got the most amusement out of the invidious comparison given by the honourable member for Mayo of this Government's attitude over the last five years with that of the Menzies Government. To the very best of my knowledge, Sir Robert Menzies regarded the South Pacific as a place that one flew over on one's way to visit great and powerful friends in the Northern Hemisphere. Several years after he left office, the total aid by Australian governments to the South Pacific was less than $1m. He regarded the countries of the South Pacific as colonies which should remain so, and was unsympathetic to their aspirations, and one hears echoes of that in statements that the Opposition makes: nowadays if only these people would see sense and agree to be run by Australia in a proper colonial manner, things would be much better. That is not the attitude of this Government and it is not an attitude which is designed to lead to a successful policy of friendship with the countries of the South Pacific.

In the time I have remaining to me I wish to mention a couple of matters which have been touched on in the debate. I passed from a sense of amusement at what the honourable member for Mayo was saying to a sense of outrage, in relation to the matter of trade. The honourable member claimed as his own initiative that there should be some development of trade in the South Pacific and that various things ought to be done so far as trade is concerned.
