In recent years this Government has placed great emphasis upon expansion of trade with the South Pacific, which involves mechanisms such as SPARTECA, the South Pacific Regional Trade and Economic Co-operation Agreement, and relations with Papua New Guinea under PATCRA, the Papua New Guinea-Australia Trade and Commercial Relations Agreement. Under those agreements all exports from Papua New Guinea and the other islands that form the Pacific Forum, with the exception of one or two items to which sectoral policies apply, now enter Australia duty free and quota free.

We have provided funds for an independent consultant to look at the benefits for island governments with respect to closer economic cooperation among themselves. Also, we have provided funds to support the office of the South Pacific Trade Commissioner in Sydney to assist the islands to market their products in Australia. For the honourable member for Mayo to claim ownership of efforts to expand trade with the South Pacific seems to me to be ludicrous.

Another aspect in relation to which the honourable member for Mayo was neglectful, it seemed to me, was his assertion that the Australian Government had taken only three initiatives in respect of the South Pacific in the past three years. That indicates either a lamentable unfamiliarity with the area-and perhaps that is true-or a lamentable inability to count, if we are to accept the honourable member's assertion of the number of Government initiatives as being accurate. His assertion omitted an area, for example, that the honourable member touched upon-defence. He left out that very important area of defence-the expansion of defence cooperation with countries of the South Pacific, as exemplified perhaps best of all through the Pacific patrol boat program. It is now the case that two of those patrol boats with which Australia is supplying countries in the South Pacific have been delivered and more are to be delivered as the program proceeds. The boats, which are built in Australia, are an excellent contribution to the defence of these countries, which rely heavily on the resources of the seas around them, and to their being able to protect those resources from depredations-from illegal fishing operations and so forth. This is precisely the response that is required from Australia and precisely the type of cooperative, carefully considered, well thought out policy that needs to be followed. In fact, this policy is the epitome of a coherent strategy and is the opposite of neglect.

Lastly, the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, of which I am pleased to be the Chairman, and of which the honourable member for Warringah is the Deputy Chairman, is conducting an inquiry into Australia's relations with the South Pacific. It has been advised that-I think for the first time in history; certainly this did not happen during the terms of the Menzies Government or the Fraser Government-it has been given the use of a Royal Australian Air Force aircraft so that the Committee may visit, as the honourable member for Warringah rightly says it should, the countries in the South Pacific that are small and difficult to get to so that the inquiry conducted by the Committee can produce the best results in terms of advising the Government on future policies. I emphasise that such policies have been extremely successful in the past and will continue to be so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for the debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member for Kingston will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House calls on the Government to review urgently the implementation of the care aggregate module and prevent a severe decline in the standard of care in Australian nursing homes.

I am rather disappointed that the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) is not present in the House, but I hope that those with whom he is associated will bring to the Minister's attention the points that will be made in this debate. There are approximately 60,000 Australians resident in nursing homes. It is essential that adequate and affordable accommodation become available for our rapidly greying population and that the quality of this care be given the highest possible priority. The Opposition believes that quality aged care at an affordable cost is achievable. It is also apparent that, whenever government involvement in the administration of aged care is reduced, the cost of running a nursing home falls.

Labor's approach has been high handed and, more seriously, inadequate. Its policy has caused insecurity and uncertainty for nursing home residents; ignored the views of the aged care industry; unfairly damaged the reputation of private nursing homes; duplicated, at great cost to the taxpayer and nursing homes, State government quality of care regulations; excluded the valuable and necessary involvement of private interests in the development of hostel accommodation; and increased the likelihood of many more nursing homes closing their doors.

The Government's policy has resulted in an increasing shortage of places in both nursing homes and hostels and, consequently, more people in need of care are being forced back into the community. Assessment teams now review the health of the elderly, replacing the opinion of the general practitioner. Licences for new nursing homes have been curtailed in what many see as a cost saving exercise to the Government. Mr Barry Lake, the administrator of the Wesley Gardens retirement complex in Belrose, New South Wales, said, as reported in the Sydney Morning Herald of 12 January 1988:
They are pushing people back up the pipeline. It costs the Government $250 for every patient in nursing care and about $50 for every one in a hostel.

I am sure the Minister will be scathing about any criticism, but he should listen to the people. He needs to listen to the industry; needs to listen to the people concerned. I remind the Minister of the responses to the Commonwealth-State working party on nursing home standards from the Australian Affiliation of Voluntary Care Associations (AAVCA). I shall quote some of its responses to the Minister:
We submit that if in fact, the Government does not recognise this Submission as realistic and provide a positive response, quite clearly some serious results will occur. These will include:
I shall now list the fears of that Association:
1. Reduction in patient care in the following areas:
1. Feeding
Increasing dependency will occur as a direct result of insufficient time to supervise/assist patients. Meals will become `Production Line' as a timesaving measure . . .
2. Continence
An increase in the incidence and frequency of incontinence will occur as a direct result of insufficient staff time to maintain continence through regular individual maintenance programs.
3. Bathing
Showering/bathing will occur less frequently, leading to problems associated with a breakdown in general hygiene; i.e. skin problems, eye infections, mouth ulcers etc.
4. Patients will be left in bed for longer periods of time, with reduced stimulation and therapy to joints, resulting in contractures.
5. Opportunities for socialisation will be significantly reduced, leading to withdrawal, anxiety, depression, etc.

I assure the Minister that these are not my criticisms; these are the genuine fears of people associated with the industry-fears that they see coming to fruition if the right steps are not taken. The Association goes on to say:
6. Communication with families will become non-existent or at the best very brief.
7. Staff will have less time to `listen to' patients, stress levels for both staff and patients will rise . . .
8. Chemical and physical restraint will be necessary to prevent the confused ambulant patient from wandering . . .
9. Respite beds may disappear-to avoid the see/saw effect on rostering brought about by frequent changes in patient category hours . . .

10. Possible reduction in staff will result in an increase in `incidents' within Nursing Homes; for example-an increase in staff accidents due to haste; an increase in patient accidents, resulting in admission to acute hospitals.

This in turn leads to increased costs in workers' compensation benefits, social security payments and disability pensions, loss of production, increase in workers' compensation premiums, increased administrative costs.

I am sure that Government members who follow me in this debate will say that these matters are fear-mongering. I can see it in their eyes now. But these are the genuine fears of people who are associated with the industry. Further responses stated:
11. Nursing homes will be unable to meet the Outcome Standards, care will be at best `custodial', and will have difficulty in recruiting competent, qualified staff.
12. There will be increased stress in not carrying out `Non Nursing' duties with industrial action being a direct result of redundancy, greater pressures and demarcation.
13. The greater need to seek volunteer assistance will cause ethical and industrial problems, particularly any activity related to the performance of direct care.
14. Directors of Nursing will be unable to complete the necessary Departmental bureaucratic paperwork-assessments etc.
15. Serious staff burnout-particularly of key people such as directors of nursing.
16. An increase in dependency as a result of only having time to provide custodial care.
17. Nationwide serious industrial action.
18. Political effects with patients and relatives being rallied to action.

I would like to assure the Minister that the last forecast of the organisation is undoubtedly true. He has not seen anything if he believes that the Government can go ahead and reduce the standard of care in nursing homes for the aged people of Australia and not get a backlash. The Minister had better believe it.

I would like to revert briefly to the forecast of industrial problems. The nursing unions also claim that changes to nursing homes policies are placing an increasing strain on their members, with the result that many opt to leave the field. According to Marilyn Beaumont, Secretary of the Royal Australian Nursing Federation, reported in the Sydney Morning Herald on 12 January this year:

They the Government have reduced ancillary staff levels, such as domestics, and the work that they did has been transferred by default to the nursing staff. These are things like cooking and cleaning.

Right now the Victorian conciliation and arbitration court is considering a matter under the hospital and benevolent homes award brought about by staff dismissals caused by the Commonwealth. That court is due to report back on 2 May, but 50 jobs have been lost already. What happens when there is a further 22 1/2 per cent cut on 1 July?

I think we should pay a little attention to the resident classification instrument (RCI). The resident classification instrument is intended to replace the present NH10 form used to claim extensive care benefits. The study consisted of 12 questions, and proprietors were asked to complete a survey form for every third, fourth or sixth resident, depending on the capacity of the home. Twelve hundred and fifty nursing homes were invited to participate, representing more than 17,000 residents. It is interesting to see that the Minister for Housing and Aged Care claimed on 24 March that all residents of nursing homes had been assessed as to the type and level of care they required. This is wrong. Only 17,000 out of 60,000 were assessed. It is also worth noting that those forms had to be returned in only 72 hours. In most cases it was hardly enough time for the survey to be carried out correctly. The comment has also been made that the questionnaire was not objective but subjective, designed to produce the answers wanted by the Department.

The Resthaven Nursing Home in South Australia recently carried out a series of computer projections based on results of the RCI, and on the assumption that one-third of the nursing home population would be replaced in each of the next three years with more dependent people. Resthaven's projections concluded:

. . . for South Australia there would be a marginal increase in hours approved for 1988-89 and then a gradual reduction into 1990-91 resulting in a decrease of time per resident per week. In the voluntary sector this would be nearer two hours per resident per week . . . Each hour or reduction over the state equates to the loss of 168 full-time equivalent jobs.
Directors of nursing in Victoria, Tasmania, South Australia, New South Wales and Queensland tested the RCI upon several nursing homes of member organisations. They determined:

Using the illustrative 17.1 National Average hours per patient per week the resultant staffing of nursing homes appeared to result in drastic cuts to nursing home `Nursing and Personal Care' staffing across all tested homes . . . We feel that without considerable modification of the Patient Classification Instrument the outcome from the use of the P.C.I. as a determinant of Nursing and Personal Care staffing levels will be disastrous.

And it will. We should recall the points already made by the AAVCA and the Private Geriatric Hospitals Association of Victoria, for instance. Since the introduction of the standard aggregate module (SAM) at least 916 beds are under receiver managership in Victoria. With further cuts scheduled on 1 July 1988, 1989, 1990 and 1991, it is expected that further problems will occur. Something must be radically wrong for at present 916 beds are under receiver managership.

With respect to the care aggregate module (CAM) component, the Government has developed a statistical profile of dependency using a much smaller sample than in the SAM survey. Previous studies such as the 1985 nursing inquiry in Victoria, the BENECS-the Joint Study by the Extended Care Society of Victoria and the Bendigo Home and Hospital-study in 1986-87 and the recent Victorian Aged Services Peak Council study on patient dependency all indicate that, at existing dependency levels in Victoria, 26.6 hours per resident week are required.

With minimal staffing who will properly look after patients once they are moved out of the nursing homes into the hostels? With the introduction of CAM from 1 July 1988 it will be possible for some nursing homes in New South Wales to have up to 70 different fees at any one time. Many would have at least 28 different fees. No consideration has been given for the additional administration costs involved, let alone the problems that will occur in the nursing home's operation. The fact is that many nursing homes will lose existing nursing hours that are currently providing basic nursing care. To stop the increasing incidence of sick leave, employee burnout and resignations, more hours are required, not less. In New South Wales there are hundreds of nursing home beds that could face closure.

The Government has not had proper regard for the human element in the staffing of nursing homes. It is not the easiest job in the nursing profession, and already the workload of the nursing home nurse is much heavier and requires much more face to face contact with patients than the counterpart in either the public hospital or the private hospital system. The Government and the Department have both failed miserably to consider the staffing element in these new plans. It is difficult to understand why, in an exercise which is supposedly centred upon cost reduction, the Commonwealth is insisting on the duplication of the inspection or monitoring process. Why is the Commonwealth not prepared to contract out to the State to do this job? Empire building is the obvious answer because the States already have the system in place.

Some strange statements have been made by the Minister, and I refer to articles that appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald on 6 and 7 April. The statement that nursing homes set their own fees is absolute rubbish. To then go on and state that `if fees exceed the pension the difference must come from the families of patients' or `patients would need to do unpaid work' is absolutely ludicrous. If the Government has any knowledge of the situation in the nursing homes and of the patients in them, how can any Minister of the Crown seriously suggest that those patients should make up the unpaid fees by doing unpaid work? It is an insult to the elderly Australians living in nursing homes.

The result of Labor's fiddling with the care of the aged is that more nursing home beds may close, forcing residents to look for alternative accommodation in our already overcrowded public hospitals, but more likely with their families. The Liberal and National parties have called for a trial run of the new nursing home funding arrangements in at least one government-owned and operated nursing home before its module is implemented Australia-wide. It is imperative that the Government ensure that its proposals work before inflicting irreparable damage on the nursing home industry by forcing its changes on residents, their relatives and staff.

I know that the Minister will make an announcement next week. It was originally scheduled for 19 April; now it is to be made on 21 April. I say to the Minister and to the Government, `For heaven's sake, do not rush in. Have a trial first before you completely destroy and disrupt this extremely valuable industry'. The time for trial and research of these new arrangements is now, not 12 months down the track, when the disruption and the reduction of services have already occurred. The aged care industry has expressed serious concern that the proposed new flat rate government subsidies for nursing homes will not meet the cost of caring for nursing home residents. Unless the Hawke Government conducts a trial of its new arrangements and finds out whether it will properly cover costs, nursing homes could close and residents could find themselves dipping further into their savings.

When the Government first announced its latest aged care policy, it said 25 per cent of nursing home residents would be shifted or relocated to hostels. Over the last five years admissions to nursing homes have been more stringently controlled than ever by Commonwealth medical officers, by assessment teams and by the homes themselves. This has meant that nursing home and hostel residents are significantly more dependent than they were in each preceding year. By and large, the people in nursing homes now are not capable of being moved out into hostels. But we are told by the Government that 40 per cent of the present population of nursing homes is to be moved into hostel care. All it proves is that this Labor Administration does not have a clue about the real needs of nursing home residents.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, I oppose the motion and take the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) to task. One of the very real problems in nursing home care has been exposed in the survey which was conducted recently. The conditions in nursing homes are a disgrace. Less than one in 10 of the residents in Australian nursing homes receive the hours of quality nursing and personal care assessed as appopriate for their needs. The situation is desperate, and it is this situation which our Government and the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) have turned their attention to and attempted to redress. The approach of the Australian Labor Party has not been high-handed and has involved a long period of consultation. Over the lengthy period, representatives of industry, aged people, a Commonwealth parliamentary committee and other bodies have been drawing attention to a very wide range of problems. As I said, one of their major concerns was the fact that only one in 10 residents received the hours of quality care that were appropriate for them.

SPEECH.PARA: There was also an unsatisfactory mix of services, particularly an excessive amount of nursing home accommodation and a shortage of hostel facilities and home and community care services. The kind of nursing home accommodation and accommodation for aged care which we have in mind is one of equity and opportunity. It also means that people will not be institutionalised. It is a key to give people an independent lifestyle, to be able to make a choice, to choose to live with their families. I am interested to hear that the honourable member for Cowper suggests that having aged people living with their families is not a viable option in his Party. This comes from the Party that espouses families and the joy of the family. Of course that is an option and people are entitled to make the kinds of choices and have the options which they want. We are talking about equality and equity no matter where people live in Australia and no matter how much money they may happen to have.

The other problems which emerged from that survey were the inadequate arrangements for the assessment of need, the very poor standards of care which were provided in many of our nursing homes and the inefficiency of the arrangements under which Commonwealth-funded nursing homes provided homes, with little management flexibility and no incentive for greater efficiency in their management processes. The key objective of the Commonwealth Government has been to implement a national aged care policy to provide greater choice of care for aged people and fairness for nursing home residents in the care provided.

In the 1986-87 Budget and since, the Government has provided significant additional money to implement that strategy, including planned increases in nursing home and hostel places in line with the ageing of our population. It has also increased resources of hostels, expanded assessment services, provided new funding for the care of dementia sufferers and increased access to care for both migrant and Aboriginal groups. In terms of the dementia program, I am very well aware of the kind of freedom of movement which such programs give people, allowing them to establish some kind of independence and quality of life. At the Neilsen Home in my electorate there is a dementia program from which 20 people have emerged to be able to live a more realistic life with much better quality.

Is this the kind of choice which is being denied to the aged people in our community simply because they are older and powerless? That kind of commitment from us is very important. Last year this Government announced that it would make major changes to the existing nursing home funding arrangements which were inequitable and based on cost reimbursement with no incentive for operator efficiency. They also involved excessive regulation and continued to produce unacceptable cost escalation and growth in government expenditure. The changes are now to be phased in over the period of 1 July 1987 to July 1991. Those proposed new arrangements are based on the recommendations of the working party and they attempt to achieve greater social equity in the way in which the Commonwealth provides support to people who need nursing home care.

I reiterate that it should not matter where one lives or how much money one has when determining the quality of care to which one is entitled. Directors of nursing will have much greater flexibility and there will be incentives for nursing homes to manage their resources more efficiently according to the needs of their residents and labour market conditions. This policy centres very much upon the needs of the residents, the assessment of those needs and delivering services that cater for the needs of our aged community. This is a client-oriented program, not a finance-oriented program. We are on about delivering care to people in our community, many of whom, because of their age and situation, are powerless.

It is our duty to ensure that, no matter where these people live, the quality and type of care which best suits them is delivered. That is what we are about and that is what this program attempts to do. In essence, the working party proposed that future funding for nursing and personal care staff be based on residents' needs. A new classification system has been developed extensively and trialed. It will determine in which of the five categories a person will be classified. The dollars will flow from there. The kind of scaremongering which has gone on at times has been somewhat frightening. I draw people's attention to the fact that in Queensland the money for aged people's care is only $282 per person in nursing home care, compared with $418 in Victoria. Are we suggesting that because people live in Queensland and have been shabbily treated by many of their State governments they should not be entitled to the extra care which many of the residents in other States get? Of course we are not. We are talking about providing a system of care which is for everybody, irrespective of where people live or the kind of money they have in their pocket.

One of the nursing homes in my electorate, Canossa, which is run by the Canossan Sisters, provides excellent care for its residents. It provides a wide range of care: through individual units, hostel accommodation for people who are mobile, a migrant section for people who have had difficulty in learning to speak English and who, in their later years, wish to participate in a lifestyle which is very much part of their own country, and nursing care for people who are extremely ill and senile. The quality of care there is determined not by the dollar but by the dedication of the women who work in that hospital because they have a commitment. It is that kind and quality of care which I want to see spread across Australia.

It is not possible for the rest of the community to be served by people such as the Canossan Sisters, people who are particularly committed. It is that quality of care which they can deliver which we must ensure is delivered to everybody. There is no problem for our Government in suggesting that everybody in our community is entitled to have his or her care needs met. Surely, if such a system is to be put in place by this Government it cannot be argued that we are attempting to debilitate the aged and frail. That is simply a nonsense. It is also a nonsense to suggest that the new arrangements will provide directors of nursing with great staff changes. The new arrangements will allow directors of nursing to average out their staff over a full year. They will then not have to make sudden staffing adjustments. Under these new arrangements directors of nursing, by offering to accept more dependent or less dependent new residents, will be able to influence their resident service needs mix to match their staffing resources. So it is in fact a question of directors of nursing being able to assess their residents' needs, assess their staffing resources and match them adequately which surely brings about the best and most efficient delivery of service.

In terms of the trialling of the resident classification instrument, there has been a great deal of confusion and a great deal of discussion. However, the nursing home industry has been extensively involved in the trials of the new resident classification instrument through which individual nursing homes will be applying the proposed new system to individual residents. There have been three sets of trials. The first two sets covered a sample of nursing homes in four States-surely a very wide-ranging sample. The third set of trials sought to cover every non-government nursing home in Australia, and 95 per cent of them actually participated. It was at the end of the first two trials that extensive feedback and discussion sessions were held with the directors of nursing of those homes. In the case of the third set of trials, every director of nursing around Australia was invited to provide comments on the new arrangements. A substantial proportion accepted that invitation. I suggest to the House that people cannot complain about not being consulted if they failed to take up the consultative processes placed in their way but subsequently did not like the way in which they saw things being met.

The suggestion that aged person needs should be at the forefront of the kind of care and services which are delivered by nursing homes seems to have raised quite considerable discussion. I thought nursing homes were there specifically to provide the best sorts of services and to meet the needs of their own residents, but I fear there are members of the Opposition who suggest this is not so. Moreover, we have seen that the new resident classification system is based on the perceptions of more than 1,200 directors of nursing and the way in which they deliver their services to meet the needs of their residents. I simply draw attention to the fact that to suggest there has been no consultation is blatant nonsense.

We also had a list of serious problems which very many members of the Australian Voluntary Care Association suggested would accrue. Let me say as someone who visits a vast range of nursing homes, and who did so for a very long time prior to my political life, that many of the services which are delivered to the aged within our nursing homes are almost entirely dependent on the way in which nursing directors and staff tend to operate. If we have good directors of nursing and people who are committed and who care-and I have cited two such homes in my electorate, Canossa Hostel and Neilson Home-we can be assured that, irrespective of whatever money we as a government place, those services will be delivered, and that people will not be condemned to sitting round doing nothing, to not being fed properly, to not being washed properly, to finding themselves covered with bedsores. To suggest that communication between patients and their families will be affected is surely blatant nonsense. Indeed, such values and practices are inherent within the nature in which hostels and nursing homes operate. It is surely imperative that we as a government seek to ensure that directors of nursing homes and their staffs carry out all kinds of needs of their patients, not simply those which they perceive to be at the forefront.

We have also heard that the Minister is incorrect when he says that fees are set by nursing homes. Indeed, I can cite a number of cases of fees having been set by nursing homes. I think we could all cite cases of residents in nursing homes, particularly in hostels, doing voluntary work in exchange for the payment of fees. What we are seeking, and what we hope will happen in the delivery of this program, is that no pensioners will be required to pay more than 87.5 per cent of their pension for the kind of care that will best serve their needs. They are after all people who have contributed to our country. They are people who are deserving in their old age of being looked after and cared for. They also have individual needs. It is the assessment of those individual needs which this new program attempts to set straight. It is simply a question of not putting people into institutions and suggesting that everybody is the same. Surely we are talking about the rights of an individual, an independent lifestyle, and a departure from institutionalising people so that our aged maintain a quality of life in what is very definitely becoming an ageing Australia. I reiterate that this Government does not intend to back away from the broad approach it has adopted in this matter of care for the aged. It certainly will not be found parroting the concern of vested interests at the expense of people in need.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Millar Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Initially I address the remarks of the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford) who in a spirited presentation expressed a number of general principles with which honourable members of this House would not disagree. They are laudable objectives. The difference rests in the means employed to attain the objectives. My colleague the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) was less than fairly treated when he was charged with having stated that there had been no consultation. That was not the case. His lament rested on the fact that there is a gap between consultation and implementation. To ensure that we do not in all good intent embark on a policy which may lead to an adverse result we should have a pilot arrangement to test such measures thoroughly. The Government then would be in a position to embark more confidently on their general application. As I say, there is a difference in attitude as to how the objectives might be achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst we talk of adequate consultation or inadequate consultation, the inescapable fact remains that there is a very significant disparity in the calculations of the aged care industry and the Government's advisers in respect of the care aggregated model. Surely, if the industry calculates a requirement of 27 hours a week for intensive care, and it is the Government's proposition that there be only 17, that would suggest, indeed insist, that someone is very much wrong. Though I thought the honourable member for Forde impugned some within the aged care industry, implying a lack of moral respectability in the way they exploit, inferentially, the aged for profit, there are an overwhelming number of establishments where that motivation is conspicuous by its absence.

The honourable member for Forde cited the Sisters of Mercy. Every honourable member of this House will have visited nursing homes within his or her electorate and will have no doubts as to the integrity, competence and veracity of nursing home administrators and staff. Those are the people who are saying that the proposal will leave them in a state of total disarray which must lead inevitably to a lack of adequate care for those who, on everybody's assessment, have an urgent requirement. Are we to adopt the stance predicated on alleged immorality of the administrators within the industry, or are we to accept that there is ample evidence in the broad that there is a respectability, efficiency and competence within the application of these quite laudable ambitions of the Government and of the House to relieve the needy? The honourable member for Forde, on my understanding, is quite insistent that all aged persons in Australia, regardless of their walk of life or means, should have an entitlement to adequate care. I rather deduced that the entitlement related to government input, that the taxpayer would have to foot the bill. At the risk of offending some, I must say that I regard that as absolute nonsense.

Ageing and dying are as much a part of life as is birth. If the people so beset by those unhappy circumstances have the financial resources to sustain themselves they should be obliged to do so. However, those people who are denied such resources must, of necessity, become the charge of the state, if I may use a term that has some ugly connotations. In reality the taxpayer will assume the burden to ensure that those people spend their last years maintaining, to the extent that it is possible, their dignity and being afforded the care that reconciles with the standards that we believe should attach to the treatment of our fellow human creatures.

In that situation the resources of the Commonwealth could be more effectively applied to those people who demonstrably are in need of it, not just because of their physical condition but because of their financial resources also. If we were restricted to meeting that requirement, clearly the resources available would have a much wider spread in terms of in-depth care. That is what it is really about. The inescapable fact, as I mentioned before, is that there is a massive disparity of opinion among those who, by any measure, should have a competence to express a view. Somebody must be very seriously wrong. The only way to establish beyond question of doubt as to where the truth lies is to conduct a pilot trial. We are not dealing with constants with aged people. There is a diurnal variation. We do not have a mode in terms of nursing home inmates. They are all different, as we have all witnessed sadly when we have visited those places. There must be a significant factoring of requirement to meet the unexpected-the variations in their particular needs and their behaviour on a given day. We cannot meet that requirement if staff are continually stretched to breaking point trying to do that which is beyond their capacity because of the lack of fiscal support and because of the physical restraints.

In short, somebody must be wrong. It would be derelict of this Parliament to ignore the submissions of those who should know and, I insist, do know where the truth of the matter lies. The only way we can achieve satisfaction in that respect is to conduct a trial for a reasonable period to establish beyond question of doubt whether the scheme will work. There will be massive disarray in the aged care industry, within nursing homes in all our electorates, when it is demonstrated, as unquestionably it will, that this well-intended-I concede it is well-intended-move by the Government falls lamentably short of its objective. We cannot simply dismiss that as an unfortunate circumstance and go back to square one and start again, because considerable damage will have been done.

I acknowledge that by using statistics the Government has manifestly made efforts to meet the requirements of the aged. There have been significant funding increases, of 11.6 per cent, 10.8 per cent and 38.5 per cent, for aged persons home and hostels, home and community care and hostels care subsidy in the prevailing Budget. Notwithstanding that, we are faced with the unfortunate reality that there is a considerable gap between that which is desirable and that which is attainable. Notwithstanding the laudable ambitions of the honourable member for Forde, we are not going to be able to accommodate the expectations of all those who may turn to the Government-the taxpayer-to meet their requirements.

The state of our Budget reflects that unhappy circumstance. In the ultimate we have to make judgments as to how we can best accommodate those who have a demonstrable dependence-I underline the word `dependence'-on the taxpayers' magnanimity or sense of duty and responsibility to their fellows. There are not the means, nor will there be the means. One could open up the Budget blindly and put one's finger on any page and see that this is so. The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) is sitting on the front bench here in the House. He is a gentleman for whom we have a high regard, even if at times we submit to human frailty and make mildly offensive comments about him. He knows very well that he could double his defence budget and still not be thoroughly satisfied that Australia was as secure as he would wish. In any area of government responsibility we will find that there is a shortfall because of the limit on our resources. Unless we address that particular matter as a nation with a common sense of purpose we are going to find our conditions worsened rather than improved.

We accept the fact that something has to be done. I personally am prepared to concede that the Government, on advice, has moved in the direction of achieving that desirable objective. But the nub of the matter is that there is a very substantial division of opinion as to what should be achieved, how it should be achieved and, in the ultimate consideration, what benefit that may bring to those who in their declining years can fairly expect the compassion and support of their fellows. I support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak in opposition to the motion I would like to dwell on a point raised by the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl). In perhaps a moment of clairvoyance, it seemed he deigned to read my mind when he said that he felt that I would stand up and accuse him of embarking on some fearmongering campaign. I think it is outside the Standing Orders and not proper to impute motives to the honourable gentleman. However, I make the comment in regard to the accusation of fearmongering because this is a very sensitive debate. The members of the community that use nursing homes are a very frail and elderly population. They are susceptible to being misled. We need to have a careful and rational debate about the issues that arise in regard to changes to nursing home policy. That is not to say that both the honourable member for Cowper and the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar) have not tried to make reasoned contributions to the debate today.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the present situation as it applies to nursing home care. I think it is acknowledged that this is an area-I will try not to be partisan in these comments-that has been neglected in the past. It is an area that the Federal Government needs to look at seriously. A series of recent studies and reports indicates the issues that need to be addressed. I will cite just a few of them. In 1981 there was an efficiency audit by the Auditor-General. There was a report of the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing chaired by Senator Giles. There was the report of the House of Representatives Expenditure Committee chaired by the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay). Finally, there was of course the 1986 Review of Nursing Homes and Hostels by the Department of Community Services. It is interesting to reflect that this present debate on the new classification system arose from that review of 1986. Senator Grimes announced on 16 April that there would be a review and that one of the important elements of the strategy was to develop a funding system for uniform nursing home staffing standards appropriate to the achievement of the quality of care and lifestyle standards.

The important point we need to address is the right of people choosing to enter nursing homes to the best care possible. It is our duty to ensure that they get the best care possible and that we maintain the standards. What Senator Grimes and the review of 1986 highlighted was the need to eliminate the current interstate and interhome inequities in the funding of the nursing home program and that these should be expressed as staffing hours per resident day. I highlight some of the disparities at present. In Victoria the Commonwealth benefit per week is $418. In Queensland it is $282 a week and in New South Wales $325.

These are some of the issues that the present process has tried to address. Let us look at the arrangements that are under discussion and that are likely to be the subject of some comment next week by the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples). We must look at these new arrangements and ask what they will achieve. Firstly, they will achieve a great deal of equity. People with the same care needs will receive the same staffing resources.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member for Scullin will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Government promotes Australian agricultural produce as being free from nuclear contamination and non-irradiated.

This notice was placed on the Notice Paper on 15 September last year and I am pleased that it has been brought on at this time. Australia's reputation as a food exporter would be enhanced if Sydney's Lucas Heights nuclear reactor were shut. That would be considered a radical statement, calling as it does for the closure of the Lucas Heights nuclear reactor. Who would make such a call? The call to close Lucas Heights came from the President of the National Farmers Federation (NFF), Ian McLachlan. It is reported in the 26 March 1987 edition of The Land. Under the heading `Call for ``Nuclear-free'' Agriculture', the newspaper article says:
Australia's reputation as a food exporter would be enhanced if Sydney's Lucas Heights nuclear reactor was shut, the President of the National Farmers' Federation, Ian McLachlan, said.

Mr McLachlan's call last week for the closure of the Lucas Heights reactor-hit recently by a fire scare-so Australia can claim nuclear free-status is a view shared by many of our customers in south-east Asia.
They are becoming deeply worried about buying European food in the wake of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster in Russia.

Mr McLachlan reported to the National Farmers Federation annual conference in Canberra in May 1987 that he had been in Europe when the Chernobyl accident occurred. He reported seeing an overwhelming commercial interest in farm product free from the risk of nuclear accident. The concerns of the NFF President were reported in The Land of Thursday, 14 May 1987. That report says:
He-
that is, Mr McLachlan-
was aware that Australia had had `piles of milk powder hanging around' before the accident-
that is, Chernobyl-
which had now `disappeared' into Asian markets.
`If we are to keep ahead of a fiercely competitive pack in the years to come, we must investigate and exploit every other possible commercial advantage', he said.

`The future for all our agricultural products lies in capturing the premium end of markets, investing heavily in research and development, packaging, promotion, getting consistent quality and ensuring reliability of supply.'

At this point it is worth while reflecting on what happened at Chernobyl two years ago. I refer to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation program Countrywide of 22 April 1987 which dealt with Chernobyl, a year after the disaster. The Countrywide reporter said:
The station-
that is, Chernobyl power station-

is spewing a radioactive cloud over Europe. A melt-down is the disaster long feared in the nuclear power industry, but the accident at the Chernobyl power station in the Ukraine is apparently even more complex. That's because the ignition of graphite is fanning the release of radioactive waste. Western experts say there's nothing to be done until the reactor burns itself out.
The reporter continued:
Radioactive iodine, caesium and strontium, all cancer causing elements, have become lodged in parts of the food chain and time, it seems, has far from eased the situation.

After the two explosions at Chernobyl, broadleaved vegetables in Italy measured 400 times the legal levels of radiation. The entire vegetable crop was destroyed and farmers were compensated. Consumption of home grown vegetables was banned but the caesium will remain in the soil for 30 years. In the hill country of Wales 300,000 sheep on 300 farms are declared unfit for slaughter because of the high levels of radiation in their meat. The farmers were told the restriction on slaughter and movement would be lifted in the third week of February this year-that is, ten months after the accident. The Government has extended the ban on the sale for human consumption of the 300,000 sheep for a least one more year.

Then there is the general case of the European lakes. Caesium now rests on the lake beds. Only a small percentage of lakes have been examined but the scientific presumption is that all are contaminated and the creatures of the lakes are now consuming high levels of caesium.

The level of caesium in milk went up by ten times and this has tended to stay high, but at a level well below the peak. But now the caesium content of milk is again rising as the contaminated hay cut last summer is fed to the cows.

Millions of dollars worth of food has been destroyed and with all this, the Russians have not paid one kopek in compensation. And now a team of Japanese scientists tells us that things can only get worse. They say that the Russians have grossly underestimated the environmental effects, in fact the water table in Russia is contaminated with twenty times the level of caesium, strontium and plutonium that the Russians claim.

The Japanese scientists say these elements will work their way slowly to the Black Sea and then, in some years, plutonium, strontium and caesium will be deposited in the fish of the Mediterranean and there it will remain for a very long time. That is one year after Chernobyl.

One of the legacies to result from that disaster is that Australia is now promoting its produce as radioactive free. Take the case of powdered milk: we've almost sold out of this season's stocks already with Japan and South East Asia preferring our supplies to those from Europe.

Nuclear power is being promoted as an environmentally safe alternative to coal, gas and oil-fired power stations. With a growing awareness of the fragility of our environment, the nuclear club has jumped on the bandwagon and is using environmental arguments to promote its industry. There are accidents in conventional power stations, but these do not result in millions of hectares of agriculture land being wiped out for decades, perhaps for ever. The proponents of nuclear power argue that it is a safer industry than the conventional power industry because of the low accident statistics. The facts disprove this claim. Figures compiled by the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) show that in 1985 there were 750 emergency plant shutdowns-28 per cent more than in 1984. There were 3,000 nuclear mishaps reported to the NRC-23 per cent more than in 1984. Any one of these accidents could have led to another Chernobyl. Further and more frightening details of nuclear power station accidents are reported in other documents.

If we think we are remote from this process at this stage, we are lulling ourselves into a false sense of security. There are energy experts on record as advocating a new nuclear power station sited in the south east of South Australia serving via a grid the States of New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania and South Australia. This information is contained in an article entitled `Electricity and Gas Supply in South Eastern Australia, 1980-2020' in Energy Economics of January 1985. The nuclear power proponents argue the safety and confinement of any minor accidents. Three Mile Island and Chernobyl literally blew their argument apart. If a nuclear power station were sited in the south-east of South Australia and a major accident occurred, prime agricultural land in South Australia, Victoria and New South Wales would be wiped out and the prevailing winds could carry nuclear debris down to Tasmania with devastating results for that State's agricultural economy, not to mention the disastrous effects on the health of the population.

Contamination from Chernobyl, a nuclear power station, has had its greatest impact in the Northern Hemisphere. Australia has been fortunate, as has New Zealand, in that the contamination and fallout in the Southern Hemisphere have been only slight. One of our immediate major trading competitors in this area is New Zealand. That country can boast about its record on broader nuclear questions. On the agricultural front, New Zealand is promoting its products as coming from a country which has a clean, green image. This view was promoted in a paper on food irradiation presented by two of the delegates to the fifty-sixth Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science Congress in New Zealand in January 1987. Their view was that New Zealand would, if it were silly enough to adopt food irradiation, be giving away a major trading advantage.

Worldwide, governments and consumers more and more are questioning the price and quality of the food products they import from outside their national borders. In this respect, we only need recall the recent limitation placed on our beef exports by the United States Government because of pesticide contamination. I think it is worth quoting a reference in a Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health pamphlet which deals with the new awareness of the consuming public about what to eat. The pamphlet states:

We live in a community becoming more and more nutrition conscious, diet conscious and consumer conscious. People today are interested not just in whether something tastes good-or whether the children will eat it; they are interested in whether it is good for them; they are interested in what it has in it.

I should now like to refer to the food irradiation connection. The food industry recognises that there is massive public opposition to mixing nuclear technology and food products. This was evident during a 1985 agricultural conference held in Canberra when a spokesman for G. J. Coles dealt with the question of food irradiation. He said:

I think my first priority above all would be to endeavour to devise some alternative name other than irradiation, which would hopefully have less of a `scary' image for the shopper and ultimate consumer.
There is a clear link in the minds of consumers between food being irradiated by radioactive fallout and food being irradiated by the use of radioactive cobalt 60.

I find one aspect of the pro-irradiation argument most repugnant, and that is the line that irradiated food is the answer to Third World hunger. This is a most offensive argument because the types of food being proposed-prawns, chicken meat, strawberries and exotic tropical fruits-are not exactly the staple diet of the Third World. These are the luxury foods of an affluent community. One of the answers to Third World hunger is a distribution of the world's food excess from the stockpiles in the United States and the European Economic Community. The irradiation of food should not even be on the agenda, let alone be touted as the saviour of the starving.

Contamination from nuclear fallout can give us a contaminated food chain. It may be somewhat ironic that the food irradiation process also has very strong links with contaminated food-that is, the use made by food irradiation technology to attempt to `clean up' contaminated food. Any advantages we may have in living in the Southern Hemisphere and being reasonably free from nuclear fallout would be lost if we were foolish enough to embrace food irradiation technology. Some of the attempts to `clean up' contaminated food-that is, food unfit for human consumption-have been detected and recorded. This sort of thing has happened in Europe and it has happened here in Australia.

Two batches of imported shrimps were irradiated in 1978 to reduce the microbiological levels. They were contaminated. The shrimps were irradiated and were then sold to Chinese restaurants in Melbourne. The report which dealt with this contamination stated:

In 1978 a crisis occurred when, without notice, microbiological standards for frozen food were amended and made more stringent. Tonnes of frozen shrimps, in transit to Australia when the National Health and Medical Research Council (NH&RC) standard was imposed, were placed in quarantine in cold storage warehouses in Sydney because the shrimps failed to meet the new microbiological specifications. Faced with the prospect of dumping or re-exporting the shrimps, and consequent financial loss, two importing companies obtained permission to examine the feasibility of using radiation to reduce the microbial population to acceptable levels. Subsequently these companies were granted a once-only approval to irradiate and market 47 and 14 tonnes of frozen shrimps respectively.
This paper is an account of various aspects of this first limited commercial application of food irradiation in Australia.

Irradiation used to clean up contaminated food is one of the serious problems we will have to face if we go down that track. Further, there is no known commercial method to detect whether food has already been irradiated. An additional problem would be the cost of the irradiation process, which would be passed on to the consumer. The loss of nutritional value and the loss of vitamins as a result of irradiation have been well documented. Another major problem is, of course, the safety of food that has been irradiated.

I mentioned at the commencement of my speech that this motion was put on the Notice Paper on 15 September last year. I am pleased that the House has determined since that time that the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts should continue its inquiry into food irradiation in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I second the motion and reserve my right to speak at a later time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this afternoon with extreme reluctance to respond to the motion moved by the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott). My reluctance is not because the matter is not an important one. We all know that to many people food irradiation is a very significant and highly contentious issue. I do not rise because I doubt the concern and the commitment of the honourable member for Hindmarsh. I think he is probably more sincere about this topic than anyone else in this country. The honourable member has, if I can use the term, a consuming interest in this matter. I am reluctant because I believe that the timing of this motion is very inappropriate. I realise that the motion was placed on the books some months ago, but there has been time for it to be withdrawn. I believe that debating it in this House today will inhibit the process of reasoned and informed debate on this highly contentious issue of food irradiation.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter is being considered by a committee, and I should like to enlighten the House on what has taken place. As Deputy Chairman of the former Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation and as Deputy Chairman of the present Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, I believe that some important facts must be raised in the debate today. The former Environment and Conservation Committee commenced taking evidence on food irradiation some 12 months ago. With the formation of the new House Committee, the former Minister for Consumer Affairs, the present Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), referred this matter to the Committee for an intensive inquiry.

The honourable member for Hindmarsh had approached the Committee Chairman, my friend the very hard working member for La Trobe (Mr Milton), and urged that an inquiry be undertaken into food irradiation. He pressed upon that Committee the need to have such an inquiry and the Committee was very happy to do that. The Committee has taken nearly 3,000 pages of evidence from organisations which are opposed to the process of irradiation, from some organisations which totally support the process and from others who can be described as experts who recognise both sides of the debate. Any member has the right to hurry along a parliamentary committee which appears to be dragging its feet. I hardly think that such a claim could be sustained against the Environment Committee on this issue. I am sure that the Committee Chairman will agree with me on that. That being the case, it is entirely inappropriate for the House to be asked to debate this matter until the Committee has tabled its report. The report is expected to be tabled in October.

I have too much respect for the processes of this House and its committee system to pre-empt, during this debate, any decisions the Committee may take. However, this motion, and some of the information which has been presented to the House by the honourable member for Hindmarsh, require a few salient points to be made. The honourable member for Hindmarsh has provided the House-I think that there is no argument about this-with only one side of the debate. The Environment Committee has received extremely well-researched and persuasive submissions from those opposed to the process. In most cases, the submissions were very well prepared. The challenge for the Committee, and eventually this House, is that the submissions from supporters of the process are equally well-researched and persuasive. Unlike the honourable member for Hindmarsh, I think it inappropriate to attempt to weigh the evidence for either side before the process is complete. It cannot be done in a 45-minute debate.

For the sake of debate, let me attempt to mention some of the benefits claimed for the process. Firstly, with the banning of some chemical fumigants and the potential banning of others, it has been argued that irradiation of grains in particular and some fruits provide, a feasible, safe and effectively alternative. Such is the case, for example, with the mango seed weevil, which cannot be touched with fumigants. It has been proven to be able to be removed by the irradiation of the mango. Secondly, it has been argued that the process can reduce the dangers of food poisoning from salmonella in chicken. I am sure that that will be hotly debated by Labor speakers. A third benefit, it is claimed, is the extension of shelf life for a limited range of products.

Finally, it needs to be pointed out that not all foodstuffs will be involved, nor will consumers be denied access to non-nuclear foods. If-I emphasise the word `if', because absolutely no decisions have been made by the Committee, nor are there any feelings as to how the decisions will go-the process is approved, controls will be stringent and only a few foodstuffs will be involved. I have no time to discuss the evidence of the significant export expansion that could also result from this process. A number of countries have approved this process. I seek leave to table a list of those countries and the foodstuffs involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?
—What is it?
—It is a list of the countries that have already approved the irradiation of various foods for human consumption.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. As mentioned earlier, the Environment Committee's report on this matter will be available for debate during the Budget session, perhaps towards the end of that session. The issue is complex. Expert opinion is divided. Both sides need to be heard and examined critically. One cannot do so on an occasion such as this. That kind of critical examination and reasoned and comprehensive debate will probably go on and on irrespective of what the Committee's findings might be. It certainly cannot be conducted without the benefit of extensive investigation and clarification of the problems which will result from the Committee's report, as I have indicated on a number of occasions. For that reason, I cannot support the motion. The debate today should be used, and ought to have been used, as a way of alerting honourable members to the issues which will be debated more appropriately later in the year. We should respect the committee process of the House. We should not pre-empt proper inquiries. Therefore, we should not carry this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised that the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) has taken the position that he has because I would have thought that, as a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, which is carrying out an investigation into this issue, he would want as much debate as possible and would want people from every walk of life-politicians, scientists or consumer advocates-to come forward and express a point of view. As the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) explained so properly, this issue was brought up and placed on the Notice Paper a long time ago. It is timely that we debate the issue because food irradiation has been around for four decades.
—They are afraid of public debate.

—I agree with the Minister. The process has been around for four decades, yet we still do not know enough about its long term effect on humans. Throughout the world there are two distinct camps-those for food irradiation and those against it. But in the middle there is a huge group of people who do not know. There have been dozens of studies and hundreds of reports and they are mostly conflicting. The use of food irradiation is being pushed very hard by the nuclear industry and major food manufacturers. If it was a safe way of extending the shelf life of a product, a way in which we could improve this country's exports in terms of the commodities we sell across the world and a way in which we could bring about a new quality of life for Third World countries whose people do not have refrigeration or for whom it is an unaffordable luxury, I would support it-provided it was safe.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not blame the exporters, food processors and some primary producing organisations for wanting governments to deal with the issue and, finally, to approve its use, but I do not condone the special interest groups with which the honourable member for Macquarie obviously wants to align himself, particularly the nuclear industry, and the multinational food companies that are directing this debate and conducting a worldwide campaign to try to convince consumers, governments and producers, and in fact the world, to adopt the process without examining the risks. I do not condone what I believe is a bodgied up debate. That is what has been happening across the world. Even in our own country the Atomic Energy Commission is sending people to speak at technical and further education colleges, institutes and producer-sponsored forums around this nation to promote food irradiation. I do not condone the nuclear industry combining with others in the world and setting down a strategy, as it says, to convince and convert the world to use this process. I believe that there has to be a balanced approach. That is what this Government is doing. Despite the confusion and conflict of opinion, this Government funded an inquiry through the Australian Consumers Association. This Government also ensured, initiated and supported the very committee of which the honourable member for Macquarie is now Deputy Chairman-a committee which, headed so ably by the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton), is carrying out an ongoing investigation into this very important issue.

I commend the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) because he has encouraged the States not to proceed with this process. They have a constitutional right to do so and that is the dilemma. The Commonwealth has a recommendatory power and controls over imports and exports, but it cannot stop any State from setting up a food processing facility, as Queensland wants to do. Let us realise that Queensland is well down the track. It has the land and I am told that it is well under way, using the Queensland Fish Board, to setting up an irradiation process for marine products. There is a concern and an urgency for this debate to continue. I also commend the Minister for acting to reverse the watering down of the labelling recommendations by the National Health and Medical Research Council.

I agree that there are two distinct sides to the argument and I recognise that many people do not understand what is going on. On the one hand there is the gung ho approach of the Queensland Government, about which I have spoken, the nuclear industry and many multinationals and, on the other hand, people are saying, `Put it on the back burner. We do not know enough about it'. It is not the Australian Labor Party in Queensland saying that. We have no official distinct policy. Thinking people are saying that the risks are there.

The British Medical Association has studied this question. What did its findings say? `Put it on the back burner'. What did the Canadian Parliament say? `Leave it on the back burner'. What did the Europeans say? `Leave it on the back burner'. What did the New Zealand Government say after its inquiry? `Leave it on the back burner'. Countries around the world are saying this. The honourable member for Macquarie has tabled a list of all the countries using food irradiation. What he has not bothered to say is how the countries differ. South Africa has a gung ho approach and I believe imposes no limitations on the dosage. It can be 25 kilograys if that is what processors want.

What about the United States of America? It imposes a limit of one kilogray. What do the Americans know that the South Africans do not know? What do the Americans know that we do not? In Australia the National Health and Medical Research Council has come forward with a recommendation of 10 kilograys. Why? I believe that it is because the Australian Atomic Energy Commission has argued that line. It argues the line that the World Health Organisation is also saying that it supports the process. But it does not bother to say that the World Health Organisation supports the idea of the extension of shop life but does not support irradiation simply to cover up contaminated foods. The honourable member for Hindmarsh has properly raised this issue. Rotten Malaysian shrimps exported to England were rushed off to the Netherlands, irradiated, brought back and sold.

The point is that we cannot tell when a product is irradiated. Is it any wonder that very important nutritionists, dietitians, scientists and consumer advocates are saying, `Let us be careful about this because we do not know enough.'? We do not know the nutrition loss. We do not know the vitamin and mineral losses once we cook something that has been irradiated. We do not know the effects of irradiating a product. Whilst it might overcome some sort of bacterial problem, in a product such as chicken we could get rid of salmonella and end up with botulism. The studies of these effects are the ones we should be concerned about.

I believe that the inquiry is proper. I believe that the honourable member for La Trobe and the honourable member for Macquarie have taken a balanced attitude in this inquiry to ensure that all sorts of points of view are considered. But let us not try to stop debate. I think the honourable member for Macquarie was saying that he does not believe that the debate is proper at this time. Of course the debate is proper when right across the world we have commercial interests saying, `Cover up the word ``irradiation''; let us not use it'. In America there was an attempt not to use the word `irradiation' but to use the terms `peko fresh' and `peko waved'. Moves were made in this country barely a year and a half ago to have the National Health and Medical Research Council change the labelling provisions. That has happened here, and people wonder why honourable members get anxious about it. People wonder why we are concerned when we know the amounts of money, the billions of dollars, that will be open to the nuclear industry if this goes ahead, and when we know the millions of dollars that are being spent in a national and an international campaign to convince people to adopt this proposition.

I say that we do not know enough. Beverley Sutherland-Smith, a top Australian food writer, says the same thing. How do we overcome the labelling problems? How does the consumer know whether the product he is about to eat in a restaurant has been irradiated? Is the restaurateur going to list non-irradiated foods on one side of his menu and, on the other, the warning: `These are irradiated foods; watch out.'? When we buy an apple or a pear, will it have a stick-on label that says `Ionised'? Will there be some type of rule about that? It is ridiculous to suggest that everyone will know. What about the caterers and the fast food processors who work within the industry? We have no way of knowing what is irradiated. We do not know enough.

This is what the issue is about. This is why I commend the honourable member for Hindmarsh for bringing this issue forward. There ought to be further and ongoing debate. We need to know more about nutrient destruction. We need to know more about the degree of that loss. If we find that we can lose 50 per cent of vitamin C from potatoes, that all sorts of vitamins-vitamins A, B complex and E-can be diminished or destroyed by irradiation-and these findings are the results of studies overseas-surely no government and no parliament can say, `Go ahead gung ho on this issue because it means dollars for big business and for the nuclear industry'. I understand that the debate has to continue, but let us make it balanced. Let us make sure that the facts are continually brought before the people-this is the issue-because they are the ones who ultimately have to buy the product. I express grave concern at the debate that is taking place at this moment but I commend this Government for its positive and very balanced approach to the issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The time available for this debate does not permit me to develop an argument or to answer the remarks from the other side of the House. Australia is today facing a serious economic challenge. Our living standards are falling in line with increases in our balance of payments deficit and our foreign debt is in excess of $110 billion. While our manufacturing industries are struggling to survive, to become competitive and to expand exports, our primary industries are facing up to the challenge of earning a major part of our export income and expanding markets against intense competition and corrupt trading practices.

SPEECH.PARA: It is for this reason that I reject the motion moved by the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott). Its intent is obviously to restrict our options for research and investigation presently taking place into the process of irradiation. While I acknowledge the genuine concern of the honourable member with any processes relating to the nuclear industry, I suggest that his motives with this motion are to close off rational discussion. To use as an example the malfunction at Chernobyl, a nuclear power station, to develop his arguments against irradiation is indeed to draw a long bow. He knows better than anyone else in this chamber that the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts is in the final stages of reporting on this issue. He knows that many of the arguments he has espoused this morning are based on emotion and not fact and he knows that the process of irradiation is widely used throughout the world for the world's benefit in human health, quarantine and effective decontamination.

As a member of this Environment Committee inquiring into food irradiation, I have concerns about the process. There are questions to which I still require answers, particularly in the evaluation of research already undertaken. But on one aspect I am thoroughly convinced. That is, the food irradiation process is an effective alternative to chemical bactericides and pesticides, including the suspected carcinogen ethylene dibromide. It passes through the food without leaving any residue and it does not make food radioactive. I reject the suggestion that irradiation is not free of radioactivity.

Let us look very briefly at some of the facts. Food irradiation has been the subject of nearly 40 years of investigation in many parts of the world and is currently approved for use in more than 20 countries for over 40 products. This process of food preservation has been under consideration for some years by the National Health and Medical Research Council, the body which develops model food regulations for this country. The model regulation for food irradiation was endorsed by this Council in June 1986 and its adoption has been recommended to State and Territory governments. I remind the House that Australia has had a research program into food irradiation since 1960. The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics presently uses electronic beam technology at Odessa for all imported grain, and its use as an alternative to fumigation treatment for export wheat is at present being investigated by the Australian Wheat Board. An option being considered is the construction of a pilot plant at a grain port terminal for comparison with other technologies.

We all know some of the potential applications for food irradiation in Australia. One is the use of irradiation as a quarantine control treatment to disinfest fruit from fruit flies and mangoes from seed weevils. This is receiving the most attention because of the need to find an alternative treatment to the use of the potentially dangerous chemical ethylene dibromide. The effectiveness of radiation as a decontamination method for dried foods such as spices and other food ingredients suggests that these will be among the first foods to be treated commercially if this process is accepted. Consumer acceptance of irradiated food is yet to be tested in Australia and public education programs will be both necessary and essential. Regulations would need to require that food be labelled as treated with ionised radiation, and the consumer must be able to exercise the choice whether to eat irradiated foods.

It should be stressed that, on the basis of logistics alone, there is no expectation that all of any variety of food will ever be irradiated. In addition, not all foods can be successfully preserved by irradiation, and in those cases, of course, the process will not be used. The capacity to meet domestic and export markets for our agricultural products is immense, but all options to improve our marketing skills and to upgrade the quality and reliability of our product must be open for research and appraisal.
