DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Media Ownership-Tertiary Education-Chemical Warfare-Overseas Aid-Capital Punishment-Rural Roads-Physically and Mentally Handicapped-Middle East Conflict

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance relates to the concentration of media ownership, the threat that it poses to freedom of speech in Australia, and the way in which this Parliament is being treated with contempt by certain media magnates. I will not repeat what I have said many times in debates on the media and on trade practice legislation about the way in which the concentration of media ownership opens up a real threat, and one which can be demonstrated to have occurred, of edit- orial interference with both the electronic and print media in terms of what the public learns about what is happening. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) is trying very hard to get his Cabinet colleagues to understand the truth of what I am saying. I understand that he is not alone, but he and his colleagues are not winning at the moment. Without repeating those views I wish to refer some honourable members, who may not have seen them, to an exchange of letters in the Australian Financial Review between Mr Rupert Murdoch and me before Christmas, and between the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and me last week and on Monday of this week. The Treasurer has never explained to the public on what basis he allowed Mr Murdoch, an American citizen, to take over the Herald and Weekly Times under the Foreign Takeovers Act. Despite all the calls that have been made to him, the Treasurer has never said upon what basis he approved of that action in the public interest, which the Act provides he should consider. He has not supplied to me under freedom of information legislation any explanation for his approval. I am now taking the matter to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in order to obtain that information in the public interest.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also clear that the Government has not acted on the apparent breach of rulings of the Trade Practices Commission on the divestment of print by Mr Murdoch, and the refusal of the Government to strengthen the law leads only to the conclusion that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer have no desire, for short term political gain, to offend media magnates. They are not worried about what the consequences may be for their Party or for other parties or for the public interest. I intend to introduce a Bill in this House either next week or the week after, which is aimed at remedying what the Government will not remedy. We have had public clamouring from people such as myself, which led the Treasurer finally to veto Mr Murdoch's takeover of the Australian Associated Press Wire Service. Again, no real reasons were given, but one could imagine the threat to freedom of speech that such a takeover would have represented had it proceeded. Likewise, after much public clamouring, the Prime Minister ruled out the takeover of the Age by a foreigner who described himself as politically acceptable to the Australian Labor Party.

Public opinion is swinging against the Government in these areas. It is swinging against the concentration of ownership, especially foreign ownership, of our media. The Government ignores that public opinion; it is out of touch with reality once again. On the very day that the Treasurer made his final response to me in the Australian Financial Review, Monday of this week, he authorised Mr Murdoch to increase his stake in the Reuters' arm of Australian Associated Press to 97.6 per cent, thus removing virtually any Australian influence in Reuters, and to increase his stake in Australian Newsprint Mills to 50 per cent, the other 50 per cent being owned by New Zealanders. So our newsprint mills are no longer in Australian hands.

The Treasurer, in his correspondence with me and in various Press conferences, where he has been personally abusive to me-this pleases me because obviously I am getting close to the bone-says how great his cross-media ownership laws are, yet he seeks to extend the right of Press owners to hold shares in television. He claims he has tight cross-media ownership rules but he seeks to extend from 5 per cent to 15 per cent the right of Press owners to hold shares in television. Why does the Treasurer seek to do that? It is because some of those owners who are identified as being mates of the Treasurer and the Prime Minister do not want to comply with the law; they will have to divest if the limit is 5 per cent. What do the Treasurer and the Government say about that? They say, `We will change the law so that they do not have to comply; so they do not have to divest'. This Parliament is being made a mockery of.

Similarly, the Parliament, via a cynical deal in the Senate, about which I have spoken on a previous occasion, made the audience reach for one television owner a maximum of 60 per cent. In the United States of America the best parallel is 25 per cent. That is a cynical exercise to satisfy Bond media because it had acquired interests of that order. The Broadcasting and Television Act provides six months grace within which a person who exceeds the lawful limit can go to the Broadcasting Tribunal and rationalise his assets in order to comply with the law. That is a generous provision of grace. It was meant to help the working of the marketplace. However, these proprietors are deciding that they will not go to the Broadcasting Tribunal, which they want to be just an empty vessel; they will lobby both sides of the Parliament to try to have the law changed so that they do not have to divest and do not have to comply with the law in the same way as other corporate bodies and individuals have to do. I dissented from that particular law but it is the law of this country-a 60 per cent audience reach. But what will happen if they acquire interests that extend beyond the 75 per cent they are now asking for? They will want a 100 per cent audience reach. What will they want then? They will want the removal of local content in advertising and program making. They will want the removal of children's classification. These matters are costly.

They want to make massive profits from the licence so they want to introduce the North Atlantic formula programs; one does not even have to speak English to understand them. They are American made and are transmitted via satellite throughout western Europe and to any other place that would seek to have the telecast beamed down upon it.

What we then have is a major threat to our culture which coincides with the threat to editorial interference, about which I have spoken. The Parliament must take a stand. It is being made a mockery of. In these circumstances it is all the more important that we fund the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) to allow them to become more independent and to structure them to be more independent of government and to reflect the evolving Australia. The commercial stations cannot be relied upon to do this, I put out a Press release, which I think only the Age gave coverage to--

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder why.

—Because it is about the only independent form of media left in this country. I am grateful to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs for his interjection. It is always a delight when I speak on this subject to know that the Minister is present. In that Press release I made the point that the Government was wrong to be considering full advertising on SBS. Since that time, as a result of an expose by Mr Austin in the Australian, it has become evident that advertisers-and indeed anyone interested in the well-being of television in Australia-are against the idea. It would be far better for the Government to adopt the recommendation of Mr Huw Evans, who is retained by the Australian Film Commission to examine the Channel 4 concept in Britain, where licence fees of commercial stations actually fund the program. In that situation there is an independent program with built-in statutory independence. Indeed, there is even a concept of group advertising, where the advertising revenue goes back to the commercial stations. The licence fees that the commercial stations pay are used to fund the station. SBS would lend itself very much to that proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's funding could be augmented by using as a basis the commercial licence fees, which are probably now too low but are of the order of $80m. This would enable SBS to make and buy Australian programs that reflect the evolving Australian culture and are not imitations of the North Atlantic culture, which is being increasingly imposed upon us by the fact that the media magnates who, with their guaranteed five mainland capital stations, are now doing deals with production houses, especially in the United States, and getting economies of scale in that way. They are using their stations merely to transmit other people's products when we are trying to liberate ourselves from the colonialism of the North Atlantic and, from our own view of the world, we are looking at the Indian and Pacific oceans, the regions in which we are living, and through our own program making to enabling the world to see Australia and Australia's perspective.

I put it very strongly that we need three commercial stations with a smaller audience reach and networking by affiliation. We need an independent ABC without commercials and we need an SBS which is again funded separately by a combination of Commonwealth Government grants and by the licence fees paid by the commercials each with their statutory authority. Then we would have some choice and we might save our freedom of speech and our culture.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Neil Mr L.R.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the major challenges facing many families in the isolated towns and cities in my huge electorate of Grey is the challenge of providing a tertiary education for their children. The various colleges of technical and further education and the Whyalla campus of the South Australian Institute of Technology provide the constituents of Grey with some access to the tertiary level of education. However, the course and degree structures available are limited. The vast majority of my constituents wishing to enter higher education institutions are forced to leave their homes and move to Adelaide to gain access to either a university or college of advanced education.

SPEECH.PARA: I should point out that the least distance my constituents have to travel to gain access to such an institution is 200 kilometres, with many having to travel as much as 800 kilometres or more. Suffice it to say that the vast distances mean great hardship for the families of those who wish to pursue tertiary education. Firstly, the students are forced by circumstances to leave the family home and establish themselves in a new environment, often without the support of their families or friends. Secondly, unless there are relatives or friends in Adelaide, students need to find rental accommodation which will provide a sound environment in which to study. Thirdly, in Adelaide, like all cities, accommodation is not cheap. Rental prices for flats and houses are expensive and so are the additional costs associated with establishing a new home. These costs include such things as bond money, furnishings, appliances and all the other necessities required to make a home livable.

In effect, many of my constituents are forced to establish a second home in Adelaide so that their children can have the opportunity to study at a tertiary institution. For many families in my electorate of Grey the costs involved in establishing this second home are too high for the family to bear. As a result, all too often the decision is taken not to pursue further study in Adelaide but rather to try to enter the work force. Unfortunately, many very talented young people in my electorate never pursue higher education outside the electorate because they simply cannot afford it. I am sure that there are many honourable members from both sides of the House who represent country electorates that are remote from tertiary education centres and who understand the situation I am describing. I am sure that these members have been confronted, as I have, by parents and students who do not have the resources to face the enormous financial difficulties involved in establishing a second home far from the family home. Unfortunately, it is not only those who have to leave home who face financial difficulties in pursuing a higher education. More and more I am confronted by parents who have tertiary students living at home who are wholly or partially dependent upon their parents for income support.

It is my view, and it is a considered view after many years of trying to assist working families to obtain the best future for their children, that the Austudy payment for tertiary students is inadequate for their needs. It is my understanding that the Government is moving towards bringing the tertiary Austudy payment into line with the unemployment benefit rate. In my view, this should be of the highest priority. In fact, I would even go as far as to suggest that the Austudy rate of payment should be significantly higher than the unemployment benefit rate, especially when the student is living away from the parental home. This would provide an incentive for young people to pursue further study as well as to provide them with a degree of income security commensurate with their needs as students.

At present the full Austudy independent rate, regardless of the student's age, and the full away from home rate for students 18 years and over, is $91.20 a week. This is the same as the single unemployment benefit rate payable to 18- to 20-year-olds, but it is $17.20 a week less than the 21-year-old and above full unemployment rate, which is presently $108.40. This situation requires urgent attention, for, if we are serious about giving our young people the best opportunity in life, we must be prepared to pay them a decent living allowance whilst they are studying. In fact, the whole idea of student allowances is one that I feel needs revolutionary change from the concepts of the past to the realities of the present.

It is my view that student allowances should be made universally available to all tertiary students, regardless of their parents' income. I believe that the parental income test for tertiary student allowances is an anachronism that is no longer relevant to present needs or realities in our society. In the so-called good old days, when only the wealthy had access to tertiary education, it was quite understandable that the parents of students should rightfully have maintained their children during tertiary study, but those days are long gone. Entry to tertiary education is now available to all Australians, based upon their ability rather than their bank balance.

However, the ability of many students to sustain their studies in a long term is being determined more and more by their bank balance and less and less by their abilities. The notion therefore that you need to target student assistance programs only towards those on lower incomes becomes more and more discriminatory against working class people, whose incomes may be slightly above or below the cut-off point applied under the parental income test.

I recently had a family in Whyalla approach me with an example of how their 19-year-old son, who was studying electrical engineering, was granted only $14.43 a fortnight Austudy because his father's annual income of $27,000 was taken into account. In this case the son still lives at home as he is able to complete his particular course in Whyalla. However, can we really expect that a 19-year-old adult should be dependent upon his parents for income simply because he is a tertiary student? Can we really expect that parents should have to provide continued economic support for a 19-year-old adult tertiary student?

Recent figures from the Australian Institute of Family Studies indicate that it costs $93.73 a week for a family to keep a teenager living at home. One would presume that this figure would be much higher for young adults who are pursuing higher education. This figure does not include the cost of housing, transport and medical or dental expenses; it therefore cost nearly $5,000 a year to provide for a teenager at home. Under the present student assistance available to them, the family I mentioned earlier will receive only $375 a year to assist with the cost of providing a tertiary education for their 19-year-old son.

A 19-year-old on unemployment benefit currently receives over $4,742 a year regardless of his parents' income. I cannot see any reasonable argument put forward which explains why a 19-year-old tertiary student should not be receiving at least the equivalent to that of a 19-year-old unemployed person. As stated previously, I would argue that perhaps a tertiary student should be receiving more than the equivalent unemployment benefit, especially if he is living away from the parental home. If we want a skilled society which is ready to take advantage of the technological revolution, and one which is ready to take this nation into the twenty-first century, we must be prepared to pay for the education of our young people and we must be prepared to provide them with adequate levels of assistance to help them to complete their education.

This matter is of paramount importance to me because, as I have pointed out, it is creating terrible strains on ordinary working class families. Although some members might argue that a universally provided scheme of assistance to tertiary students would add an additional burden to the Federal Budget which is, of course, the first argument that would be used by those who opposed such a scheme, it is, however, unacceptable to allow inequity to exist simply because resources are supposedly unavailable to help to redress the inequity. Resources simply have to be found as a top priority if we are to address the serious anomalies that I have outlined here today. I urge all members here today to support me in my campaign to have the situation rectified and as quickly as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems inevitable that from time to time and for a variety of reasons, whether good or bad, differences between peoples and nations will be expressed in hostile actions and wars. Since the Second World War this globe has been afflicted by many wars. At present we have two major conflicts-the Iran-Iraq war and the war which still continues in Afghanistan despite Soviet claimed intentions to vacate that country in the near future.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no condonation of acts of war to observe that this is a reality which we seem to have to live with whilst striving to promote peace and to foster the endurance of peace. But when war breaks out, much as we would prefer that this never happens-that there should be no hostilities and that people should be able to determine the issues that divide them by international mechanisms-it is important to guard, so far as we can, against excesses and to mitigate the worst features. There are conventions which have been agreed upon between countries for that purpose; conventions relating to civilians, to torture, to the rules of war, and to the prohibition of certain kinds of weapons. But, unfortunately, as one weapon has been prohibited others have been found and the weapons which are found to replace the old weapons are usually more terrible than the old weapons themselves.

In this context, Mr Deputy Speaker, the use of chemical weapons is universally deplored and condemned in this country. The Government has itself pursued in its disarmament negotiations the objective of a comprehensive ban upon chemical weapons and that is an objective that I and we on this side entirely support and one that in government we would pursue. But we need to go further than urging the end to the use of chemical weapons and seeking to secure a ban on the use of those weapons and the production of those weapons and at the same time, of course, the destruction of those weapons.

Whenever people on this earth are afflicted by the disasters of chemical weapons we need to ask ourselves, as a civilised country, what we can do. I understand from what I have read in the newspapers and inquiries made by my office that an approach was recently made to the Australian Government from Iran, a plea to help in the care of war victims. I read from the Age newspaper of 8 April the following extract:

The Foreign Affairs Department told Iranian representatives in Australia that Australia's own hospital facilities were stretched and Europe was a better destination for the war victims. The department, however, is known to fear that Australian assistance to Iranian soldiers would compromise Australia's neutral stance on the Gulf War. `We have given them our responses', a spokesman said. `It is not possible for us to accept their soldiers'.

This was given, I understand, in response to a request to permit soldiers who had been injured by chemical weapons to be treated in this country. I understand that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade maintains that facilities in Iran for treating such victims are to be found and that there is no special expertise in Australia. I merely interpolate that it is probably unlikely that there is special expertise in the treatment of chemical weapons anywhere to be found in the world, since the use of chemical weapons has mercifully been somewhat restricted. But I would have thought that we would be in just as good a position as any country to provide help for the treatment of victims of chemical weapons.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, I understand, also maintains that it is most concerned about moving victims to Australia, and that this would only exacerbate their condition. On such a subject one does not want to be unnecessarily critical of the Government and I will not be. But I do think that whilst we do not take sides in the war between Iran and Iraq, and we support the Government's position on that, it is no betrayal of that principle to provide help to those injured by chemical weapons, from whatever country and whoever asks for it.

I would like the Government to ask itself this question: How can Australia, as a civilised country, help? We condemn the use of chemical weapons and that is right. But cannot we match our rhetoric with some actions? After all, rhetoric is cold comfort to those who have been injured. As a civilised country our condemnation of all governments of all people who use chemical weapons must be matched by more than words. I would hope that the Government would seek to assess what help can be given to the victims of chemical weapons, be they Iranians, be they Iraqis, be they Kurds, be they anyone else, either alone or in conjunction with other countries or agencies such as the International Red Cross, and so match our expression of concern and our expressions of condemnation with effective action for the victims of those weapons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The use of foreign aid development grants and subsidies to boost export orders for industrial enterprise in developed nations has been the subject of debate for many years. Much thought and action have gone into reaching a situation where, according to the report of the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau, which I received in my office today, and I quote, `A balance can, and should be found, between the humanitarian concerns of our aid and Australia's economic interests.'

SPEECH.PARA: However, my grievance today goes beyond the aid-trade debate to one of even deeper concern to me-the corporate abuse of the opportunity to enter the Third World, or the Two-Thirds World, as many aid assistants are now referring to it, by transnational corporations who do not merely exploit this opportunity for valid trade purposes, but who deliberately erode the position of consumers in underdeveloped countries, just in order to boost profits.

I will examine this process in the context of consumer activity against corporate abuse in the developed world. To the shame of the Western world, the nation which is already down and out may become a recipient of the developed world's rejects. I am referring to products that we do not want as a result of our consumer alertness in the West. I refer to the infamous example of baby formula which had been rejected by the United States Food and Drug Administration, being dumped on the Third World in the contaminated form of aid, with disastrous effect on young children. Thus consumer practice is not only the responsibility of individuals, but of governments, as well as the business sector.

Certainly consumers from developing nations could be forgiven for believing that Western consumerism, in focusing on issues such as the use of additives to make meat more pleasing to the eye, or irradiation to prolong the storage of grain, has no relevance to consumers in the Two-Thirds World, where the very presence of grain, in any form, can mean the difference between life and death. But appearances can be deceptive. Consumerism is not just about consumers rejecting or demanding additives, but about consumers' growing hostility to marketplace practices designed to put dollars in the well-lined pockets of the few at the expense of the many. It is about the manner in which some market barons pursue their profits to the health and safety detriment of those why buy and those who consume.

In this context, consumerism can effectively link issues common to both the developed and underdeveloped world alike, but given the harsher hand dealt out to consumers in the Two-Thirds World, it must be an aim of the Australian consumer movement to ensure that consumer abuses of practices in the developing world which are linked to the West are addressed. In Australia the issues are different depending on where you live, where you work, if you work. Aborigines, disabled, jobless, homeless, aged, low income earners, all have particular problems, but overall questions of safety, health and pricing affect all.

The Federal Government is striving to get some pricing justice by setting up a national prices network and I am one of a number of Government members who are taking a part there. I am a Queensland co-ordinator. In the developed world, the world of private enterprise, householders or consumers have had little say in the prices they pay. I believe current marketing practices should be challenged. I do not wish to attack business practice per se, but what morality is there in allowing the marketplace to influence pricing? My discussions with chain retailers at executive level in Queensland have revealed that competitive pricing, or charge what you can get, is the basis for pricing in Queensland in the 1980s. In fact when the age of the supermarket emerged the new barons of the marketplace told consumers that, although they may lose the service of the corner store in switching to the supermarket, the payoff would be cheaper prices as a result of bulk buying.

In Australia today, where is the promised trade-off, where is the cross-subsidisation to ensure that the profits of bulk buying flow on to the consumer, particularly in a monopoly or isolated situation? It does not exist and despite statements re narrow margins, the largest grocery chains are clocking up record profits. These, then, are the rewards of big business endeavour in Australia. What about the rewards of multinational endeavour? Are they too great? What effect do they have on the recipient consumer societies, and what responsibilities should and do multinationals assume to ensure that their intrusion does not cause greater problems for the society they claim to service but who, from the size of the rewards, could well be seen to be servicing their own desires for cumulative profits?

Governments in developed nations have for some years gone beyond direct food handouts to the setting up of training and development programs which will assist the recipient developing country to take steps towards self-sufficiency. But a well recorded phenomenon which Colin Hines and Barbara Dinham, researchers, call agribusiness has worked against the interests of these people whom the projects are designed to assist. This is how agribusiness works: citizens of an underdeveloped nation are dying of malnutrition. They are not self-sufficient in the provision of food for the millions of people. The developed world decides that it will meet its humanitarian responsibilities not only by shipping grain or direct food aid to the worst affected areas, but by setting up major agricultural projects designed to lead to self-sufficiency. But the nature of agribusiness is to make a profit out of the inputs to farming-that is, seeds, fertilisers, pesticides, agricultural machinery, management and consultancies, animal foodstuffs, research-as well as from the outputs of the farms.

Large companies such as Fiat and Coca-Cola have funded so-called agricultural projects which are intended to assist people in poorer nations, but which in fact assist to a far greater extent companies which make profits out of servicing the project. This phenomenon was started in about 1911 by W. H. Lever, forerunner to the world's biggest food business, Unilever. Money invested by Unilever and other multinationals such as ICI and Shell was designed to derive strength and profits from processing, trading, transport, marketing and distribution, often to the detriment of people in the Two-Thirds World.

Take Nigeria. In 1980 the Nigerian Government launched the green revolution, a program designed to bring new land under cultivation and in which the proposed investment of $US8.2 billion was involved. A United States and Nigerian joint agricultural consultative committee was established in July 1980. This committee included representatives from multinationals, such as Coca-Cola, Ralston Purina and the Ford Motor Co. as well as large banking groups and it was to be the principal vehicle for transfer of United States agricultural technology to Nigeria.

The move was commendable but according to Hines and Dinham the committee was involved particularly in supplying fertiliser, seed, milling and baking technologies, integrated poultry systems and methods for the small scale production and distribution of fresh produce. Another company-Pulman Kellogg-was involved in building a nitrogenous fertiliser plant. So who profited from the provision of fertiliser, seed, et cetera? Obviously United States farm exports to Nigeria as a result of projects such as this are big, big business involving big, big money. Did the project assist consumers in Nigeria?

A similar project certainly did not assist 60,000 peasants who lived in northern Nigeria and who were forcibly removed from the land on which the project was sited. They were reportedly unable to farm; they were given no compensation and finally they protested and the state called in armed police to put them down. What we are looking at here is an unholy stampede to exploit potential within the developing world, to syphon off what small money there is from that world. It would be too harsh a judgment and would be quite unrealistic for me to suggest that self-interest motivated most programs of this nature, and this is just not so.

Non-government organisations are doing a marvellous job in conjunction with the United Nations agency and, in the case of Australia, the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau and the Australian missions in Third World nations. But Western corporate practice can, and in many recorded instances has, encroached adversely on consumers in developing nations. In condemning this fact I do not attack small business, which is often the victim of the corporate creep. I do attack the system which allows uncontrolled accumulation of profits. For where is the halting point? What is the point of running sports aid projects such as the Bob Geldof effort, which was very commendable, when the very nations which we seek to help are being held back by corporate parasites who are deliberately exploiting people in nations already victims of widespread poverty and excessive foreign debt?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I happen to be one of those who believe capital punishment should be restored in Australia. Though my opinion may well be in the minority in this chamber it is certainly not in the community. In every opinion poll I have seen taken in Australia, more people are in favour of capital punishment than against. In recent years polls have varied from a majority of 43 per cent in favour up to 95 per cent in favour. However, most polls have returned a substantial majority of around 70 per cent in favour and about 25 per cent against, with a handful of people being undecided.

SPEECH.PARA: The classic case which shows how opinions on this issue cut across all barriers was a Morgan gallup poll taken in July 1986 regarding whether Australians who are convicted should be sentenced to death for drug trafficking in Malaysia. The question returned a result of 80 per cent in favour and 15 per cent against and the result was constant throughout all groups irrespective of how people voted, where they lived, whether they were male or female, and of age, occupation, education or income. Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to incorporate this poll in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. I believe there is a strong case for holding a referendum in each State to seek the views of the people on this issue. I believe there is also a strong case for re-introducing capital punishment for a whole host of crimes. This would include first degree murder, treason, some forms of brutalised rape and mutilation, some forms of kidnapping and terrorism, especially where lives were at risk, and for serious forms of drug running. Certainly the death penalty should not be restricted to the crime of murder.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Anita Cobby assailants had not actually murdered their victim, what they did to her up to that point would alone have justified the death penalty, in my opinion. Had she survived that brutal, degrading and horrific experience, she would have been mentally, if not physically, disfigured for life. Capital punishment has been carried out in several forms in different countries; we used to hang them in Australia. However, other countries have used methods which include electrocution, gas, lethal injection, firing squad, the guillotine, stoning, necklacing-which the African National Congress uses in South Africa-and torturing and mutilation.

I would favour lethal injection, which is really equivalent to an overdose of an anaesthetic, as it is quick, painless, non-ghoulish and would avoid a lot of the hoo-ha that surrounds most executions. Most people believe capital punishment should be carried out with a minimum of publicity. Capital punishment still exists in most countries of the world, with the exception of the Western countries. However, even among those that have abolished capital punishment, the general public are usually in favour of it and, in some cases, are even reintroducing it; for example, 37 of 50 States in the United States of America have done so.

In Australia we have hanged 114 murderers since 1901, with Ronald Ryan in Victoria the last to go in 1967. Of course, as recently as 7 July 1986 two Australians, Barlow and Chambers, were hanged in Malaysia for their drug activities. One of the prime arguments in favour of the death penalty is that the person who has committed the crime has forfeited his or her right to live. This argument says that so highly do we place human life itself that anyone who violates that principle through first degree murder and so on automatically forfeits his own right to live. Another argument in support of the death penalty is that execution prevents the criminal committing another murder.

It is recognised that the number of murderers let out of gaol who go on to murder someone else is low. That, of course, is only what you would expect. Nevertheless, there is a percentage of murderers, especially those connected with violent crimes, who, after release, commit further murders. In New York in 1976-77, 85 persons arrested for homicide had a previous arrest for murder. I do not believe the population should be subject to that increase in risk.

Of course, many citizens, especially among women and the frail and aged, worry about murderers in gaol escaping. It is a legitimate worry, especially as escape does happen, and all too frequently. Let us not dismiss lightly the fears of those innocent people. There seems to be no shortage of trendies and academics running around today agonising with concern for the rights and comforts of the perpetrators of such crimes. However, I hear none of their ilk expressing such concern for the victims of these crimes, let alone the potential victims. The fear of these criminals escaping and, while on the run, entering the homes of these innocent people is a very real one out there in society.

The death penalty, of course, obviates the need for the expense of keeping these people in gaol. While I think this reason should be accorded a relatively low priority, it should not be overlooked. I understand it costs about $35,000 or $40,000 each year to keep a prisoner in gaol, but it can cost $100,000 or more to keep a high security prisoner in gaol. There are many who would consider that much of this money would be better spent on the welfare of the victim's relatives or even, for that matter, in preserving the lives of some of the millions who are dying from starvation overseas.

Perhaps the most telling argument for capital punishment is that it is a proper punishment for the crime committed. There is a sense of justice about it, not only for the community, which is always appalled at these crimes, but also for the victim's relatives. For the victim, of course, it is all too late. Capital punishment is the only punishment that does not fall short of fulfilling the criterion of bringing a proper retribution. To gaol these criminals satisfies so few. We all know that a life sentence no longer means life. It does not even mean 20 years any more. In practice, the tenacity to lobby for the welfare of the criminals by the bleeding hearts in society usually means that the criminal is out after a decade, or even after five years or less in some cases.

It is of no use saying that the situation can be improved. People have been saying that for years and yet the length of time that criminals stay in gaols gets shorter every year. The community also resents the fact that these prisoners live under such good conditions, with carpet, television, meals, sporting facilities, library and so on, being provided. Such short sentences only cheapen the value of the innocent life that has been taken and this causes resentment. Is that all a life is considered to be worth these days, 10 years, before the murderer or mutilator is let out into society again?

People feel that the justice system is so stacked in favour of the rights of criminals today instead of the rights of the victims that they are now despairing. Capital punishment will help to maintain a respect for the law also, which has been somewhat diminished in recent years. It is interesting to note that those who chant the loudest to abolish capital punishment on the grounds of respect for human life are often the same people who so strongly advocate the right to abortion, which kills the innocent unborn.

Another reason in support of capital punishment is that because of its finality it does not readily invite undesirable follow-on action by supporters of the criminals. This is particularly seen with terrorist acts. If, say, aircraft hijackers are apprehended and gaoled, their sympathisers are often tempted to hijack yet another aircraft and use the unfortunate hostages on this craft to bargain for the release of the first lot of hijackers. We saw this syndrome occur with the Baader-Meinhof gang when it was in action in Germany. Many people in favour of capital punishment say that it acts as a deterrent. While all elements of one's commonsense might tell one that this should be so, it is very hard to demonstrate in practice from the figures available. If all statistics are examined on the murder rates from countries that have either introduced or banned capital punishment, overall no discernible pattern can yet be established in support of the deterrence theory. Though capital punishment may well be a deterrent for some forms of murder the deterrent aspect cannot be used on any scientific basis as an argument in favour of the use of capital punishment overall.

There are, of course, a number of arguments against capital punishment. A prime one is the respect for human life angle with a variance that it degrades civilisation to take a life and that capital punishment is a barbaric practice. I have just argued the opposite, namely, that the proponents claim that life is so precious that anything less than capital punishment for the perpetrators of murder and the like only cheapens life. I guess one argument cancels out the other and we end up supporting the one we inherently believe in.

Some say that it is inhumane to apply capital punishment. No doubt others can argue that it is more inhumane to lock up a person for 20 years. This, of course, is why in practice these people are usually let out early. For some reason it is wrong to subject a criminal-even a murderer-to inhumane treatment. Some say that if the capital punishment exists for murder, a perpetrator of this crime may as well kill others, too, as the sentence cannot be increased. I find this a poor argument. The same can be said about giving 20 years gaol for a single or a multiple murder. Also, a murderer convicted for life has nothing to lose by killing to escape; the arguments cancel each other out.

Much is often made of the fact that an innocent person may be hanged. No doubt, there has been the odd incidence of this happening. However, the argument is grossly overstated; such an occurrence would be extremely rare under our modern-day multi-layer appeal system which is lengthy and painstaking. Besides, the instances of a gaoled murderer escaping and killing an innocent person again would probably outweigh the risk of an innocent person being hanged. The risk is extremely small and is one that society should readily accept. Gaoling an innocent for life would surely be no more pleasant.

It is intended to reintroduce capital punishment only for horrific crimes that are beyond doubt. Everything we do in life has some risk attached to it. We do not ban cars simply because 3,000 die on our roads every year. Others argue that most executed will be poor and, in the United States of America, black. However, most of the victims are poor and black too, as well as dead. Some claim capital punishment is a cruel and unusual treatment and that killing, whether done by the state or an individual is a no-no at all times.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in this grievance debate on a matter which has been concerning me for some time, not only because it affects me personally but also because it affects the people in my electorate and beyond. If there is one thing that tends to bind country people together it is the parlous state of rural roads. They can differ on many other issues but a gradual and seemingly inexorable deterioration of the rural road system becomes a cause celebre for most people in rural communities. Those who live beyond town and city boundaries in my own electorate of Ballarat are no exception.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the most common concerns of the 15 municipalities in my electorate is road funding, with particular reference to unclassified roads; and likewise, farmers also are concerned about road funding. I believe it is a relatively simple task to demonstrate the important function that roads have in economic and social terms. For instance-and this is not an exhaustive list of course-roads carry produce from the farm to the market; they carry tourists to their destination; the roads carry vehicles providing emergency services; roads carry children to schools; roads are a vital part of a modern society.

The National Association of Australian State Road Authorities (NAASRA) in its recent report tells us that road transport related activities employ 500,000 people, or about one in 13 of the Australian work force. It is not difficult to imagine just how important these jobs are to small rural communities. It is not just jobs of the men who operate the heavy machinery or the blokes who hold the `Slow Down' or `Stop' signs. It is not just the road patrol people or the shire engineers. They are the visible ones. It is the jobs of those working extracting gravel and sand. It is the jobs in the local garage where the trucks and machinery are serviced and it is the jobs of the secretaries who work in all the offices servicing the industry et cetera. NASRA says that the road sector has the highest employment generating capacity of all sectors which produce a physical product of economic value.

Mr Deputy Speaker, as well as being an important part of the economy we should be aware that an adequately funded road maintenance and construction industry contributes to road safety. The Federal Government has done an enormous amount to raise awareness of the cost to the community of road accidents. High profile safety campaigns have used the media effectively and imaginatively to emphasise the importance of safety on the roads. It is estimated that there are around 25,000 road crashes in Australia a year; 3,000 people lose their lives and 32,000 are admitted to hospital. Each fatality costs the community about $400,000. This is not a pleasant topic; it is almost macabre to look at death on the roads in terms of dollars and cents when the cost in grief and pain to family and friends is so great. But we just cannot escape the financial cost of road accidents either.

Even the cost of injuries as a result of road accidents has been qualified; it is about $60,000 for each hospitalisation. In total, the cost to the community of road accidents is about $3,000m each year. It requires more than good roads to reduce the incidence of road accidents; we know that. But the condition of the road system is undoubtedly a real factor to be considered. We are all aware that the road system is a vital key to the life of all rural communities. Most people here are familiar with the great improvements that have been made to the highway system. Great credit must go to the Minister for Transport and Communications Support (Mr Peter Morris) for his efforts to improve the system, and he enjoys enormous respect out in the community.

Few people would be aware of the other roads, those referred to as unclassified roads. In Victoria alone there are about 133,000 kilometres of these. Many of these roads are far past their useful lifespan and they need not maintenance but total reconstruction. In Victoria, the most compact State in the Commonwealth, the density of rural traffic is an obvious factor in determining the needs for funds to maintain and upgrade the system.

Spending cuts affect the maintenance of roads, the construction of new roads and the livelihood of people who work on the roads. The significance of the cost of a deteriorating road system to industry is often overlooked. If wear and tear on vehicles is excessive, the costs will be passed on to consumers and this applies whether we are talking about transporting primary produce or a truckload of assorted groceries. About 77 per cent of all goods is moved by road. We all know about the effects of the tyranny of distance in this country. The road system underpins successful commerce in this nation.

Bearing these facts in mind, it is not hard for us to understand the special pressures on those who are charged with the responsibility for maintaining the quality of our roads, let alone improving them. To put the record straight, it is only fair to remind the House that this Government has a commendable record as far as road funding is concerned and as compared with that of our predecessors. But the Labor Government's record, better though it might be than that of the coalition when last in office, has taken a disconcerting direction over the past couple of years.

The wear and tear on roads all over Australia is something we cannot run away from. Deterioration happening now to the road system will need fixing, either now or at some time in the future. I am fully aware of the Government's need to exercise sound standards of fiscal management and to reduce expenditure in this difficult economic period. Organisations such as the National Farmers Federation (NFF) are calling for huge Budget surpluses of at least $2.5m. I have to say that this is cloud-cuckooland stuff, if we are also to meet the costs of essential programs.

One of these programs, even the NFF recognises, is construction and maintenance of the road system. Likewise, my municipalities and all road users feel the same way. Road funding must compete for a place among all items of expenditure. I am not suggesting that the Government is insensitive to the needs of local and State governments for increased support to maintain the road system. The Minister said when introducing changes to the Australian land transport program back in 1986:

Road transport is a fundamental part of the Australian way of life. Well designed and constructed roads make significant contributions to Australia. They reduce costs. They save lives. They encourage all forms of industry and they repay to Australia far more than their cost.

However, I believe that funding for roads must be held at the very least to last year's levels in real terms. I want to stress `in real terms'. In fact, I would like to see it increased because last year's levels were a reduction in real terms on the previous year. The road construction industry, local government and all those involved in maintaining the standards of our roads should not have to survive another round of funding cuts.

There is a particular need for a replacement program for the Australian bicentennial road development project. This was targeted to national highways and arterial roads. What is needed now is a specific program to arrest the deterioration of the unclassified roads around this country. I notice the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) in the chamber and I am sure that he agrees with me wholeheartedly, coming from where he does down in Bookar. Everybody knows where Bookar is.

So many of these roads have long passed their effective lifespan that it will take years of purpose or planning and major expenditure to overcome the backlog of essential works. There is considerable anger about the increases in fuel excise without a proportional increase in the amount allocated to road funding. I think it is important for the Government to recognise this fact. Some lobby groups argue that all taxes raised from road users should be returned to road users through road funding. If one followed this argument with all aspects of government revenue one would end up with a very strange society indeed.

If the Opposition succeeds in levying a consumption tax on bread we will have to ask: Will it be expected to return that to bread eaters exclusively? The mind boggles if we contemplate the implications when it comes to sales tax. Nevertheless, governments over the decades have used the tax on fuels as a means of raising revenue and the community is prepared to accept a proportion of the price it pays if the petrol pump is its way of contributing to the maintenance of the road system.

I believe it is important that the Government make a greater allocation of excise available for road maintenance. There has been a good deal of speculation about the possibility that we will shortly see no more federal road funds as such. The Municipal Association of Victoria has urged all its members to lobby the Government. It believes that the Federal Government wants to hand funds directly to the States and priorities will then be set by the States on a State by State basis for road expenditure. It believes that should this happen there would be no guarantee that levels of road funding would be maintained.

Road funding would have to compete against other programs and could suffer a reduction in its priority ranking. There is nothing more than rumour to base these fears upon but the point is still worth making. To some degree the maintenance of an adequate rural road system is everybody's concern, whether living in the city or the country. I raise this matter today in the hope that the Government will increase road funds and in the expectation that all members share my concerns.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the last 12 months parents of intellectually and physically handicapped persons have approached me in despair as to what might happen to members of their families with the introduction of a program of deinstitutionalisation. Would this mean that care for their sons or daughters would suddenly become their sole responsibility or would they be at the mercy of the inadequate community services? One has only to talk to both parents and clients to understand the trauma that these proposals have brought to their daily lives. This section of the community is severely disadvantaged, through no fault of its own, and governments need to provide support services and a compassionate guiding hand.

SPEECH.PARA: Last September I wrote to the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) expressing grave concern at the proposals to deinstitutionalise the physically and mentally handicapped in Victoria. I sought clarification of the situation, particularly in relation to the two institutions Karingal and Colanda in the Corangamite electorate. Three months later the Minister finally managed to reply:

. . . that with the implementation of the Disabilities Services Act from 5 June 1987, services for people with disabilities which were previously funded under the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act, such as Karingal, would be involved in a five-year transition process to meet the principles and objectives of the new legislation.

The principles and objectives of the Disabilities Services Act, so the Minister tells me, address a range of quality of life issues which focus on positive outcomes for people with disabilities. Parents, patients, administrators and the community at large will have difficulty in understanding exactly what this means. However, the Minister assured me that people with disabilities will not be left without appropriate services. In the present economic restraint, State and Federal governments will have to maximise the use of resources to look after the disabled.

The Victorian Government's admission that it lost $1 billion in the share market crash will not help funds for those disabled in Victoria. There are serious doubts that deinstitutionalisation will offer those with psychiatric difficulties an improved quality of life. Deinstitutionalisation, discharging patients into the community, was introduced into the United States of America 30 years ago. Deinstitutionalisation on a massive scale has been a universal failure. Honourable members may have seen a recent television report which revealed that one in four of the homeless wandering the streets of New York are mentally ill patients who have been released into the community and who cannot cope with the pressures of life and self care. Is this to be the result of deinstitutionalising people in Australia?

Our prisons could become de facto psychiatric hospitals. In spite of the best intentions and the undoubted benefits of integration into the community for some patients, the community at large simply cannot cope with the burden of looking after the physically and mentally handicapped. The services that are needed are too widely dispersed and they are neither sufficiently available nor accessible. To provide adequate services would entail long term training to develop skills. Placing patients suffering from chronic intellectual disability in community residential units would require adequate supervised accommodation; adequate community day centres; designated case managers; coordinated hospital and community services, both adequately staffed and available 24 hours a day and not nine to five; and coordinated administration to control standards.

Institutions are strong, they offer mutual support; services and support groups are readily accessible when needed. All these are necessary in the care of the handicapped. The staff maintain their morale and support one another in a difficult professional environment. In community residential units they can become very isolated and suffer from lack of peer support. Deinstitutionalisation imposes strains on both staff and residents. In some cases clients in community residential units could find themselves more confined and more institutionalised than in the residential unit situation. Take one example: escorts are required when they wish to socialise. They are house-bound until they have assistance. There is a great need to look at the broad spectrum of client needs before deinstitutionalisation is widely embraced. Generic services cannot provide specialisation. In institutions medical experts are constantly on hand.

In the community residential units there are no doctors on hand and clients would be relying on local general practitioners whose general practitioner training courses includes only a matter of hours on mental retardation. Some people are best serviced by specialised services; others certainly can benefit from integration with the community. It is the degree of illness which should govern the final decision. Balance is necessary to provide a place for both services. Above all, the parameters should be what is best for the client. There is a belief that the same principle must apply to everyone, but the intellectually retarded patients are not like everyone else.

Existing institutions should become a resource base with some residents. They could well become the regional centre to provide backup services for those who are in residential community units. Six thousand adults in Victoria have no day places at this moment. The problem would be overwhelming if all those now in institutions were vying for them with places because the institutions had been closed down. There have been some recent cases where quite obviously people have spent a great deal of their time in institutions and have been released into the community, when quite clearly they should still be under constant care.

In my own electorate of Corangamite there was a clear case of a person with schizophrenia undergoing treatment in an institution, where his condition was controlled by the use of drugs. However, under the law he was not restrained from returning to his home environment. Unsupervised, he failed to take his prescribed medication and the problem of violence arose. Family, friends and the police were unable to exercise any legal control over him and he became a danger to the community.

Is deinstitutionalisation a good thing in this environment? Local government does not have the necessary support services to cope with people who have left institutional care. Further difficulties arise with the legal responsibilities of local government officials in handling these people. There is a community concern over legal liabilities, whether or not an insurance policy covers damage caused by people who through no fault of their own have been abandoned by the authorities, who have no hope of providing the necessary care for patients who have been used to getting care in institutions. Because the cost of providing care for the physically and intellectually impaired is skyrocketing, the Victorian Government seems intent on cost cutting by putting patients out into the community.

In the city of Colac first-class institutional care is provided by Colanda. The staff is dedicated and the facilities are modern and located in a pleasant countryside environment. There is a recognition by the local community that Colanda plays an important role in looking after the disadvantaged. In turn, the city of Colac appreciates the contribution Colanda makes to the area. Karingal in Geelong is a fine example of supervised care being provided by a voluntary group. One hundred and thirty adults receive loving care and attention in an attempt to make their lives fulfilling and worth while. Karingal provides educational and recreational programs for its clients on their various establishments, supervised by dedicated staff.

Karingal runs a horticultural farm operation which utilises clients' skills to commercial and personal advantage. It also operates a commercial laundry and workshop. Karingal is a voluntary organisation which receives about two-thirds of its funding from both State and Federal governments and raises the remainder from the community. Karingal is an outstanding example of a caring and understanding approach to looking after those less fortunate members of our community by providing skilled supervision in a modern, diversified institutional environment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Events taking place in the occupied territories of the West Bank and Gaza Strip are causing alarm and dismay in the international community, mainly because of Israeli brutality and intransigence towards the indigenous people, the Palestinians, but also because it is obvious to any reasonably thoughtful person how easily events could escalate and expand to involve us all. The record in the occupied territory since this period of Palestinian resistance began late last year speaks for itself; 191 Palestinians are dead and 6,000 to 8,000 are wounded. Basic human rights are being denied. A minimum of 8,000 people have been arrested with over 700 of these being administratively detained.

SPEECH.PARA: What this means is that they have been imprisoned without charge, trial or review. Imprisonment under these regulations is allowed to continue for six months but it is indefinitely renewable. It is interesting to see that included among these numbers are lawyers, teachers, university lecturers and journalists; that is, the intellectual leaders of the community. This denies Israeli claims that those arrested are stone throwers and so-called terrorists. All schools in the West Bank and Gaza Strip have been closed. This means that over 800 schools have been closed down.

Restrictions have been placed on foreign media and the Israelis closed down the Palestine Press service in East Jerusalem over six months ago. Given this record by the Israelis in the occupied territories, we need to look at what they are hoping to achieve. I believe that an interesting pointer can be found in the death of the young Israeli settler only last week. Misinformation and the rhetoric surrounding this tragic incident all points in the same direction. I believe it is worth while going into some detail about not only the death itself but also the process of disinformation which followed.

As an aside, I found it instructive to see the value placed on this one Israeli life compared with the indifference shown by Israel to the fate of many young Palestinians who have been shot or dragged from their homes and severely beaten. When the death of this girl was first reported we were told that she died as a result of a vicious and unprovoked attack with rocks by Palestinians on a group of young girls innocently hiking. There are further claims by settlers that the Palestinians had tried to slaughter the rest of the group as well.

As a result of these reports immediate retribution began on the Palestinians. The Israeli Army blew up or bulldozed 14 houses of villagers suspected of involvement. Soldiers also shot dead a Palestinian youth who they claimed was running away. Presumably he did not want to have his bones smashed over a 40-minute period as happened to two youths in an incident filmed by the CBS network several weeks ago.

Within a couple of days of the shooting a different version of the event began to leak out. It turned out that the girl had been shot with an M16 rifle bullet, the type of gun carried by the two men guarding the girls. It also turned out, as the Australian reported on Monday, that there was no evidence that villagers had tried to massacre other members of the party. The guard who had killed two villagers and wounded two others was the only other person seriously injured, despite ample opportunity for the villagers to have carried out a massacre.

The incident was described in a New York Times article of 8 April as having been triggered by one of the settler guards unleashing `impulsive bursts of gunfire that killed one Palestinian and wounded another before the group of Israelis reached the village'. After these facts came out about the girl's death, settlers claimed that their reports that a Palestinian had been seen firing a Kalashnikov rifle from a fair distance away were being ignored. However, evidence from the autopsy showed that the shot that killed the girl had been fired from only a few metres away and from an American M16, not a Kalashnikov.

The Israelis have not annexed the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, at least in a formal sense. They refer to them as `occupied territories'. Despite this, settlers strongly believe that the land belongs to them and that the Palestinians have no rights there. One of the girls involved in the incident I have just described was interviewed on television and asked whether she did not think that their visit to the village was provocative, given the current situation. She replied that they were showing the Palestinians whom the land belongs to. This week's Newsweek magazine said, and I quote: `Hiking has become a political statement among Jewish settlers, a way of asserting their ownership of the biblical land'.

I recommend this Newsweek report entitled `A Hike into Tragedy', for those who would like to read a comprehensive report from a publication hardly noted for its radical or anti-Israeli views. One further point about this incident that is worth mentioning, because it shows the unwillingness of Israel to punish settlers who take the law into their own hands, is that the guard who shot the girl, Roman Aldubi, who was apparently the one who led the hikers so close to the village, is an anti-Palestinian fanatic who was involved with a vigilante shooting in Nablus on the West Bank last year. His punishment for that crime was to be banished for six months from the city.

A larger problem is that the attitudes so prevalent amongst the settlers are not surprising. It has been inevitable ever since Israel made the irrevocable decision to proceed with massive settlement of the occupied territories. Many millions of dollars have been poured into the settlement and it is obvious that the settlement was meant to be permanent; in other words, a de facto annexation. A great deal of this settlement was paid for by the United States.

Israel forms the core of the United States strategic defence plans in the Middle East. Because of this, the United States has been prepared to massively bankroll Israel, with both civil and military aid. With the help of the United States, Israel has become the fourth largest military power in the world with an undoubted though unadmitted nuclear capacity. I do not suppose that the United States desires this money to be used to hegemonise the Palestinians but there are many things that the United States is prepared to tolerate, so long as it achieves what it sees as its strategic interests. Given that Israel intended from the start that its settlement of the Occupied Territories be permanent, one has to wonder what its future intentions have been for the indigenous Palestinians. There is little doubt that an influential group of Liberal politicians ultimately envisages the forced removal of the Palestinians from these areas.

Immediately after the first reports of the incident, the Israeli Justice Minister called for the demolition of dozens of Arab homes and the expulsion of hundreds of Palestinians. Right-wing religious leaders and politicians, including Ariel Sharon, called for the village of Beita to be wiped from the face of the earth. We are seeing the engineering of a climate where an anti-Palestinian program of horrific dimensions is a real possibility; we are seeing the emergence of frightening racist attitudes, clearly manifested in the different value attached to Israel and Palestinian life.
I mentioned earlier the large number of Palestinians killed and injured in prisons, but up to now there have been no civilian Israelis--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 1.45 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106 as amended for this session, the debate is interrupted. I put the question:

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Mr M. Mansell-National Flag-Nursing Homes-Education Funding: Queensland-Family Allowance Supplement-Tax Deductability for Donations-Australian Security Intelligence Organisation-Road Funding-Register of Members' Interests

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I am firmly against Michael Mansell going to Libya. I just cannot understand why the Government does not stop his passport; secondly, that phoney Aboriginal passport of his should be burnt and thrown away; and, thirdly, we should do everything in our power to let the people of Australia know what he is all about. He is a publicist; he does not have the support of the Tasmanian Aboriginal people, he does not have the support of the Aboriginal people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: All he is doing is going to a bloody butcher to try to get blood money to try to help the Aboriginals of Australia. What he is going to do is divide the people of Australia. All of a sudden in Hobart there is a resentment against the Aboriginals, there is a resentment caused by this fellow going over there. Let me quote from world news:
Libya. Gaddafi has reduced Libya to a refuge of crime, corruption, bankruptcy and destruction.

All of a sudden we see this group trying to go there, trying to help the Australian Aboriginals, and I repeat that they are doing more harm than good. I also note that now the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) is thinking of sending a crew over there to cover this newsworthy item. Let me tell the ABC that it has a bit of support for trying to get additional funding to keep its good programs going, but if it is going to send a crew over there to follow this phoney, I am more of a Tasmanian Aboriginal than he is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to reply to a letter received from the Australian National Flag Association of Queensland. It wrote to me, amongst all members of the House, to suggest that there should be no change to the Australian national flag. I do not disagree; I think that is fine. What I want to draw attention to is the fact that it seeks, if there were to be a referendum held on the matter, that the form of the question to be given in the referendum should be as follows: `Do you see any reason for changing in any way your present Australian national flag?'. What I object to is the biased manner in which that question is phrased.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a question which begs the answer, and as we know in any referendum, you cannot ask such a biased or begging question. It must always be in a neutral tone. So I have replied to the Australian National Flag Association of Queensland, making it quite clear that I am not against its move to have the current flag remain the Australian flag. That is not the issue, but if it wishes to enter into a debate about referendums and how referendums are to be used, then, please, it must ensure that questions are neutral and do not in fact beg the answer. I have written to the Association in those terms. I thank the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to call upon the Government to establish an independent committee of inquiry to examine and report on, firstly, the level of nursing and other care necessary to enable nursing homes to meet the outcome standards which the Government by legislation now obliges them to achieve; secondly, the appropriateness of these outcome standards to provide nursing home patients with an acceptable standard of living; thirdly, the suitability of the narrow medical approach of the formula contained in the resident classification instrument to determine the minimum level of nursing care at which the outcome standards or other appropriate standards can be achieved; fourthly, the level of non-nursing care required in relation to various levels of nursing care if these outcome standards or other more appropriate standards are to be achieved; and, fifthly, the funding necessary to meet the cost of employing staff engaged to provide nursing and non-nursing care to a level which enables nursing homes to achieve these outcome standards or other appropriate standards.

SPEECH.PARA: I am advocating this, Mr Deputy Speaker, because there is a crisis of care facing those who operate nursing homes. There is a crisis of care facing nursing home patients. These crises have been caused by a government which is out of touch with the needs of the average Australian. These crises have been caused by a government which has become totally insensitive to the needs of the most frail in our community. I am amazed that the Government should now be cutting back on the funding available to nursing homes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the House's attention to the committee of inquiry which has been established by some members of the Queensland Government supposedly investigating federal funding into further education in Queensland. In fact, the Queensland Government itself has failed to address the whole issue of higher education in relation to technical and further education and has turned down $1 1/2m for TAFE in the nurses education area. This group now goes around blaming this particular Federal Government for not providing funding for further education in Queensland. It seems to me that very little of the real truth is being told.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

Phrases like `Getting back to grass roots' have been uttered, loudly and often. In reality that will mean spending more and already we are seeing some amazing examples of the waste of taxpayers' money. SPEECH.PARA: The irony is that many of these families are not even eligible for the allowance. With some mirth and with a grain of truth one of the local newspapers is my electorate, the Collie Mail, described the fiasco as a taxing experience. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to discuss further the question raised by the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) about Michael Mansell. In many respects he is quite correct in his comments. Perhaps he was a little too exuberant; nevertheless he was correct. One of the problems Mansell will create or may well create is to turn the tide of opinion amongst the general populace against the Aboriginal people and he would greatly disserve his own people by carrying on in the manner in which he has. I have had cause to write recently to constituents who are worried about the acts of Michael Mansell.

SPEECH.PARA: As a government, of course, we do not support any of his actions; in fact we took away his support by the Aboriginal Legal Service in Tasmania, I think last year. So there is no way in which we give any support to Mansell. Should he head off to Libya or places further, then he will not retain any support from the Australian public and in fact, as I say, at a crucial time when resources are short, perhaps he will turn the tide of opinion against Aboriginal people. I guess since 1972 all Federal governments-I mean all governments-have served Aboriginal people in this country extremely well and I hope that Mansell's actions do not bring into disrepute those good acts of government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Recently in this House I drew attention to reports that the Hawke Government is considering the abolition of tax deductability for donations to charitable and other community organisations. This concern arises in part from the decision of the New Zealand Government to abolish such deductability from 1 April last. The tax deductability of donations to recognised organisations is a well established practice which encourages voluntary and private sector support for those organisations. It is not in particular to be thought of as a benefit only to the rich who are able to make large gifts. As World Vision of Australia pointed out in a recent Press release, about 60,000 ordinary middle and low income Australians who sponsor a World Vision child in a poor developing country overseas for $288 a year benefit from the deduction. From the organisation's point of view, abolition of tax deductability would make it much more difficult and costly for it to raise funds and undoubtedly curtail such private initiative in assisting the poor and needy. I would again urge the Government to think long and carefully before it should seek to follow the New Zealand example in this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.
