TALK.START.PARA: —Roads carry 77 per cent of our freight, and are used for 83 per cent of our domestic tourism journeys and 97 per cent of passenger trips. Road travel is expected to grow by 35 per cent between 1990 and the end of the century. Revenue from fuel excise has increased by about 200 per cent in real terms since the Australian bicentennial road development program was introduced. Federal road funds have remained at the same level in money terms for the last four years. It will not be long, Madam Speaker, before rural local governments will be tearing up sealed roads and converting them back to gravel roads.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to advise the chamber that I intend to amend the Register of Members' Interests in that I wish to list a range of shareholdings I hold with 16 million other Australians. Of course, I refer to those government-owned enterprises which are held and owned by every citizen of Australia, every taxpayer, and for very good reasons I believe that these government enterprises should not be sold off in part or in total unless we have a general meeting. What better time than that is a general election, and if there is anything that distinguishes the Opposition most from ourselves over here, it is our attitude to these public enterprises and government instrumentalities.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, to make it very short, the Opposition believes in the user pays argument, where regardless of your income and your standing in society, you pay for whatever you get; there is no such thing as a social wage. On this side we believe utterly in social justice; that is, that these public enterprises provide a service which cannot be purchased purely with money. I intend to advice the Registrar of my shareholding interests, as I said, that I share with 16 million or more other Australians, so that we retain proper competition where there are two major competitors only such as the airlines, where we can set social goals, such as affirmative action and interest rates.

—I just repeat that I am not too exuberant about Michael Mansell. His passport should be stopped. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) should dissociate himself from Mansell. He is going to a country that trains terrorists, he is going to introduce them back into Australia. Gadaffi is a brutal murderer and we should stop Mansell trying to say that he is going to help the Aboriginals. He is driving them apart from us and we should stop him, and I challenge the Minister to stop his passport and to cut out that stupid Aboriginal passport that he is leaving Australia with.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FITZGERALD COMMITTEE TO ADVISE ON AUSTRALIA'S IMMIGRATION POLICIES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that at a meeting in his office last Wednesday or Thursday, attended by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and two members of either his Department or his office, he instructed the Minister to ensure that certain recommendations in the FitzGerald report, which were critical of the Government's immigration policy, be changed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me at the outset condemn on this issue the Leader of the Opposition, as he should be condemned, who once again has picked up a rumour and made an assertion which is absolutely false. He issued a Press release yesterday. I had expected that I might get a question from him, but I guess that is expecting too much. In his Press release he said:

ANSWER.PARA: Reports that the Prime Minister has personally tampered with certain recommendations contained in the FitzGerald Committee review . . .

Let me make it quite clear that that allegation-as is the insinuation in this question-is absolutely false. The position is that Dr FitzGerald, who is currently overseas, has indicated that he will be in a position to provide a final report to the Government within two weeks of his return.

The Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs, like many other government and non-government organisations, was consulted on aspects of the Committee's work, by the secretariat of the Committee. As did other departments, the office made some suggestions to the Committee in relation to a working draft of the report-I emphasise a working draft-which I have not read.

I would not seek to change any recommend- ations, for the simple reason that when a government commissions inquiries there is no undertaking on the part of government that it will accept the recommendations. This Government, when it receives the final report, will conscientiously consider it and its recommendations and if there are recommendations in the report with which we agree and upon which we decide positive action should be taken we will take it. If recommendations come from this Committee with which we do not agree, we will not act on them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the honourable member for Port Adelaide.

—Madam Speaker, thank you for the opportunity to ask my first question in the national Parliament as the member for Port Adelaide. My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. In view of reports that the Government could move the submarine project from South Australia, will the Minister advise the House of the precise situation regarding this contract? What prospects are there of the project proceeding according to schedule?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Port Adelaide for his maiden question and wish him a long and successful career in this House. I know that he is very interested in the submarine project, which is a major economic boost to Adelaide and to Port Adelaide in particular. Unfortunately, some substantial industrial relations problems are being experienced in relation to this project.

ANSWER.PARA: To explain that I will say at the outset that, contrary to Opposition statements, there have been no work stoppages at this stage on this site. The project is in the construction phase and the assembly phase is some 18 months away. The construction work is continuing. It is slightly behind schedule because of a delay in the letting of some contracts. The delay was due to concern about getting finalisation of the site agreement before further contracts were let. Those contracts have now been let and the site agreement should be finalised very shortly.

The real problem relates to the assembly phase. The Australian Submarine Corporation (ASC), which is the consortium constructing the submarines, made it clear from the outset that it would want to have a restricted union agreement for the assembly phase, as already exists in some shipbuilding yards in this country. At Australian Shipbuilding Industries (WA) Pty Ltd in Fremantle there is a one-union agreement in the most efficient shipbuilding yard in the country and at Carrington Slipways Pty Ltd in New South Wales there is a three-union agreement. So ASC is not asking for something which is unprecedented. It is already in operation in two major shipyards in this country.

The concern of the Corporation not to have a multiplicity of unions is understandable because that brings inefficiencies, as we have seen at the Williamstown Dockyard where 23 unions have been on site and where inefficiency has been notorious. That comes about through demarcation disputes, an inflexible work force and, most importantly, the prevention of adopting more efficient restructured awards.

Last December, the Australian Submarine Corporation reached agreement with three federal unions for a three-union agreement-with the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union, the Electrical Trades Union of Australia, the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia and the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). The South Australian unions and the United Trades and Labour Council in South Australia were not involved in that agreement. Since that time, they have refused to accept the three-union agreement.

Last Monday they met and agreed to impose bans on new contracts for construction unless the three-union agreement was torn up. All unions that would normally have been members on such a project were able to do so. Yesterday, I went to South Australia to meet the South Australian unions and the United Trades and Labour Council to explain to them the Government's position in relation to this matter. I made it very clear that the Government supports the restricted union agreement. I said we supported the decision of ASC to seek such an agreement and the view of the ACTU that that was an appropriate way for such a project to go.

I made it clear that if we cannot get that agreement as part of an overall efficient operation there are other options for the Government. Those options are difficult and unpleasant, but they are there. The Australian Submarine Corporation has a right under the contract to seek to have the first submarine built totally in Sweden if there is significant delay in the project-instead of most of it being built in Australia-and the Government has the option of taking the whole project to some other part of Australia where a more efficient operation would be possible through restricted union agreements. I instance the two yards I have already mentioned.

What came out of that meeting was that it was agreed that the bans on new contracts for construction work would not apply, provided that there was conclusion of the site agreement which we expect to happen quite shortly and that a discussion process would take place between the Australian Submarine Corporation and all of the interested unions to explain to them what is involved in submarine assembly and module construction on and off the assembly site and what would happen in relation to employment for their members, much of which would occur for most of the interested unions off the site. The Corporation will also explain to the unions the importance of having a restricted union concept.

I am hopeful that this process will demonstrate to many of the unions that their members would be unlikely to be involved in the assembly phase anyway in quite a few cases, that they will get substantial work for their members off site in module construction in South Australia and in other States and that the restricted union agreement is a sensible and necessary way for the project to go.

I make it clear that, although at the level of the ACTU and significant Federal unions, there is a full understanding of the need to restructure the Australian economy and the implications of that for union activities, including restricted union agreements, that knowledge needs to seep down to lower levels of the union movement at a faster pace than has occurred hitherto. Yesterday's meeting would have helped in that process. I am sure that the discussion with the ASC over the next month or so certainly will assist in that process. I am confident that we will see more sensible views coming from the South Australian unions in the future because of that process. However--

TALK.START.PARA: —If honourable members of the Opposition are not interested in a major project like this, I can understand that. They have no interest in shipbuilding in Australia. When the Fraser Government was in office it built two ships on a cost-plus basis--
—Order! Honourable members on my left will come to order.

—Madam Speaker, I understand the Opposition's disinterest in this matter. In conclusion, I say that the unions have to understand that if they cannot get to a position where they fully understand the importance of restrictive union agreements in relation to the submarine project in South Australia, the other options I have mentioned will have to be exercised by the Government. That would be a tragedy for South Australia. We do not want that to happen, but it must remain a real possibility unless union attitudes in that State change considerably.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FITZGERALD COMMITTEE TO ADVISE ON AUSTRALIA'S IMMIGRATION POLICIES

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer him to the answer he gave to the honourable member for Mitchell. I note that in that answer he denied having seen a copy of the original report of the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies. Is it a fact that the Prime Minister has received a detailed briefing on the contents of that report? Has he been told that the original report strongly condemned the thrust and delivery of the Government's immigration policy? Has he been told that on page 1 of that report the Government's policy was described as `a failure'? I ask whether the report also said:

QUESTION.PARA: The current selection procedures are ineffective in controlling numbers. They are not seeking enough skilled and entrepreneurial migrants and they are widely considered inequitable.
In the light of this, does the Prime Minister still adhere to the answer he gave to the first question and to journalists outside the house today? If so, on what basis?

TALK.START.PARA: —I repeat: I have not read the report. I have received a briefing on the report.

—That is a matter that causes the machine to wind up-`Oh, the Prime Minister says he has received a briefing on the report'. I have received a briefing on the report. I assure the Leader of the Opposition that I am not going to tell him what goes on in conversations in my office, with one possible qualification: I may be prepared to do a deal with the Leader of the Opposition. If he will share with me the details of the conversations that go on in his office, when he tries to gag the honourable member for O'Connor and when he tries to ram down the throats of his colleagues his latest position on consumption tax, and if he is prepared to share with me the details of what must be extremely colourful conversations in his office-not as colourful, of course, as the conversations that the President of his Party has about him-I may give consideration to sharing with him the conversations in my office. I repeat, however, on the substance of this question, that I have received a brief on this matter. There would be no attempt on my part as a result of that briefing or on any other ground to change or try to determine the nature of the recommendations that are made by this Committee. The Committee can make any recommendations it likes. I hope that on the basis of any range of recommendations it makes there will be in this community sensible, rational, non-emotional discussion about this fundamentally important issue. I still cherish the vague hope that in that rational discussion within the community on this issue even the Opposition will play a part.

—I address my question to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister advise the House of the revenue being collected by the Government's fringe benefits tax (FBT) and substantiation rules, capital gains tax and the removal of tax deductability for entertainment expenses?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Maribyrnong for his question and inform him that the fringe benefits tax and substantiation rules collect $940m, and the capital gains tax collects at least $80m. That is a total, as the honourable member will appreciate, of more than $1 billion. It is very interesting that the shadow Treasurer, when he was prepared to speak on the subject in March at the Victorian branch of the Liberal Party Conference said that the FBT and the capital gains tax are small beer in the total revenue picture. The shadow Treasurer, when he was speaking on this issue, said that a billion dollars is small beer.

ANSWER.PARA: I also inform the honourable member for Maribyrnong that the end of the free lunches brings in another $330m, which takes the total to at least $1,350m. The only thing we know for certain about the Opposition's policy, as the honourable member will appreciate, is that it would remove these taxes on the privileged which this Government has brought in. They would also remove the assets test, at an additional cost of $350m, as I think the honourable member would appreciate. Madam Speaker, I remind you, the House and the honourable member who asked the question that that alone leaves a revenue hole of $1,700m before the Opposition parties even start to look at personal tax cuts.

It is in those circumstances that at least one thing can be said in favour of the first of the three Johns, John Elliott, the President of the Liberal Party. John Elliott has the honesty to acknowledge that the only way of filling the revenue gap to which I have alluded, if those taxes are abolished and the assets test is removed, is with a consumption tax. But, of course, the second John, John Howard, the Leader of the Liberal Party, has not got this degree of honesty. I suggest, particularly to the honourable member for Maribyrnong, that we should remember the clear position of this gentleman in 1985 on the question of the consumption tax. I remind the honourable member and members of this House what the Leader of the Opposition said on 20 March 1985. These words are very important. No doubt the words of this John are in the ears and the mind of the other John, John Elliott. What the Leader of the Opposition had to say on 20 March 1985 was:
If we really want to reform the Australian taxation system, if we really want to take the load off those marginal rates of personal taxation, we have to bring in a broad-based consumption tax.
Those were his words. But that was not enough. He said:
Furthermore, that broad-based consumption tax has to operate with minimal and desirably no exemptions.
Unless we do that, we will not have enough money to bring about a major reduction in personal income tax.
That was in 1985. Two years later, in 1987, the same John, John Howard, had this to say:
There will be no consumption tax. All Australians are fed up with new taxes and there won't be any under the Liberals.

So a different section of his back bench applauds that statement. But the Federal President of the Liberal Party does not. We know what the position of John Elliott is. We know what the position lately of John Howard is. If honourable members want to know the position of the third John, John Stone, the shadow Minister for Finance, on the consumption tax, he said that it would be so crazy that no sensible person would be part of it. It would be both bad financial policy and bad politics.
In conclusion, the important thing to note is that John Elliott has said, in regard to the Federal Leader of the Liberal Party:
They have to make up their minds. They have got to get their act together. They have got to bring in their policies.

The situation is, we have been told, that the Liberals will finalise all their policies, including tax, by August of this year. Madam Speaker, both you and, I am sure, the honourable member will recall the Leader of the Opposition undertaking that he would not put his name to any policy that would not add up. He said that he would not suspend the laws of arithmetic. I guess we are all waiting now with bated breath for August to see the tax policy of the Opposition. All we can be sure of then, however, is that it will not add up; it will not be a principled position. The only thing we can be sure of is that it will take away the taxes on the privileged brought in by Labor. It will restore the privileges and the rorts to the privileged of this country. In one way or another, most probably by a consumption tax, it will seek to impose a further burden on the ordinary people of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. I remind him that on 27 October I asked him a question concerning the net borrowing of public financial enterprises. The Treasurer promised to `furnish a reply'. After five months I am still waiting. I note that data released yesterday by the Victorian State Auditor-General put the losses at $918m in the wake of the October share market collapse for Victorian State Government enterprises, which include several public financial enterprises. I ask the Treasurer again: Why have some financial enterprises, including State Government insurance offices, been permitted to become substantial net borrowers in recent years? Moreover, what are the measures referred to on page 418 of the Budget Papers that are being taken by State governments to reduce the net borrowings of the respective insurance offices in order to place these organisations on a sound financial basis?

—It should come as no surprise to any member of the House that any superannuation fund or insurance office with financial assets, particularly if they reflect assets in the equity market, will have changed in value between the middle of last year and now as a result of the October share market crash. Companies record, as I am sure financial institutions do, paper losses or gains on the stock which they hold. But that said, the fact is that these funds are held in trust. Even though the body concerned may be a State government body, the funds are held in trust and are not available for State expenditure. That is, they are not part of the whole recurrent government expenditure business of, in this case, the State of Victoria. Therefore, I do not find that remarkable at all.
—You are happy to lose a billion dollars.
—Well, a lot of private companies have lost that. And the fact is that--
—No more pig shooting then.

—There is the idiot son of the Establishment piping up again. The fact of the matter is that I will furnish the honourable gentleman with a reply to his question. That work is in progress. As soon as I can give him one I will.

—Is the Minister for Social Security aware of claims by the Opposition that the Hawke Government's commitment to ending child poverty by 1990 cannot be achieved? What progress is the Government making on achieving its objectives? Will the Hawke Government achieve its objectives?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the statements by the honourable member for Bradfield in the Melbourne Herald on Monday. He was quoted as saying, `I don't think you will ever eliminate poverty'. I am certain that the 1,765 low income working families receiving a family allowance supplement from the Townsville offices of my Department would never believe the honourable member for Bradfield and would support the honourable member for Herbert and the Government because of what the Government is doing. The statement of the honourable member for Bradfield highlights the usual misguided view of those on his side of politics in this country that to ensure a fair deal for every resident of Australia is just too hard, the politics are too tough, the work involved is too much and the vested interests are too strong, particularly at the top end of town.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us look at the history of poverty in Australia in recent years. In 1976, before the Howard-Fraser Government had commenced hacking into the living standards of the poor, there were 372,000 children of pensioners or beneficiaries. Payments for each child were 15 per cent of the married rate of the pension. Over the seven years of conservative rule that number grew every year by 50,000 children. It grew by that number every year from 1976 to 1982. When the Howard-Fraser Government destroyed the labour market in 1982-83 a massive 150,000 children were added. Therefore, over the seven years of the Howard-Fraser period in office, 410,000 children had their parents forced into dependency on pension benefits. I repeat: 410,000 children. Honourable members opposite are the people who talk about incentive. They are the priorities of honourable members on that side of the House. In 1977 payments for children were 15.2 per cent of the married pension rate. In 1983 this figure had fallen to 11.1 per cent of the married rate pension. Over that period the real value of that married rate pension itself had also fallen.

Let us look at this Government's record in comparison. In 1983 we inherited a situation of 266,910 children dependent on families in which there were no adults employed. We have reduced that number. In January this year there were 204,941 children in such families. We have cut the number of children in unemployment beneficiary families by 60,000 during our period in government. We have cut the number of children in pensioner and beneficiary families overall. We have done that not because the Prime Minister made a commitment last year. Let me make that very clear. In the period we have been in government we have moved from 11.1 per cent of the married rate pension which we inherited to 12 per cent in 1984, 12.6 per cent in 1985, 13 per cent in 1986, and last year 14.1 per cent for younger children and 17.2 per cent for the children aged 13, 14 and 15 years. Our commitment was clear. It was stated in the policy speech last year that we would lift those levels to 15 per cent of the married rate pension for children under 13 years and 20 per cent for older children.

TALK.START.PARA: —`There will be no children in poverty by 1990'.
—Order!
—For the first time in the history of the Commonwealth a child payment was being based on a standard of adequacy--
—Order! The Minister will cease for a moment. The honourable member for Bradfield will not interject again. I call the Minister.
—The Minister had better tell the truth.
—Order! The honourable member has been warned.

—For the first time in the history of the Commonwealth there had been established a standard of adequacy in relation to child payment based on research on equivalent scales carried out in the Department and other research centres. For the first time in the history of any child payment made by the Commonwealth, that payment effectively was committed to indexation.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, there will be discussion about the extent of the Government's achievements and what can be done. Helen Brownlee of the Institute of Family Studies concluded that the achievement of the benchmarks will now mean a reduction in child poverty of more than 75 per cent in working families and more than 30 per cent in non-working families. If this were all that was achieved, it would be a magnificent achievement, given the massive build-up in child poverty that occurred as a result of high unemployment and marriage breakdown in the late 1970s and early 1980s.

However, of course, that is not the end of the Government's commitments specifically promised. There is also the child support scheme, which has the potential to assist hundreds of thousands of children in sole-parent families. Four hundred thousand of the 800,000 children of pensioners and beneficiaries are in sole-parent families. We are introducing that scheme to put an end to the gross inequities within families, between custodial and non-custodial parents following separation. The child support scheme will secure to custodial parents regular and timely income support. Of course, we recognise that along with those income transfer policies, which are highly equitable and progressive, there is more that needs to be done. The Government has given fundamental importance to the question of employment. It has introduced a number of social wage measures which affect the distribution of real income within the community. The Government recognises that in terms of meeting its commitment, it must act not only in relation to direct income transfers but also in relation to social wage.

In conclusion I point out that a few moments ago the Prime Minister spoke about the $1.3 billion in relation to some tax measures introduced by the Government. The Opposition would throw out all those measures, thus undercutting its capacity to produce the kind of equity and social justice which has been the hallmark of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following the previous answer of the Minister for Industrial Relations, I ask him to give me a clear answer to a straight question. Will the Government approve a settlement of the current submarine dispute if that settlement involves the participation of more than the three unions currently agreed to?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make it quite clear that the parties involved directly in this matter do not include the Government. They are the Australian Submarine Corporation, those unions involved in the three-union agreement and others who think they should be involved. Of course, as the purchaser of the submarines, the Government is extremely interested in this matter, but we are not a direct party. Thus, the decision on the number of unions involved in any restricted union agreement will be a matter for the parties directly concerned.
—What were you talking about before?
—Order! The honourable member for Deakin will cease interjecting. I will not speak to him again.

—It will also be a matter for the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission which will be involved. I made it quite clear at the meeting yesterday that we strongly support the concept of restricted union agreements; that the numbers that apply in other shipyards where restricted union agreements are in place are small-one in one case and three in another-and that therefore, we would be supportive of that kind of concept.

ANSWER.PARA: However, as a result of the process of discussion which will take place over the course of the next month or so, it may be that there will be a desire on the part of the parties to make some change. I do not know; that is something that will come out of that discussion. I must say that I would not expect there to be much change, otherwise the concept of a restricted union agreement would be considerably watered down. In the final analysis that is a matter for the parties. We strongly support the concept and I hope very much that in a short time an agreed restricted union process for the submarine assembly phase can be put in place and endorsed by the Arbitration Commission. I hope this will provide a smooth basis for this project to proceed from here on.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Community Services and Health to claims made by the honourable member for O'Connor in a Press release dated 8 April 1988 that there was:

QUESTION.PARA: a massive Medicare budgetary blow out of $882m in figures released by the Department of Finance for the eight months to the end of February.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Madam Speaker. This question is definitely out of order.
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. The Chair has not even heard the question yet!
—Can the Minister inform the House as to whether Medicare is on budget this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course the statement made by the honourable member for O'Connor was simply another of his extravagances.
—What about Walsh then? Is he a liar?
—The honourable member for O'Connor would do well to keep quiet.
—I rise on a point of order, Madam Speaker. There is a responsibility on Ministers in this place to tell the truth. The figures were published.

—The honourable member will resume his seat or I will name him. The honourable member for O'Connor has no more right to grab the microphone and launch into speech than anyone else in the House. The Minister has the call.

—When discussing the truth in these matters, the allegation was made by the honourable member for O'Connor that the Medicare budget had blown out by some $800m. To the end of March Medicare medical benefits expenditure was slightly under budget-some $20m under budget. This, of course, follows the trend set last financial year when Medicare benefits again ended up slightly under budget. Indeed, one of the most encouraging features is that the rate of growth per capita in medical benefits expenditure has been slowing down under Medicare in the last two years. The facts show quite clearly that there is no blow out under Medicare and that the claims made by the honourable member for O'Connor are simply an extravagance.

ANSWER.PARA: We can understand this and we can help him with the paper that he has before him by pointing out that the error occurred because he simply failed to comprehend the document that the Minister for Finance put out. If the honourable member reads that document he will note that the Finance Minister pointed out that there had been an advance payment on the Medicare benefits and that is simply an accounting explanation for the sorts of figures that he is producing. Indeed, the honourable member for O'Connor needs to try to understand the statement put out by the Finance Minister. But of course this extravagance is typical of the honourable member. For instance, yesterday he claimed that one could rip $3 billion off the States and the States would not suffer in any way. Yesterday or the day before he made claims that one could have risk rated insurance and get rid of community rating and it would not hurt families with young children or those in which the wives are in the child bearing years. He also claimed it would not hurt sick or elderly people. Those claims are just not believable. The honourable member has even suggested that under this scheme everyone would be eligible for attention in private hospitals. It is about time that he looked at the cost of that. either to individuals or to the Government. Does he simply intend to bankrupt the Government to enable everyone to be eligible for attention in private hospitals?

How does he intend to pay for all these extravagances? When I read the Bulletin yesterday I discovered one of the ways in which he intends to pay for such extravagances. Talking about making private health insurance compulsory he said:
I wouldn't throw you in jail or prosecute you . . .
At least the rest of the community can feel satisfied and I suppose they should be thankful for small mercies.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should be thankful it is only a $500 fine for what you did.
—Order! I give the honourable member for O'Connor a fair go in this House. He has been warned. He has again interjected. I am going to name him without warning in future.
—He said:

ANSWER.PARA: I wouldn't throw you in jail or prosecute you, but I would penalise you through the tax system if you didn't have private cover. It could be $1, or it might be $1,000.
So low and ordinary income families in this country know that if this Opposition ever came to power there would be tax fines imposed on them for not contributing to private insurance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to the Approved Defence Projects Protection Act 1947, introduced by the Chifley Government, which makes any boycott or threat of boycott of an approved defence project an offence. Given that the current industrial action on the submarine project is an offence under this Act, will the Government use the provisions of this important legislation to ensure that work on the submarine project continues unhindered?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the honourable member for Mayo needs to understand a lot more about industrial relations if he is going to make any contribution on the matter in this House. The Opposition, and the honourable member for Mayo in his question, clearly think that by waving big sticks one can always achieve one's objective. The use of that kind of approach may have some justification in particular circumstances. What we are looking at here, however, is a need for work to be carried out in a satisfactory and efficient way on a project which is to run for a decade and a half or perhaps two decades. We do not want to bludgeon people back to work in the present circumstances and then expect them to operate in efficient ways. We do not want them to operate in a way that would restrict the possibilities of an efficient outcome from this project.

ANSWER.PARA: We are looking here at the initial stages of what will undoubtedly become a wider concept. As a nation, we will reduce the number of unions in existence and in particular enterprises. That is part of the restructuring of this country which the trade union movement as a whole accepts. This was part of the Australia Reconstructed concept which was endorsed by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) at its congress last year. Of course, putting this concept in place is a much more difficult process than simply adopting it. We are looking here at the initial stages of doing that. I do not think it helps particularly to say, `We will force you back by some kind of approach', particularly when we do not have in the present circumstances bans which are stopping the work from proceeding. The work is proceeding.

We are looking at getting a satisfactory basis for the assembly phase, which is a year and a half away. We believe that we can get such a satisfactory basis. We have made it clear that if we cannot get it in South Australia we will get it somewhere else, because it already exists somewhere else. I believe that this basis exists in places such as the Williamstown Dockyard, which during the period of the Fraser Government continued in operation with 23 unions. No attempt was made by the then Government to achieve restricted union agreements. No attempt was made by it to make the Williamstown Dockyard, or any other dockyard for that matter, more efficient. No attempt was made by it to bring about a shipbuilding program in this nation. That Government simply bought everything off the shelf from overseas or ordered things from overseas. It had no desire to have an efficient shipbuilding industry in this country.

This Government is facing up to that need for an efficient shipbuilding industry. We have something like $15 billion worth of naval shipping requirements for Australia lined up in the frigate program and the submarine program. This is a massive influx into the economy of funds and jobs. We are determined that those programs are going to be effective. We will undertake this task in the way that we believe likely to be most successful. I believe that the course we are embarking on is quite clearly likely to be the most successful. The big stick approach of the Opposition, in which it thinks it can simply bludgeon people back to work and then have them work efficiently and co-operatively, is quite absurd.

We believe that the course we have embarked upon here is the right course. It has the support of the ACTU; it has the support of the major Federal unions. We have a problem in South Australia. I believe that that problem can be overcome. If it cannot, the project then can be taken to other parts of Australia where more commonsense approaches will apply.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy advise the House of the scope of Commonwealth assistance for primary producers affected by drought in central and northern Queensland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge the honourable member's representations and close interest on behalf of drought affected producers in his electorate. I listened with interest to the points he made in the Parliament last night. We are in the ironic situation of currently providing both flood and drought assistance in Queensland. This may come as news to National Party representatives because they have been running round the country claiming that there is no Federal assistance for drought affected producers. I do not mind if the Leader of the National Party wants to go to the electorate of the honourable member for Hinkler, as he did recently, and misrepresent the facts. By doing that, he only erodes his own credibility further, if that is possible. Of course, he did not have his farmhand with him in Eidsvold-the bloke who managed to put out a Press release in Canberra from Bendemeer without his boss's knowledge-so I suppose it is no wonder he got it wrong.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us look at the facts. The facts are that the Commonwealth jointly funds drought assistance with the States under the natural disaster relief arrangements on a permanent basis, on an agreed formula basis with the States. It is the States that have the responsibility of declaring a disaster area, whether that area be a shire, a part shire, a pasture protection board district or even at the farm level in the case of South Australia. I set up a national drought consultative committee early in the life of my occupancy of this position. The National Farmers Federation and all the States were represented on this committee. We have an agreed method of dealing with droughts.

For expenditures on all natural disasters within a year, above a certain trigger point-that point is $14m in the case of Queensland, according to the formula-the Commonwealth provides matching funding. Beyond the second trigger point-$24.5m in the case of the honourable member's State of Queensland-the Commonwealth provides $3 for every State dollar. This second trigger point has been passed and the Commonwealth is now funding 75 per cent of drought and flood assistance in Queensland. So, like the honourable member, I simply hope that we do not hear any more of this nonsense from the National Party in Queensland, including the Minister in that State, as well as the Leader of the National Party in this House.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MR MICHAEL MANSELL: PROPOSED VISIT TO LIBYA

TALK.START.PARA: —In the spirit of consensus and cooperation which is one of my hallmarks, I ask: Is the Prime Minister aware that Libya is a training ground for terrorists led by a despotic butcher-with great respect for the ladies present, a bloody butcher? First, will the Prime Minister stop the passport of Michael Mansell? Secondly, will he outlaw the so-called Aboriginal passport? Thirdly, will he stop the funding to Michael Mansell? Fourthly, will he stop a proposed Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) television crew, either black or white, covering the event if Mansell should ever go to Libya?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Franklin for his question. Reciprocating the spirit of consensus that led to his question, I say to him that I understand his concern about the person to whom he referred. I share that concern and, broadly, his assessment of the regime in the country to which he referred. Having said that I share that sort of concern and apprehension, I have then to say that I cannot satisfy the honourable gentleman any further. He asked whether I would stop the person in question going to Libya. No, I would not, because one of the things that distinguishes the sort of country which we believe in and the sort of democracy that we pride ourselves on having from that sort of regime is that we do not impose restrictions on the free movement of our citizens. I am afraid that-I hope the honourable gentleman will appreciate the sense in which I put it-were we to stop the free movement of Australian citizens, so much more would we be moving towards the sort of regime that we despise. That covers the second aspect of the question about a so-called Aboriginal passport. The people of this country have Australian passports and those are the ones on which they travel.

ANSWER.PARA: Regarding funding, which was the third aspect of the honourable gentleman's question, action was taken on this matter in a previous year, but I understand that, to the best of my recollection, the then Minister, my friend and colleague the honourable member for Melbourne Ports, undertook an analysis and received undertakings that no Commonwealth funding would be directed in any way towards purposes of the kind that the honourable member and I find abhorrent.

As to the fourth and final part of the question-that is, whether I would take action to stop an ABC television crew, black or white, going to Libya-let me make two points. No, I would not do so, because there is no power in the Government to do such a thing, nor would it, I would think, be received with great acclamation generally across both sides of this House and outside in the community if the Prime Minister were seen to be interfering with the free exercise of the power of the ABC. Having said that, let me make it clear that I find it rather remarkable that an organisation which suggests that it is strapped for financial resources and is pressing the Government to make funds available should consider undertaking such an exercise. I do not think that it makes the best of cases in that regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. What would be the likely impact of the Commonwealth progressively withdrawing from education funding as proposed in some quarters recently?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I am sure that what he is alluding to is the decision of the Federal Council of the Liberal Party to withdraw from the funding of schools throughout Australia. That was one of the many extraordinary decisions and apparently colourful events that occurred at the Hyatt Hotel recently. Of course, on the prominent issues the Leader of the Opposition took the course of simply siding with his boss, Mr Elliott, in order to ensure that he did not suffer the embarrassment of defeat. But on at least one issue he did go down in a screaming heap because, against his wishes, the Council adopted a motion which proposes the progressive withdrawal of Commonwealth involvement in the funding of schools throughout Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: Since this Government has been in office there has been not only a substantial increase in funding for government and non-government schools but also we have put it on a secure basis so that schools throughout Australia have an idea of what they can expect from the Commonwealth. I can say that our secure funding arrangements will continue, although the precise level of funding in the future will depend on Budget decisions. This year we are committing some $950m to the non-government school sector alone. This is a serious matter because the Liberal Party intends to imperil the future of our children in Australia. It intends to imperil their education on the whim of the political fanatics who make up the Liberal Party Federal Council.

The shadow Minister, who is the failed shadow Treasurer, also went down on this issue. He and his Leader opposed the motion and both were defeated. But he knows where the new power in the Liberal Party lies. He knows that that new power lies behind the locked doors of the Liberal Party's Federal Council where Mr Elliott and others can pursue their obsessions. The very next day he said, quite contrary to current Liberal Party policy, that he would observe the wishes of the Federal Council and he has gone about a review which will see, no doubt, the Federal Liberal policy being one of withdrawal of funds from the school sector.

Such a policy would have enormous implications not only for the government sector but also, and more particularly, for the non-government sector. Honourable members must remember that the Commonwealth provides 50 per cent of the recurrent funds of Catholic schools throughout Australia and most of their capital requirements. Lest anyone thinks that the State governments might take up this responsibility with any alacrity, I might point out that this year the Queensland Government has reduced funding to non-government schools by 6 per cent in real terms. The proposal would not only threaten the secure arrangements for non-government schools, which depend so much on Federal funding, but also it would shatter the important partnership between the States and the Commonwealth in relation to establishing national priorities in our education system and determining the important priorities of higher retention and skills development.

I think that this is just another example of the chaos which prevails in Liberal Party policy making, after the Liberal Party has been in opposition for years and has had plenty of time to make up its policies. It just shows that the Liberal Party is unequal to the obligation of office and can look forward to being in opposition forever.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. The Minister appeared to be reading from notes. Is he prepared to table them?
—Does the Minister wish to table his notes?
—No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Papers are tabled as listed in the schedule circulated to honourable members earlier today. Details of the papers will be recorded in Hansard and the Votes and Proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: The schedule read as follows-
Parole Board of the Australian Capital Territory-Annual Report 1986-87-Seat of Government Administration Act.
Commissioner for Employees' Compensation-Anual Report 1986-87-section 122 of the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971.
The Wheat Industry-Industries Assistance Commission Report No. 411.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.
—I claim to have been misrepresented. I also claim that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) has been misrepresented.
—Order! The honourable member cannot claim that on behalf of the Minister for Finance.

—In Question Time the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) claimed that I had published a Press release saying that there had been an increase in Medicare expenditure. I will quote from the Press release of 29 March 1988.

—I raise a point of order, Madam Speaker. My point of order is very simple: the honourable gentleman is entitled to say that he has been misrepresented, but he is not entitled, in saying that, to debate the issue by the use of other publications. He is totally out of order in so doing.

—The honourable member has not yet given his personal explanation. He may not debate his explanation, but he is perfectly entitled to tell the Chair where he has been misrepresented. I call the honourable member for O'Connor.
—The Press release referred to by the Minister says, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: The Shadow Minister for Health, Wilson Tuckey, said today that as he had been predicting for some time, the Federal Government will have no option but to increase the Medicare levy--

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Speaker: the honourable member is confused. I was not referring to that Press release. I was referring to his Press release of 8 April.
—It is a point of explanation rather than a point of order. The honourable member for O'Connor might get to the point.
—The point is, irrespective, that there has been a blow-out, and the figures are in the Minister's--
—Order! The honourable member may not debate the issue. The Chair gave him leave to show how he had been misrepresented. I ask him now to resume his seat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—Please proceed.

—During Question Time the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) referred to an article, headed `Handouts won't stop hardship-poverty experts', in the Melbourne Herald of Monday 11 April 1988. The article gave quotations from Mr Julian Disney, Bishop Hollingworth, Dr Edgar, Dr Cass, Professor Bipond, Mr Saunders, Ms Brownlee, Ms Carter, Senator Powell and me.
—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. I am sure that all those experts were named, but we are interested in where the honourable member was misrepresented.
—Yes. I would like the honourable member to get to the point.

—The Minister stated that I said that we cannot eliminate poverty. He did not read the complete quotation. The article stated that I `described Mr Hawke's promise as too ``deep'' to be fulfilled'. It went on:

SPEECH.PARA: `There is a problem with the high level of single parent families', he said.
`These people will remain in poverty unless family maintenance improves. Poverty concerns taxation, housing and the family environment, not just fiscal transfers.
I don't think you will ever eliminate poverty,' . . .
Every one of the other people quoted agreed with what I said.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member has made his explanation. He will now sit down.
—Madam Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do, Madam Speaker.
—Please proceed.

—During Question Time the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) claimed that I had said, following the passage of a resolution by the Liberal Party Federal Council calling for the progressive withdrawal of the Commonwealth from education, that I would implement that resolution. What I said was that I treated the resolution seriously as a motion passed by the Federal Council of the Liberal Party and that I would be putting an issues paper to the backbench committee and giving it proper consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I wish to make a further personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do, Madam Speaker.
—Please proceed.
—The Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) has now passed to me a further Press release in my name in which I referred to the process of giving a Medicare discount. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: He said that `such moves which would mean reformed smokers and drinkers and people who drastically altered their diet habits and increased their exercise levels would be offered a discount on their Medicare levy would be another contradiction to the already massive Medicare budgetary blowout of $882m.

The figures for medical services and benefits released by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) show a blow-out of 22.6 per cent as compared with a budgetary estimate of 8.8 per cent. If medical services and benefits are not the real Medicare cost, the Minister might tell me what is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member is now trying to debate the issue. He is quite out of order.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The subversion of the proper process of inquiry and debate on Australia's immigration program by the Prime Minister.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's Committee of Inquiry into Australia's Immigration Policies has reported to it on aspects of immigration for Australia's future, as instructed by the Government. The Committee, at the time of its establishment, was hailed by the Government as conducting the biggest review for a decade. It was chaired by Dr Stephen FitzGerald, a distinguished Australian. The Government has been told by this specialist Committee that its immigration program is a failure. The report prepared by Dr FitzGerald's Committee says:

SPEECH.PARA: The current selection procedures are ineffective in controlling numbers. They are not seeking enough skilled and entrepreneurial migrants and they are widely considered inequitable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Madam Speaker. I do not want to stop the honourable gentleman's flow, but I do not have a completed report. For the honourable gentleman to say that he is quoting from the report is to mislead the House. I do not care what other description he gives it but I do not have, and there is not in existence at this stage, a report from the committee.
—There is no strict point of order.

—The Government established this Committee, appointing to it the people that it wanted. It gave it the terms of reference. It is the Government's own Committee. Now the Government is not prepared to wear the recommendations, the comments and the conclusions of its own Committee. Mick Young, in launching this Committee on 23 September 1987, said:

SPEECH.PARA: I . . . urge Australians to become involved, to place their arguments, views and concerns before it, in a spirit of seeking policies in the national interest.

So much for the national interest when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) can subvert the report before it sees the light of day. The members of this Committee are distinguished Australians. They are not members of a Caucus committee; they are distinguished Australians. Let us find out about some of these Australians. They are individuals with the capacity and background to make such an inquiry. They are Dr Stephen FitzGerald, an academic, a businessman, former Ambassador to China, and consultant to the Government; Mr Alan Matheson from the Australian Council of Trade Unions; Dr Alessandra Pucci, Managing Director of Monoclonal Development Pty Ltd and Qantas businesswoman of the year in 1985; Mr Jim Hullick, Secretary of the South Australian Local Government Association; Mr Tony Bonnici, Chairman of the Victorian Ethnic Communities Council and a Victorian barrister; and Professor Helen Hughes, Professor of Economics and Executive Director of the National Centre for Development Studies at the Australian National University-a collection of people chosen by the Government to perform a task.

The Committee was given six months to advise on the economics of immigration, changes to the legislation and administration needed, the relationship between immigration and our population, the capacity of the Australian community to absorb migrants, the proposals for an amnesty, illegal immigrants, refugees and the relationship between immigration and multiculturalism. That was a huge task to be performed in six months. The end of March was the deadline. The Committee reported and the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Holding) received the report. There were no comments about its being a draft report. There were no comments about time being extended to allow the Committee to brush the report up. The deadline was set. It was not a time for fudging, for bodgying up the report. The deadline was known by all Australians.

The Prime Minister, by his answer today, accepted the substance of the questions put to him. The Prime Minister did know of the report, and he did interfere in the processes and final outcome of the report. He has subverted the inquiry and the debate. How will the House know and how will Australians know what was in the original report? How will they know what is the work of distinguished Australians and what is the work of the Prime Minister? How will they be able to sort out the results of long hours of consultation, of going through submissions, as this Committee has done? How will they distinguish that detail from the policy, polemics and philosophies of the Government? They will be intermixed. It will be a corrupted and doctored report.

The cost of the report to the Australian community is $860,000-over three-quarters of a million dollars. Distinguished Australians have taken part in examining this huge list of sensitive and difficult matters. They have spent a lot of time and have received a lot of Government support. There has been $860,000 spent on this process. The Government is prepared to pollute, corrupt and subvert because it is not happy with the result of the Committee's inquiry. I refer to what Mick Young and Stephen FitzGerald have been reported as saying in national newspapers. Mick Young said, `I will not pre-empt the inquiry. I will not interfere'. FitzGerald said, `We are not going to be a rubber stamp for the Government'. Those two statements were made in the course of the inquiry and they are proper statements.

These are sensitive issues; we do need to address them. I do not, nor does the Opposition, have any view about what Stephen FitzGerald and his Committee have reported. We want to discuss these matters but we want to know the base from where we should start. We want to know what that Committee found before the debate commences. There should be debate; it is proper that debate should take place on these matters. It is an important inquiry and there should be no doubt, from the commencement, that the Committee's report is a proper report-unpolluted and uncorrupted.

What about the commitments of the Minister, the Prime Minister, and the Government? Today the Prime Minister shifted ground. In answer to the first question he said, `I have not read', and, `I did not direct'. His answer to the second question, however, was: `No, I did not read'; `I was briefed'. Typical skating out from under. Can we trust the Prime Minister? Most Australians do not, and this is the reason why-the bland statement up-front and then the backtrack. What about the second issue. The Prime Minister said, `I did not direct'. He watered that statement down to: `I will not change the recommendations'. What about the conclusions and the substance of the report? They are as significant as the recommendations. If the Opposition and all concerned Australians are to participate but conclusions have been manipulated and facts and chapters changed, how can we decide whether it is an accurate presentation?

The Prime Minister is saying that the recommendations stand but that somehow or other it will change the process by which the recommendations are arrived. The recommendations are likely to suit the Government in any event. The Opposition believes this is a sensitive matter. There are community concerns, and, as a parliament, we cannot walk away from those concerns. My Party and the Opposition have a proud record in matters of immigration and the settlement of people from all around the world. We have a proud record in relation to the settlement of people with special humanitarian needs and special circumstances that apply to refugees and to families. We do not resile from that record; it is a fine record. May I say that that record is more substantial, both in quality and in quantity, than the record of this Government. That record is the reason that we want to be assured in detail of the changes that the Prime Minister has made. What directions did he give? How will the report be changed? How has the draft been fiddled with? I refer to the report in the past tense because the original report no doubt no longer exists. Already the work has started.
It is no good the Government saying that it has not interfered. The Prime Minister, in his statement today, said that he has done so. Of the Committee the former Minister, Mr Young, said:
Each member is specifically knowledgeable in the social, economic and population dimensions of immigration, while bringing a breadth of other experience to this task.

These are people with diverse backgrounds and with wide interests. They are people, on one side, who are interested and knowledgeable in the law, economics, foreign affairs, and the world at large. They have a knowledge of the work force and business. They would appear to me to form an appropriate membership of the Committee, but the Committee was given an impossible task. I have read to the House the huge list of items the Government expected the Committee to address in a short period of six months. It was almost an Herculean task. But the Committee rose to the task and endeavoured to address matters of great importance to Australia. Yet the Government has sought to denigrate that process by changing the report before it becomes public, which is completely inappropriate.

The Prime Minister, by his attitudes, has indicated that he does not believe inquiries are worth having. The fact of the matter is that this is the second inquiry in this area that the Government has changed, rejected or neglected. Do honourable members recall the Dr James Jupp Review of Migrant and Multicultural Programs and Services? It was supposed to provide all the answers to problems relating to the settlement of migrants in Australia. That report still has not been dealt with by the Government. It languishes on the sideboard because the Government has done nothing about it.

If the Government wants to gain the trust, confidence, and goodwill of the Australian community in this regard, it has to be fair dinkum and up-front with it. It is no good the Government going behind closed doors, changing the substance of significant reports such as this where there is sensitivity and concern. The Prime Minister, by the stupid action he undertook, has corrupted the process. All we will have is a bodgie, doctored report. I hope that when the final report is prepared Stephen FitzGerald and the other members of the Committee will be public in their comments about whether or not the real intentions of the Committee were changed. I hope they are not knobbled by the Government. If anything is needed in Australia, it is honest debate. But the Prime Minister's personal attitudes do not permit that.

I do not impute any motives to the Minister. I believe he has acted properly throughout this process and I express my appreciation to him for the way in which he has endeavoured to handle this difficult matter. But the Minister is not the problem; it is his boss-the bloke who is down there in the corner, who is so insecure and feels so threatened that he is not prepared to have a report tabled in the Parliament that is critical of a number of areas of Government policy. The Government, the Opposition, and the community can reject and modify the report. Ours is the decision-making process. But first of all, let us start with the facts, let us start with the real knowledge and with the work of these talented individuals so that we have a sure starting base, and, may I say, an equal starting base from which the Minister and his Party, and I and the Opposition, can work together.

If doubts are sown in the minds of Opposition members and in the minds of Australian citizens at this stage, I do not like the Government's chances of getting through this process properly. It has to be done for the sake of the national interest, and now is the time to start. The man down in the corner, the Prime Minister, should be prevented from corrupting this process and from subverting the process of proper debate on such important issues as immigration, multiculturalism, settlement, selection, illegal immigrants, and the entire mess that the Minister inherited from the three Ministers who preceded him. In the 2 1/2 years that I have been shadow Minister, four different Ministers have occupied this portfolio. No wonder the program is in a mess. But let us try to settle the matter in a proper way. There is no doubt that the Government has been improper and inappropriate in its actions. It corrupted this process at the beginning and it has subverted the debate, the discussion and the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I should say that I feel a great sense of sadness for the way in which this matter has been presented on behalf of the Opposition. I feel this sadness for this reason: I have said publicly to the media, on television and on radio-and I say publicly to this House-that I believe the tabling of the report of the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies will make available a document that will provide the parameters for a rational, sensible debate on a wide variety of issues that go to the entire question of our immigration policy and the type of nation we want Australia to be. I do not for one moment resile from that commitment.

SPEECH.PARA: As the shadow Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), will confirm, when I became Minister he asked me to provide him with a copy of a draft model Bill which will form part of the report of the FitzGerald Committee of Inquiry into Australia's immigration policies. I indicated to him that I would endeavour to discharge that. Early last week in a discussion with him I indicated that I would try to extract conclusions from the recommendations made in the report. I said that I would endeavour to provide that to him and to the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Haines) so that they would be in a position to consider all the issues and topics, which I think have to be considered with maturity, and I say with some deliberation, to enable parties in this Parliament and people in the broader community to formulate their positions. I think that was a proper gesture and I still stand by it.

The problem is a simple one. There have been a number of speculative Press reports, not merely in the national media but in the ethnic Press, and I have endeavoured wherever possible to remedy that without in any way pre-empting the recommendations of the Committee. It is the Committee's report. How the report is put and the recommendations it makes are matters for the Committee. Let me go back to the immediate issue. Dr FitzGerald has made it perfectly clear that there are three elements in this report. The first is the report itself and its recommendations. The second is a series of accompanying documents and articles which are the work of private consultants who were commissioned by the Committee. I think some four of those documents have already been made public; as yet, the others have not. The final element is a draft Bill. That will constitute the report. When I receive it I expect to receive a letter, as I normally do, saying, `Minister, here is the report and the accompanying documents'. The report will contain recommendations, and when the report is tabled debate can begin. I indicated to the shadow Minister that to the extent to which I could put all honourable members on notice I would be happy to do so.

What is the present position about directions from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and antagonism? The fact is that there was a totally erroneous Press report which indicated that there were directions by the Prime Minister, that I had been carpeted, and that all sorts of directions were issued. Let me say to the House that the statement made by the Prime Minister today was completely accurate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which one?

—The honourable member knows which one. I can enlarge upon it in this way. I sought the appointment with the Prime Minister because I had to inform him that we were not going to have the report within the timeframe and schedule in which I had hoped to get it. What I did receive was a working report. I received one before Easter and a second one after Easter. For the information of the honourable gentleman opposite, I received a third working document yesterday. At the request of the shadow Minister I have asked for copies of the working or model Bill, as it is called. I could not get them last week because I was told that work was still taking place in respect of it.
—I got one at a consultation.

—Yes, but it is different from the one I have. It is a subsequent Bill that I received this week, which is different from the one the honourable member got at a consultation. The one I received this week is available; it is an updated model. On the front it is clearly marked `Draft Only', and work is continuing. That is the state of play. That is the reality. So whatever documents are available, either to the Caucus committee, to the Democrats, or to honourable members opposite, they are documents which, whatever they constitute, do not constitute the report.

SPEECH.PARA: One may well ask: how did this matter of public importance before us today emerge? It emerged on the basis of a totally inaccurate Press report which suggested that the Prime Minister had given directions. I say without hesitation that that is completely false. I was there; I should know. It would have been appropriate for the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), if he knew his job, to say in a Press release, `I've read that allegation. It's a matter of concern to me as a responsible Leader of the Opposition and I will press that matter home in order to discover either the truth or the falsity of it'. That would have been a responsible position for a responsible Leader of the Opposition to take. But what happened? Before Parliament had even met, the Leader of the Opposition issued a Press release on the basis of an inaccurate, false and mischievous Press report. What did he say? He not only attacked the Prime Minister-I understand that; we all understand that that is how the game is played-but also he attacked the Committee that has been lauded and praised by the shadow Minister. Let me quote the words of the Leader of the Opposition:
The Prime Minister's behaviour has damaged not only his own credibility but that of the final report of the FitzGerald Committee.

I ask honourable members to think about that and weigh it up. The Leader of the Opposition picks up a Press statement in the morning newspapers. He has no capacity to check it out. He does not wait for Parliament to meet, to use the proper and legitimate processes of this Parliament, to put whatever questions he wants to put to the Prime Minister and to myself. That is not the way this Leader of the Opposition behaves. He issues a Press statement based on a falsity, making allegations against the Prime Minister. He then goes on to attack the integrity of the Committee.

In the second question asked yesterday, the chairman of the Caucus committee, the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), asked me about the state of the FitzGerald report. I made a very full statement to the House as to the processes that had taken place, the nature of the report, and when I expected to receive it. It was open to the Leader of the Opposition to pursue me in respect of any of those details. It was open to the Opposition today to pursue the matter further. I did not receive one further question during the whole of Question Time yesterday. Today a question was directed to the Prime Minister in which he was asked whether he had issued any direction and the answer was perfectly clear that he had not. Before this Parliament had even met, before that question could even be put, I received on my table notice of this matter of public importance. It is not a question of coming in here and exploring and seeking the truth; it is a question of this Opposition grabbing any desperate piece of scuttlebutt and trying to mount a case. That is why I am sad.

I do not believe that the shadow Minister has his heart in this matter of public importance. I do not believe it for two seconds. I believe that he was genuinely concerned to try, when the report was received and the relevant documents were there, to get his Party into a position where it had an informed and responsible position. He does not believe that Dr FitzGerald or any member of this Committee is the sort of Australian that would be stood over by anybody. He does not believe it and he knows in his heart that it is not true. I suppose that the problem if one is a shadow Minister-because the shadow Ministers have been muted by this incompetent Leader of the Opposition-is that one has to take whatever case one is given, whether or not it is based on a tissue of lies, and try to make something of it. I genuinely felt sad for the role the shadow Minister was called upon to play.

I hope-and I believe that this is still possible -that this report will provide a basis for this House and this community to debate these serious issues as they ought to be debated, without heat or malice and in a spirit of trying to find solutions to what are very important and pressing problems. Whether those opposite agree with all the recommendations of the FitzGerald Committee or reject some and accept others is the prerogative of the Opposition, just as it is the prerogative of the Government to accept or reject any aspect of that report. That is how this process works.

TALK.START.PARA: —How it should work.

—That is how it will work according to this Government and this Minister; but the shadow Minister is talking about this matter today because the Leader of the Opposition has made yet another mess of this exercise, talking about a report which he has not seen--
—How do you know?

—He has not seen it, and the honourable member knows it. He has not seen the most recent draft because I got it only yesterday afternoon-and there is more to come. What is the honourable member talking about? There is no final report; so he has not seen it and his Leader has not seen it. But he thinks he is entitled, on the basis of that, having said that noble Australians are producing it, to say in this House-God help us-that the document these people have worked on has been corrupted and doctored. They are the terms that were used-corrupted and doctored, polluted and subverted. That is the terminology of those opposite.

SPEECH.PARA: The people of Australia are entitled to expect much more than that from this Opposition and the people who have worked on this Committee are entitled to receive much more. I do not believe that the shadow Minister's heart was in this matter. He was trying to get this hopeless Leader of the Opposition out of the mess he got himself into by his own careless actions. Let me say that I will endeavour to argue, as I have argued, to maintain the integrity of this Committee and of this report. Where there are Press statements-and there have been plenty-which endeavour to distort some of the conclusions, I will try to answer those without in any way pre-empting the rights, obligations and duties of the Committee. This sad matter of public importance reflects grievously on the parlous state of this Opposition. What do we do as a government when the case that is built up against the Prime Minister is the subject of one question at Question Time in this Parliament? He denied it.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were two.

—It does not matter whether there were two, three or four. The answers would have been the same. I did not get a question. It is bad enough that those opposite-and there are some men of honour on the other side-on a major issue which goes to the whole question of the fiscal structure of this Commonwealth and the whole basis of social justice and equity in the important area of taxation have allowed themselves to be neutered. I pray and hope that in the final FitzGerald report members of the Committee do not make recommendations and then suggest that they be paid for out of a consumption tax-because if that happens those opposite will be able to say nothing.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that the shadow Minister and other members of the Opposition will try to extract themselves from the impossible position they are in with respect to this report. I say to the shadow Minister that I will honour the undertakings that I have given him in terms of trying to get as much material as possible to him so that the Opposition can obtain an informed position-because I believe that it is in the interests of this country that it do that so that there can be informed and rational debate on this report.
