Let us have done with this nonsense about corruption and a document which is described in terms of being a corrupted and doctored report. There is no such thing. When I have received the final report it will be made available to this Parliament. To the extent that I can co-operate with the Opposition in providing the information it needs so that it, and my Caucus committee, can get themselves into a position where they are properly informed, those undertakings will be honoured.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Holding), the Minister at the table, for doing a pretty good job with a pretty poor subject. There is no doubt that immigration is an area which causes more discussion and concern in the community than just about anything else one can mention. It is particularly so today. We have seen it happen so often in the past few years that public debate about immigration can become extremely heated and people can become extremely emotional. Therefore I, like all the other members of the Opposition, welcome the decision by the former Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to set up the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies. It was in 1977, under the Fraser Government, that the previous broad-ranging investigation into immigration policies was carried out-and it resulted in the Green Paper.
—That was when you were the Minister.

—I thank the honourable member. It happened to be when I was the Minister for Immigration. It was designed to accomplish and did accomplish the task of allowing people and groups throughout Australia to express their views as to the nature of the Australian immigration intake, the integration of migrants into Australia once they had arrived here and many other aspects of the whole process. It was an important task that that committee was given and it is an important task that the FitzGerald Committee has been given.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important also that the public have confidence in the role of that Committee and in the final reports. The Minister has pointed out at some length that there is not just one report but three reports to come forward at the end of this process. It is important that the community can have confidence that those people, headed by Dr FitzGerald and appointed by the present Government, have been able to carry out their task free of coercion from anyone. That is the point about which this issue is being raised today-free of coercion from anyone, particularly the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).

This is an area where, hopefully, debate will be less emotional than it can become. It is important for the future of this country that that process take place because there is no doubt that the future of this country hinges largely around the immigration process and program, just as it has particularly since the end of World War II. We would not be the country we are today without the immigration program. The nature and composition of the immigration program determines the sort of nation Australia will become. That is why this matter is so important and why it is important that this Committee should have expertise available to it and should be able to consider the submissions made to it, free of coercion.

Let me come to the coercion point. The Minister at the table was very clever in the way he approached the task of answering the charges. He said, `You should not believe what you read in the papers'. I understand that completely. All of us in politics would endorse that sentiment. But then he went on to say, `I sought an appointment with the Prime Minister. I was not carpeted. He did not say anything nasty and cruel to me. I went along to see him'. Why did the Minister go along to see the Prime Minister? Why was it necessary for the Minister to talk to the Prime Minister about the working papers which the FitzGerald Committee had made available to him? Is that not, by itself, an interference in the affairs of the Committee? Why was it necessary to brief the Prime Minister? Could it be that the Prime Minister was being briefed by somebody else?
I remember what happened during the Green Paper debate in 1977. The Prime Minister of the day was also very keen on being briefed by his experts.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did that quite a bit, too.

—He did it in a number of areas but particularly in relation to immigration-and the present Prime Minister learned from the previous Prime Minister. He has an office within his Department which briefs him on these matters, the Office of Multicultural Affairs. If the present Prime Minister-and I believe this to be the case-has some of the attitudes of the previous Prime Minister, I am quite certain he would want to know what was likely to be happening in the FitzGerald inquiry. He would say to his advisers, `Hey, what is the buzz? What are these guys up to? What are they coming forward with?'. I am quite certain that he would receive information and a report from his advisers.

SPEECH.PARA: Now we get the spectacle of the present Minister, on his own instigation, going along to the Prime Minister and saying: `Look, I am coming to see you about this draft report. Let us have a bit of a chat about it'. I do not know what went on. I was not present when the Minister, at his instigation, sought that meeting with the Prime Minister. I really would like to know why he felt it was so important that he should go along at that time and brief the Prime Minister. But what do we find the Prime Minister saying? In answer to the first question he said, `I have not read the report'. That is quite right, he has not read the report. He probably has not even read the draft report-the first, second, third or however many versions there are. But what did he say later? He said, `I was briefed'.

Who briefed the Prime Minister, apart from the Minister? What was the briefing about, and what did it contain? Did it disturb the Prime Minister? Was he concerned with the briefing that he got? Did he raise with the Minister some of the concerns he had been briefed about? Did he say anything to the Minister? Did he say, `Look, I have got this briefing. It seems to me that the chaps are heading a little bit in the wrong direction here and there and I think we might make some adjustments, don't you believe so, Clyde, mate, digger, cobber, sport'? Would not that be more likely? `I have not read the report', he said, all sanctimoniously, `but I was briefed'. He did not say what the briefing was.

Why did not the Minister tell us what the briefing was? `I didn't direct', he said. What did he go on to say? `The recommendations will not be changed'. That is very significant-`the recommendations will not be changed'. He did not say anything about the content of the report. He did not say there were some aspects of the report that the people who were briefing the Prime Minister were pretty concerned about. And he did not like the way some of the statements leading up to the recommendations were being made. He may have been concerned about that, but he does not say anything about that in his answer in the House today. `The recommendations will not be changed', is what he said. He did not deny that he may have made some suggestions as to the content of the final report.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did so; he made that quite clear.
—Is the Minister saying to me that there is no truth in the belief, which some people have, that some suggestions were made by the Prime Minister-not directions, suggestions?
—You can speculate all you like; you are bound by his answer.

—The interesting thing is that an incredible amount of work is going on at present on finalising this report. Why is that incredible amount of work going on at present? Why did the Minister go to the Prime Minister-at the Minister's own instigation, he hastens to tell us? He was not carpeted-not much! Everybody knows the way this Prime Minister operates. Everybody knows the way this Prime Minister would like to see this report come out-based on the aspects of immigration and the directions of immigration that he would like to see. That is the really worrying aspect of this whole thing.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a matter which requires, hopefully, dispassionate debate. It is an area which requires the opportunity for groups and individuals right throughout the Australian community to put forward their suggestions, their ideas, their fears and their hopes about the composition, make-up, direction and all other aspects of Australia's migration program, ranging from skilled people to family reunion, to the question of illegal migrants, to the question of refugee resettlement. That whole issue is enormously important. That we have a situation where it appears pretty apparent that the Prime Minister has had discussions with his Minister responsible for this area before the report is presented to this Parliament, gives the unmistakable impression that once again the Prime Minister has interfered, and once again the Minister has had to come into the House and use all his legal trickery to get away from the prime point; and the prime point is that the Prime Minister did haul the Minister over the coals. The Prime Minister did make sure that the report would be written in the general direction he sought. That is an utter disgrace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I see the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) is about to leave the chamber. Well, he should not, because he is a disgrace as Leader of the Opposition in the way he has behaved in trying to bring the name of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) into this matter and in the way in which he has tried to smear members of the Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies. I proceed to substantiate the comments which I have just made. As the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Holding) said in his remarks, the Leader of the Opposition issued a statement on the basis of nothing more than a report in one newspaper. Similar reports had appeared in previous times, but nothing was done about them. But, in this particular newspaper there was an exciting statement. The statement that excited the Leader of the Opposition was something to the effect that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs had been carpeted by the Prime Minister. What rubbish! On the basis of that the Opposition decided there was something in that report and it had better do something about it. Without even consulting the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), the Leader of the Opposition issued a statement. He did not wait until the afternoon to ask questions about it in the House; he issued a statement in which he attempted to smear the Prime Minister and to smear members of the FitzGerald inquiry. Unfortunately, that process has been followed up by the shadow Minister. He also has sought to smear Dr FitzGerald and the other members of his inquiry in a disgraceful way. He started off by saying what distinguished Australians they are, what intellectual integrity they had, and so on. Then he said that the report had been doctored and corrupted.
—By the Prime Minister.

—Is the Leader of the Opposition suggesting that Dr FitzGerald will change the report simply because some suggestions are supposed to have been made-and we deny that they have been made-to him by the Prime Minister? That is an extraordinary suggestion to be making about a man of the integrity of Dr Stephen FitzGerald. The Leader of the Opposition should be ashamed of himself. Furthermore, the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) suggested that coercion had been used in this matter. What rubbish! Members of the Opposition do not even know what has been going on. That is their problem. They do not know the whole process. The shadow Minister should know. The Leader of the Opposition would not have a clue because he never takes an interest in issues of immigration and certainly never takes an interest in issues of multiculturalism.

SPEECH.PARA: I have yet to hear the Leader of the Opposition defend the concept of multiculturalism in this House. That is the sort of man we are dealing with. He allows the shadow Minister to race around Australia and talk about multiculturalism, but he never does that himself because fundamentally he does not believe in it. I return to the basic point, which is that Dr FitzGerald received many submissions and as part of his job decided to discuss aspects of his report with a number of people. He has done that. So what! It was his job to discuss aspects of his report with a number of people. The shadow Minister would not deny that, would he?

TALK.START.PARA: —Good idea.

—Yes. The shadow Minister went to a workshop on this matter along with the FitzGerald Committee. This has been an open process. The collection of data has been an open process. Therefore, why should the Minister, according to the scenario we have heard here, take the report under his jacket, race off to the Prime Minister's office and say to the Prime Minister, `We have got some problems with this report.'? What rubbish! First, the Prime Minister is, as the honourable member for Warringah says, aware of the submissions made to the Committee because he has been kept in touch with those processes. It has been an open process, not a closed process that Dr FitzGerald has undertaken. What is the big secret supposed to be?

SPEECH.PARA: I go to my next point. As the shadow Minister himself has said, when this report comes out-it is not finalised yet-it will contain a series of recommendations. It will contain a series of statements about immigration, about multiculturalism and a number of other matters. As a result of that report we will have community discussion and a discussion in the Parliament. Therefore, why should the Minister worry if, for example, there are aspects of the report about which either the Prime Minister or he are unhappy? Why should they worry about that? The fact is that Dr FitzGerald can recommend what he wishes. It is up to the Government and the Parliament to accept or reject those recommendations. That point has been made again and again. It has not only been made by the Government but also been supported by some Opposition speakers. Logically, why should the Prime Minister be involved in such a process? Of course, this is all an absurdity.

What is even more serious is the hypocrisy that is involved. We have heard the shadow Minister talking about the subversion by the Prime Minister of the proper process of inquiry and debate on Australia's immigration program. If we are to accuse anyone of being involved in subversion of the debate on this matter we must accuse members of the Opposition because they have made a series of statements in relation to the FitzGerald review. This is the latest action on their part. However, I remind them of an earlier action which shows just how much they believe in debate.

When I made my submission to the FitzGerald inquiry as chairman of the Government members immigration committee-I also made a personal submission-what happened? The shadow Minister without even reading my submission-I had the courtesy to send him my submission but he had not then received it-attacked the submission on the basis of Press reports. My submission was described in an Age editorial as worthy of consideration in the most serious terms by the FitzGerald Committee. The shadow Minister attacked it. Last Sunday, after he had read the report, he was asked on a Special Broadcasting Service program, `What do you think about Dr Theophanous's recommendations?'. He said, `I agree with quite a few of these. I agree with this problem'. This is the shadow Minister who does not know what he is doing, who jumps the gun. This is another case of his having jumped the gun. Certainly, he was not interested in debate in relation to that aspect of the submission.

I ask him: What about the other submissions to the FitzGerald inquiry which have been made public? Has he considered those? Has he contributed to the debate on those? If he wants to have a serious debate on this matter we will have a debate. Of course we are going to have such a debate. However, the action taken here today has made the debate more difficult because the shadow Minister in his comments has tried to undermine the integrity of Dr FitzGerald and the report itself. In so doing he is suggesting that people such as Dr FitzGerald will be submitted to some form of coercion or that the report will be corrupted. That is what was said. The shadow Minister did not simply imply that the Prime Minister might have been trying to do an exercise. He said that the report had been corrupted and doctored. That is an outrageous statement. If the shadow Minister made that statement outside this House Dr FitzGerald and other people would be entitled to take legal action against him for implying that they had been pushed around by the Minister, the Prime Minister or anybody else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!
—That is not rubbish at all. The fact is that he made that statement. Yesterday the Leader of the Opposition said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister's behaviour has damaged not only his own credibility but that of the final report of the FitzGerald Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Humbug!

—It is humbug that the Prime Minister had anything to do with those actions described by the shadow Minister. Secondly, what the Opposition has done by raising this issue on the basis of a false statement in the newspapers is that it has thrown a lot of cold water on the integrity of the report itself and the people writing the report. The shadow Minister then has the cheek to stand up and describe them as brilliant Australians who are making a substantial contribution. That is a very hypocritical approach to have taken. I say to the shadow Minister that we will proceed. We will not be deflected. We will proceed with a genuine debate on immigration in this country. We call on honourable members opposite to get involved in the decent aspects of the debate and not to try to bring up red herrings of this kind.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I say that the Prime Minister has been unjustly slandered in this process by the shadow Minister and the Leader of the Opposition. His record on these matters, especially his defence of multiculturalism, can withstand anything honourable members opposite say.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The debate is concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1987-88[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1987-88APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1987-88]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 March, on motion by Mr Dawkins:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate Appropriation Bill (No. 3) concurrently with Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2). There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) and the Government for bringing this business before the House slightly out of order as per the blue sheet purely and simply to meet my convenience. For that I am grateful. Today we are debating Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1987-88, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1987-88 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1987-88. These traditional Bills are to meet expenditure additional to the appropriations made for the current financial year under Appropriation Act (No. 1) and Appropriation Act (No. 2) and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Act. As these Bills are an integral part of the budgetary process, the coalition will not be opposing them. Of course, these appropriations are required to meet commitments that have been approved by the Government since the Budget, as well as requirements of an ongoing nature.

SPEECH.PARA: The principal factors underlying these requirements include certain unavoidable cost and price increases and other parameter changes since the Budget was prepared. In fact, the Government likes to tell us that these are essential and unavoidable expenditures. That may be so in one sense-in a technical or contractual sense. However, there is no way that many of these expenditures and the programs of which they form part could legitimately be regarded as essential and unavoidable. The reason why this Government, frankly, is on the nose throughout every State in Australia is its intrusion into people's lives. The dead hand of government weighs heavily as a burden on taxpayers' backs. These expenditures simply translate into tax collections elsewhere in the Government's books. To highlight that I move an amendment which states:
That all words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting, the following words:
``whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House notes that:

(1) Budget estimates put Commonwealth Government outlays at over a quarter of Australia's GDP, and that this is funded by revenue collection that has made this the highest taxing Government in the post-war history of Australia;
(2) the Government has increasingly burdened not only individuals but business with new incentive-sapping taxes like the fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax;
(3) national productivity is not expected to rise much more than a dismal 0.5% during the course of 1987-88; and

(4) without the incentive to invest and work productively, Australia will find it increasingly difficult to extricate itself from its $87 billion foreign debt strait jacket without further reductions in our standard of living''.

I expect that various shadow Ministers and other Opposition members will discuss the specific effects of these Bills on various portfolios. However, I wish to address myself, in line with the amendment I have just moved, to the poor state of the Australian economy. In September 1986 Moody's downgraded Australia's AAA credit rating and the current Treasurer (Mr Keating) was rated the world's second worst Finance Minister by Euromoney magazine. That is the same journal which, a couple of years earlier, had given him some kudos. To use a previous farming analogy of the Treasurer, the Government had ploughed the field and sown the seeds and now it was harvest time. What a bitter harvest it has been. The Government sowed the seeds when it added $15 billion to this country's public debt in its first two years of government. This swallowed up domestic savings into wasteful expenditures and caused business to go offshore for funds. However, to listen to the Government today, one would think that the earlier crisis of a short 18 months ago had vanished. Nonetheless, that has not fooled, amongst others, the overseas analysts and it certainly has not fooled the people of Australia. As far as overseas analysts are concerned, in reviewing Australia's credit rating drop in March this year Moody's stated:

The pace of adjustment since 1983 has been steady but slow relative to several other OECD countries that have faced similar deficit problems. A pertinent question is whether this gradualist approach to reform will succeed rapidly enough to prevent external borrowing requirements from reaching unacceptably high levels.

The latest figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics show that at the end of last year net foreign debt stood at $86.8 billion, up by $4.1 billion on the level at the end of September 1987. Any perceived improvements in the Australian economy in recent months are just that-mainly perceived, but without substance. Our economy is still highly vulnerable as is shown by the foreign debt figures. The terms of trade have been rising as commodity prices respond. Wool has dominated the rise in commodity prices, while nickel prices have skyrocketed and prices for aluminium, beef and wheat have also grown strongly. This has led to a slightly improved export outlook.

But what is our future? The stock market crash of October 1987 was a warning to certain countries to address their structural problems. Australia was obviously one of those in need of warning and with such an enormous stock of foreign debt, there is no doubt that we remain one of the most vulnerable economies in the industrialised world.

Yet today, a highly misleading media statement was released by the Confederation of Australian Industry (CAI). The CAI makes a number of points. It states that the Australian economy can be regarded as being `in the process of recovery'. I find it incredible that this organisation can hold such a view in the face of the evidence-huge and growing foreign debt, more than 580,000 people unemployed and an inflation rate more than double that of our trading partners. The CAI implies that there has been `restraint'. What restraint? Nominal wages have been running at about 6.5 per cent per annum over the last few years and public sector demand continues to grow. The CAI also climbs on to the Government's and the trade union leadership's band wagon and claims that `labour market flexibility has been improved'. If it had been, why are more than half a million people unemployed? The CAI's claims, quite frankly, are more than spurious in this regard. The Government has supported flat, across-the-board wage increases which disadvantage young people and apprentices particularly. Is that what it calls an improvement in labour market flexibility?

Clearly, the outlook for the economy remains precarious. We remain highly susceptible to external shocks and those shocks could easily occur, given the task that the incoming President of the United States of America will face. Whoever is elected, his responsibility will be to address that economy's problems and, as a result, a subsequent recession cannot be discounted. The reality is that no matter who is elected in the United States, that person will have to move immediately with the degree of goodwill that will exist for him in those early stages. He will have to try to take Congress with him and take decisions to address the sorts of structural imbalances that the United States has in its economy. This will have its impact. We should be getting our own house in order before those actions are taken and the consequences impact upon us throughout 1989.

Indeed, all the areas of commodity price rises that I mentioned earlier are the same old traditional staple exports. The rises in those prices are assisting us now. But the underlying realities remain bad. The Government has not even addressed the area of so-called micro-economic reform. The micro-economic reform agenda was to be the hallmark of the third Hawke Government and that is just not getting off the ground. Productivity remains despairingly low. This is directly related to the low level of investment, which means that Australian workers are working with a depleted and outmoded capital stock. Not only is this seen as detrimental in terms of foreign debt statistics, but it is also seen as such in human terms as well.

There are two key reasons for Australia's current low standard of living and these are low productivity and high taxes. These are two factors which are entirely within the Government's control. Low productivity means low real wages. High taxes means that pay as you earn taxpayers take home less of their already low real wages. In short, the deterioration in our living standards is very much a direct result of the Government's mismanagement of the economy. Figures based on the work of the National Institute of Economic and Industry Research suggest that more than 2 1/2 million people-one in every eight households-live in poverty. Of that total, more than 20 per cent are children. The number of people on public housing waiting lists has gone up by 35 per cent to 166,000 since Labor took office in 1983. It is now estimated that 100,000 people are on the Medicare waiting list. One of the most distressing figures comes from the Human Rights Commission which suggests that there could be as many as 40,000 people sleeping in refuges and emergency accommodation or in the open.

The biggest cause of poverty is unemployment and according to the preliminary figures for March 1988 the number of unemployed still stands at 588,000 people. I have said before, but of course it needs to be said again, that the pace of economic adjustment in the face of our external imbalances is just too slow. In the past it has allowed these various indices of social distress to climb. For the future it lays Australia wide open to further body blows. The policy of the Liberal and National parties is directed towards reducing the size of government and hence the taxation burden on the community. A decrease in the tax burden increases the incentives to invest and, of course, the incentive to work. Along with micro-economic reforms to increase productivity, reduced taxes are the major avenue to raising standards of living for all Australians.

There is a need to run a Budget surplus. We are going to have a surplus in the next Budget. We could well have included within the May statement an estimate by the Treasurer that we could have a surplus at the end of this financial year of approximately $1 billion. While I concede that there will be policy changes, if we project the flow of revenue to the current Government in the next financial year without policy changes to establish what is transpiring there will be a Budget surplus of $3 billion to $3.5 billion.

When we take that figure in association with the demise of the Australian Labor Party throughout Australia and the cry that it is out of touch with its grassroots, the pressure is being put on the Treasurer already from members of the Left and others to use that money and to shovel more funds into the community by way of various programs that can be dreamt up. This will be entirely the wrong course of action. Might I say that it will jeopardise the Treasurer's own thrust at the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). He has got the numbers to take over. If he succumbs to the pressure that is there at present he will lose credibility amongst those who want to see Australia's economic house put in order.

What the Government must do in its budgeting is ensure that moderate surpluses remain. It must do that as a matter of paramount importance. It is important to run surpluses on the Commonwealth Budget for two reasons. First, there is a need to reduce the public sector debt rather than bequeath a huge debt to our children. The debt is massive now and we must take steps to reduce that debt. Secondly, the Commonwealth should run a surplus to offset the deficits run by the States for obvious macroeconomic and, hence, balance of payments reasons.

On 27 October last year I drew the Treasurer's attention during Question Time to the net borrowings of public financial enterprises. I still have not received a reply to the question. The Treasury, as distinct from the Treasurer, undoubtedly shares my concern at the amount of debt these public financial enterprises in the States are running up. For reasons of brevity, I will not quote the statement in the last Budget papers, but the Treasury's concern is expressed at page 418 of the Budget Papers. Public financial enterprises, and in particular State government insurance offices, have become substantial net borrowers in recent years. According to the Treasury, between June 1983 and June 1987 net borrowings for these authorities rose rapidly from $200m to more than $2,000m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't--

—I do not know what is happening to the honourable member and his legal practice, but he calls into question a number of the members here. When I have established precisely what the Law Institute is doing to the honourable member and for what reasons-negligence, defalcation or whatever-this House will be acquainted with it. I am fed up with the sorts of remarks that the honourable member shovels across to this side of the House. The honourable member knows-if he is not able to practise law now, he would know from when he was taught about law-that if one came to a court such as the court of the parliament or a court of equity, one had to come with clean hands. While the honourable member's are dirtied, he should keep his trap shut. We will deal with him a little later on another occasion. We are not going to put up with rubbish from fellows who cannot look after other people's moneys.
—The honourable member for McEwen should not be interjecting from a place other than his proper seat.

—According to the Treasury, between June 1983 and June 1987 net borrowing for these authorities rose rapidly from $200m to more than $2,000m. However, the Treasurer has not seemed concerned. As I indicated a few minutes ago, he did not know anything about the issue when on 27 October last year I asked him why such a situation had been permitted to occur and what measures were being taken to place these organisations on a sound financial basis. Despite prompting on at least two other occasions, the Treasurer has not furnished a reply to my question.

SPEECH.PARA: We were informed only yesterday by the Victorian Auditor-General that the Accident Compensation Commission in the State has lost $244.5m as a result of the stock market crash and that total stock market losses of Victorian authorities amount to almost $1 billion. The Victorian Workcare system is absolutely collapsing and, in the process, has accumulated a deficit of $1.71 billion. But that is not the end of the matter. Across in Perth the Labor Government has participated, through the State Government Insurance Office, in a rescue package. Not only is the debt escalating in Victoria, but also over in Western Australia we find that firms are in trouble, looking as if they are going to go under. Who comes to rescue them? I do not mind elements of the private sector getting together to prop up companies. That is all right. If fellow participants in the capitalist system want to rescue someone, that is fine; that is their choice. But when State authorities bob up and put taxpayers' money into propping up companies, one is forced to ask not only whether this is a wise thing to do but also whether it is correct. The State Government Insurance Office in Western Australia entered into a rescue package for at least two businesses-Rothwells Ltd and the Bell Group. The Treasurer was, of course, privy to these rescue packages. Indeed, he has offered both overt and covert encouragement to State authorities to participate in the financial restructuring of some businesses which suffered following the share market collapse.

Rather than following up the concerns of the Treasury about rapid increases in the net borrowing of public financial enterprise, in effect the Treasurer has been encouraging the reverse. Maybe we will never know what deals were done by Premier Burke before his hasty retreat to the Emerald Isle. But to what extent did the large investment in Rothwells by the Catholic schools system cause the Premier to mount a rescue package for the firm? Is it correct that the authorities of those schools had invested money to obtain high interest rates and that they would have been unable to provide funds for education had not the State Government Insurance Office intervened? What were all the background negotiations to the State Government Insurance Office's bail-out of the Bell Group? The Treasury knows, the Treasurer knows, but he does not tell us. In circumstances where his own Department, the Treasury, is rightly warning us of the borrowings these authorities had entered into and the damage this could do, they start to use taxpayers' funds to prop up corporations, without any explanation of the macro-economic impact or the reasons for this.

After all, the Commonwealth Government is responsible for the overall financial stability of the Australian economy. The net borrowing of the States is a key issue in terms of macro-economic management. The Treasurer should drag himself away from compiling lists of insulting epithets and address that responsibility. I ask the Treasurer what action he will be undertaking at the Premiers Conference in four weeks time on the matter I have raised-the matter of borrowings and the operation of State authorities? Will he be using the Government's influence, through the Loan Council, to get an even fuller disclosure from the States on the nature and extent of the build-up of debt by public financial enterprises? He certainly has a duty so to do. The Government must use the Premiers Conference and the mini-Budget to set the course to strengthen our economy against an uncertain future.

I indicated at the outset of my remarks that the Opposition would not be opposing the Bills before the House. I have, however, moved an amendment which will be seconded by the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Aldred). I urge honourable members to support that amendment when it is put to the vote in due course.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened carefully to the speech of the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) and to the terms of his amendment to Appropriation Bill (No. 3). I am amazed that two people can look at the same economy and come to such different conclusions. At one point the honourable member talked about perceived improvements in the economy. He said that they were perceived and just that-not real. That was a quite astonishing assertion on his part. I want to go through the four points he made in his amendment and examine them with a bit more care because none of them stand up to careful analysis.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point claims that Commonwealth Government outlays, at over a quarter of Australia's gross domestic product (GDP), are funded by the highest taxing government in Australia's post-war history. The first thing to be said about that is that during the last five years-the term of the present Government-taxation has been almost constant as a proportion of GDP. The Budget Papers that were tabled by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) when he produced the Budget last year show that for each of the last four years revenue, as a proportion of GDP, has been almost constant. In 1984-85 taxation revenue was 24.4 per cent of GDP; in 1985-86 it was 24.3 per cent; in 1986-87 it was 24.8 per cent and in 1987-88 it was 24.5 per cent. During those four years it was almost constant. It fell slightly in the last year. Quite clearly, that is the direction in which the Government is moving.

The question we must ask is: How does that compare with the situation in other countries? If one looks at the proportion of tax revenues to national income in other countries, one sees that Australia is one of the lowest tax countries in the Western world. I attended a lecture given by an economist from Sweden in Parliament House on Tuesday night. He said that in his country tax represented 55 per cent of GDP, which is more than twice the level in Australia. It is certainly true that Sweden is one of the higher tax countries in the world, but virtually every other major Western country collects tax at a higher rate than in Australia. We are one of the lowest tax countries in the world. The Opposition continually misrepresents that. It likes to pretend that this Government is a high taxing government. That is factually not true; nor is it true that in the last few years tax revenue has risen.

The Opposition also neglects the question of what the appropriate level of tax should be. It simply asserts that tax should be lower and that would be a good thing. We would all like to pay less tax; there is no debate about that. The Opposition neglects the issue of the appropriate level of tax relative to the level of service that the community wants. It neglects to assess whether we should be increasing, for example, the level of investment in this country. One of the most important issues for the longer term growth of the economy and the structural adjustment that the previous speaker-the honourable member for Kooyong-asserted he wants and which this Government wants, must be the level of investment in which the Government and the private sector are involved.

One of our real problems is that during the last couple of decades there has been a tendency for the level of public investment to decline with consequences for both the rate of economic growth in a direct sense and the capacity for economic growth in the future. It is absolutely essential that we build up the level of public investment in our roads, railways, ports, airports, water supply, sewerage, electricity, gas, power, telecommunications and so on. All of those networks of services that are essential to the efficient and effective functioning of the economy require that we increase investment in them and maintain them effectively. The real danger of a further rundown in public revenue is that we will not be able to afford to maintain them. Some of those networks are becoming quite old. We must build up the level of maintenance expenditure on them.

The second point the honourable member for Kooyong made concerns what he called incentive sapping taxes such as fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax. That was surprisingly inconsistent with his alleged concern about poverty. To relieve poverty, it is essential to tax every form of income. What the Government has done, by introducing fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax, is to introduce, to the tax system, equitably and fairly, parts of income that were not subject to tax previously and which were used by the wealthy in the community to avoid paying tax. Unless fringe benefits are brought into the tax system, people have an incentive to receive a larger proportion of their personal income in forms of income that are not taxable; in other words in-kind-in cars, holidays, private school fees for their children and so on. Those are all ways of allowing people to avoid paying tax on their income. The Government has not only made an equitable change to the tax system but also it has closed off some of the most rampant abuses of the system by closing off tax minimisation loopholes through the fringe benefits tax.

I am quite sure that those in the community who understand what the fringe benefits tax means would support that change overwhelmingly. It is a fair change. It is a change of which we can be proud because it makes Australia a fairer society. It is one of the symbols of this Government's commitment to fairness and equity. The same is true about the capital gains tax. They are taxes which all of us who are concerned about fairness, equity and justice can support wholeheartedly. They do nothing to discourage incentive because they were accompanied by some reductions in marginal tax rates which probably contributed in some way to increasing the incentive to earn income. Whether that is true or not, taxes within the rates that are used in Australia have not been shown in careful analyses to have much impact on incentives. What provides the incentive is the overall level of income, the overall level of work satisfaction and the overall level of other kinds of satisfaction that people can get from the work they do.

The honourable member's third point concerns national productivity. He complained that national productivity is not growing fast enough. National productivity depends on a whole host of factors such as the level of investment, the level of education of the work force and the level of employment growth. Nowhere among the honourable member's comments did I notice any remark about this Government's remarkable achievement in stimulating the growth of employment. In fact, it must be regarded as the Government's most important achievement that during the last five years there has been a growth in the total level of employment of over one million jobs. Employment in Australia has grown during the last five years faster than in any other Western country. That is a remarkable achievement. Greater employment growth must be regarded by anyone concerned about the well-being of the whole community, about the elimination of poverty and about equity as the central criterion for good government in this country.

When this Government came to office it promised to aim to create half a million jobs in its first three years. It overachieved that target and now, within five years, it has doubled it, which is superb. That trend is continuing at present. We have seen in the figures released only a week ago that employment has continued to grow during the early months of 1988. The statistics for the month of March show that during February there was a seasonally adjusted growth in employment of 49,000 jobs. That means that nearly 50,000 new jobs were created during February. So at present we are seeing a very rapid spurt in employment growth, maintaining the trend which has been evident throughout the last five years. The effect of that, of course, is substantially to reduce unemployment.

When Labor won office in March 1983, unemployment represented about 10.2 per cent of the work force. It is now down to 7.4 per cent of the work force. It was at that level in both February and March. That shows that the level is being maintained. That represents a very striking fall of 3 per cent over the five years of this Government. It would be lovely if that figure were higher, but during that time the participation rate has also risen. If the participation rate-the proportion of the population that is in employment or wants to work-were now at the level it was at when Labor won government in March 1983, the unemployment rate would be less than 5 per cent. We have had not only a rapid employment growth but also an increase in the proportion of people who want employment, and that has made it more difficult to reduce the level of unemployment. But, despite that growth in the participation rate, there has been a real improvement in unemployment, which is now down to 7.4 per cent, well below the level of many of our trading partners.

The fourth point made by the honourable member was about what he called the incentive to invest. He did not make this point with much conviction. Of course, he could not make it with much conviction because the fact of the matter is that during the last couple of years the level of investment has been growing rapidly. There are good reasons for that, which I will come to in a minute. The most recent figures show that in 1986-87 private new capital expenditure went up by about 19 per cent. Even if we take account of the implicit price deflator for private capital expenditure, 11 per cent in that year, that still represents an 8 per cent real increase in new capital expenditure by the private sector last year. Similarly, in 1987-88 private new capital expenditure is expected to rise by about 8 per cent-significantly faster than the expected price deflator for this year.

The most recent statistics also include estimates for 1988-89. The Australian Bureau of Statistics, with its rigorous forecasting methods, estimates that the private sector will invest 15 per cent more than in the current financial year. That is a very striking expected improvement at a time when there is quite a deal of uncertainty. The impact of the crash on Wall Street and the associated decline in stock market prices throughout the Western world has created a lot of uncertainty and insecurity amongst investors. Investment stagnated everywhere for some months while people tried to sort out the consequences of that decline in share prices. But in Australia, despite that insecurity and uncertainty, we are seeing a renewed spurt in investment. I think that is an impressive affirmation of confidence in the State of the economy.

The honourable member for Kooyong tried to say that the employers did not know what they were talking about when the Confederation of Australian Industry announced in a statement yesterday that Australia was going through a process of recovery. Surely employers are likely to have a fairly clear idea of the direction in which the economy is moving. Yesterday's statement is a striking affirmation that people who have no particular reason for wanting to support a Labor government ideologically recognise that we are well advanced in the process of recovery that everyone is seeking. It is not just the figures I have mentioned so far which confirm that. Any of the statistics which have come out recently show the same picture. This has not happened accidentally.

One of the central points that I would like to emphasise is that Government policy has been one of the principal influences on the steady improvement that we are now experiencing. A letter published on Tuesday in the Australian Financial Review showed an estimate by two academics that the prices and incomes accord had led to an increase in employment of about 8 per cent. These scholars estimated that so far the accord alone had been the factor leading to the creation of 600,000 of the new jobs created. That is a very striking direct result of one of the Government's central policies.

Similarly, as a direct result of the accord, industrial disputation has fallen to about one-third of the level it was at when we came to government. In 1982 the number of working days lost was just under four million. In 1986-87 the number of working days lost was 1.2 million, less than one-third of the level in the year before Labor won government. That must also be directly due to the greater level of consultation and the commitment to equitable policies and effective dispute settling procedures under the prices and incomes accord, which has been part of this Government's policies.

One could go on for quite a while with these kinds of statistics but I would like in conclusion to mention two or three others which are very powerful indicators of the fact that the economy is going through a stage of steady recovery. One of the most important of those indicators is the growth in housing construction. The Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry released on the day before Easter its estimates for the March quarter and for the next financial year. They showed that housing commencements were likely to rise from fewer than 120,000 last year to about 150,000 in the coming year. That is a very striking growth, and it is not accidental. It is due partly to the fall in interest rates in the last 18 months. Housing interest rates have fallen from about 15 1/2 per cent 18 months ago to less than 14 per cent now. Other interest rates have fallen even more strikingly. The interest rates charged by banks to businesses for loans for over $100,000-the indicator rates-have fallen from 18 per cent in June 1986 to 13.5 per cent in February 1988. That is a major fall which is contributing not only to housing construction but also to investment.

I believe I have given enough of an indication to demonstrate clearly that the economy is firmly launched on a process of rapid recovery, and that the picture painted by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong, is misleading and improperly gloomy. There is no basis at all for the points he makes in his amendment. I hope that the House will reject the amendment and support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure that I rise to speak in this debate and to second the amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). Appropriation Bills present a financial picture of a government's policies. They are a window, if you like, through which we can view both the strengths and weaknesses of each individual policy objective. As I look through that particular window I can see many weaknesses. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, in his comments, addressed in particular many of the economic weaknesses that are evident in these Bills. However, I wish to deal with one weakness in particular, that is, the defence of Australia-or more correctly, the lack of defence that Australia now has. That fact is further demonstrated through what is provided in these appropriation Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: Currently we are witnessing a major shift in the balance of power on our western flank. It is a shift that the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) in his recent address to the Centre for Indian Ocean Regional Studies in Western Australia described as merely `intriguing'. Of course, the shift is the result of the huge Indian military expansion in the region. The Indian naval build-up is expected to eventually see India with a fleet of more than 100 ships of which approximately half will be of 3,000 tons or more in size. This shift in the balance of power is nothing less than dramatic. Considering the fact that this shift so adversely affects Australia, I should have expected a responsible government to reflect some concern through these appropriation Bills that are now before the House. This irresponsible Labor Government, however, does nothing.

My concern about the Indian naval build-up are well known. Conversely, the lack of concern by the Minister for Defence is also well known. However, as the Minister should by now be aware, I am not alone in my concerns. Mr James Webb, the recently resigned United States Secretary of the Navy has also said that India's expansion is a major problem for Australia.

I have previously spoken in this place about the two, and soon to be three, carrier battle group formations comprising the centrepiece of India's naval power projection. I have spoken of India's recent acquisition of a Soviet nuclear submarine, and on 22 March this year in this chamber I revealed the fact that India's follow-on Soviet nuclear submarines were to be of the advanced Victor III hunter-killer class. In earlier debates I have briefly referred to the substantial increase in India's surface combatants. However, to illustrate the fact that this Government has still not grasped the significance of the current developments on our western flank, as evidenced in these appropriation Bills, I will elaborate a little further.

Current Indian naval philosophy believes that sea control, one of its objectives, can be applied by carefully amassed and concentrated forces, embodying massive firepower. This has prompted the Indian Navy to acquire surface combatants with considerable firepower. The core elements of this force are the Soviet supplied Kresta II class guided missile cruisers and the Kashin II class guided missile destroyers, which the Indians will soon have in abundant numbers. These powerful warships are supplemented by the Indian-built Godavari class frigates and will be further supplemented by the new Project-15 class of 12 indigenously-built frigates. These new frigates will be in the 5,000-ton range, and will carry two Sea King anti-submarine warfare helicopters, surface-to-surface missiles, and possibly an MK-6 dual purpose gun mount.

This imposing selection from the Indians' inventory is apparently only enough to make our Defence Minister `intrigued'. Perhaps I can help him fully recognise the enormity of the problem now confronting us. I have recently been informed that the latest Soviet warship on the Indian shopping list is the Sovremenny class destroyer-a warship recognised for its enormous firepower. Indeed, such is the firepower of these ships that they are considered extremely useful and effective for supporting assault landings, which directly leads me to my next point.

At the same time as I learned about India's interest in the Sovremenny class destroyers, India's rumoured interest in acquiring a substantial force of blue water assault landing craft was confirmed. Although it is not widely known, India purchased, from the United Kingdom, the plans for the Sir Lancelot class tank landing ship which it has since modified to meet its own particular needs. The result thus far of its acquisition of these plans has been the commissioning of the 5,000 ton Magyar in late 1987. I have it on very good authority that a class of at least eight of these tank landing ships will be produced. Eight of these vessels will give the Indians the extraordinary capacity to carry out a two-tank brigade lift-a feat beyond the capability of any other littoral state including Australia.

Concurrently the Indian aircraft carrier Vikrant, currently undergoing a refit, is expected to emerge as a multi-role carrier. The decision to make Vikrant a multi-role carrier, rather than a dedicated aircraft carrier in the true sense, fits into India's offensive power projection concept, which also encompasses the current program of building tank landing ships and its keen interest in acquiring Sovremenny class destroyers. As a multi-role carrier the task of the Vikrant will be to act as a specialised anti-submarine warfare vessel and commando carrier. Twenty MK-42B Sea King helicopters have been ordered from Britain and these will be fully convertible to commando use. The refitted Vikrant will then give the Indians the capability to project their power through a coordinated sea and air assault from its seaborne resources, thus embracing the total concept of modern sea assault doctrine.
The Defence Minister, in his recent address to the Centre for Indian Ocean Regional Studies, to which I referred earlier, said:
India's overall strategic context justifies a substantial navy.
He went on to say:
Any development of a force projection capability in our general region must interest us.

When the Minister said this on 28 March he must have been aware, through intelligence sources, that India is close to achieving the ability to launch all-arms military operations throughout the entire Indian Ocean region. When India's naval expansion is complete she will have the ability to lift two tank brigades and a commando brigade, and be able to provide her assault forces with massive fire-support from warships such as the Sovremenny class destroyers and air support from her Harrier aircraft operating from aircraft carriers. The greatest obstacle facing the movement of such a force over great distances is the threat posed by enemy surface, sub-surface, and air elements. However, even this obstacle has been overcome through India's balanced carrier battle groups and submarines. In essence, the Indians will shortly have the ability to intervene anywhere in the Indian Ocean region. This is a stunning reality that the Defence Minister will ultimately will have to recognise fully.

By comparison, Australia has one heavy lift amphibious ship, HMAS Tobruk, and three or four operational heavy landing craft, each able to carry two to three main battle tanks. Our mediocre amphibious capability is restricted to a one-squadron tank lift. We have no equivalent of a commando carrier to carry the infantry, artillery and other fighting arms required for an assault landing, and no naval airpower afloat to protect an amphibious force. The people of Australia really need to ask just how interested and concerned the Minister for Defence is. The disturbing developments on our western flank are certainly not reflected in these Appropriation Bills now before the House.

The Minister's assurance that this Government `will watch diplomatic developments carefully' obviously implies that this Government does not believe India's military developments need watching. Despite the enormity of India's build-up there are some people who continually attempt to justify it, whilst at the same time saying that it in no way affects adversely Australia's future security. The Hawke Labor Government is doing just that, and that is reflected in these Bills. The most oft used justification for India's build-up is the need to counter the naval threats from its traditional enemies, Pakistan and China, together with the possible threats posed by the activities of extra-regional navies. In looking at this we need to ask whether the threat to the environment justifies such a naval expansion? Furthermore, will the expansion help to mitigate the threat? A reasoned and logical examination of the facts leads to a negative response on both questions.

The situation in the Indian Ocean is certainly more complex than it has ever been before. Nevertheless, the military containment of India is not an objective pursued by any extra-regional navy operating in the Indian Ocean. Apart from Pakistan, no littoral power poses any naval threat of consequence to India, and that includes Australia. However, upon detailed analysis of Pakistan's minor naval resources it becomes quite apparent that it is beyond the capability of Pakistan to launch a sustained strategic naval offensive against India. Furthermore, Pakistan's naval vessels, which do not match the size and firepower of India's vessels, are maintained to keep India off balance and for their limited nuisance value as much as anything.

The increased size of the Chinese navy and its ability strategically to project its naval power have been grossly overestimated. The most recent of the Navy's ships of the People's Liberation Army (PLA) could not be described as matching some of the older western and Soviet ships now afloat. Technologically the Chinese still have a great deal of ground to make up. Senior defence analysts believe that the PLA Navy will slowly continue to increase in size and, at best, will become a regional naval power able to deal with Soviet surface ships in the South China Sea.

As is evident from what I have already said, there is a further pressing and disturbing development in India's military expansion that the Minister for Defence needs to address, namely India's ability to carry out opposed troop landings throughout the region. Madam Speaker, it would be remarkable if anybody were to suggest seriously that this beach assault capability is required to combat the threats India believes it faces from either Pakistan or China. The threats from these two countries have been and continue to be territorial in nature, requiring significant land and air forces rather than navies for their resolution. In any future confrontations India is geographically positioned to take full advantage of the hundreds of miles of land borders it shares with its traditional enemies. The large casualties that are inherent in beach assault operations make it ludicrous to suggest that India would need to launch such an operation against either country, but particularly China.

These Bills we are debating give the Hawke Labor Government the opportunity to demonstrate its commitment to the defence of Australia. It has failed to use this opportunity. It has sidestepped reality and failed to acknowledge that the domination of our western approaches by a single power has serious ramifications for Australia's future trade and security. These Appropriation Bills give little hope to Australians, who quite rightly expect their government to provide them with a credible defence against all possible future aggressors.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free Mr R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to join the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1987-88, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1987-88 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1987-88 and to take the opportunity to comment on some recent political events. We on the Government side could hardly be ignorant of a certain amount of glee in the Opposition ranks following the results of the by-elections in Adelaide and Port Adelaide and the results of the State election in New South Wales. I am pleased to note that that delight is rather less than universal on the Opposition side following the Groom result, which certainly brought a degree of gloom to the National Party ranks.

SPEECH.PARA: Before the New South Wales election I was at some pains, both in this place and outside, to remind the people of that State just what life was like under a Liberal Party government. I attempted to remind people in my electorate and outside it of the ramshackle state of public transport in New South Wales before 1976, the neglected health services and the run down education system in that State under the Liberals. It is a matter of great regret that the people of New South Wales now have the opportunity to relearn what life is like under the State Liberal Government.

I am a charitable person and I admit that it is early days. It is only 26 days since that election took place, but already there have been a number of major blunders. This afternoon I would like to cover in some detail the first four blunders of the new New South Wales Minister for Education, Dr Terry Metherell. In under a month in office Dr Metherell has been responsible for the dismissal of the incoming head of the New South Wales Department of Education for a shameful attack on the Chifley University, for the introduction of standardised testing in New South Wales public schools, and for the demolition of the New South Wales schools accreditation system. These four blunders, these four acts of ideological buffoonery from this naive Minister, have all been achieved in his first 26 days. He is a Minister whose only previous claim on public attention was his activities as a nocturnal skinny-dipper in the New South Wales parliamentary swimming pool.

Let me turn to blunder No. 1, which concerned the dismissal of the New South Wales Director-General of Education. It was on March 28 that we learnt through the pages of the Sydney Morning Herald that the Greiner Government had sacked the heads of Education and Housing and demoted two other departmental heads in a shake-out of Labor appointees. The Sydney Morning Herald tells us:

One of those removed, Dr Gregor Ramsey, had not yet started in his $83,000-a-year post as NSW Director-General of Education. He had been recruited from the Federal education sphere to replace Mr Bob Winder who retires this month.
The Sydney Morning Herald continues:
In an interview with the Herald yesterday, the Minister for Education, Dr Metherell, said he had sacked Dr Ramsey on Friday in person. His position had been `abolished' and would be re-advertised.
As to Dr Ramsey's contractual rights, Dr Metherell said he did not know how this would work out. Those details were to be negotiated between Dr Ramsey and the Secretary of the Premier's Department.

We learnt a little more of the circumstances of this matter two days later following an expression of support for Dr Ramsey from the Federal Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins). I quote again from the Sydney Morning Herald:
The Federal education Minister, Mr Dawkins, yesterday accused the Greiner Government of political motivation in sacking the incoming head of the NSW Department of Education.
In a rare ministerial statement of support for a public servant, Mr Dawkins defended Dr Gregor Ramsey's record as a member of the now defunct Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission.

Dr Ramsey was a first rate officer with distinguished service in both Canberra and South Australia, Mr Dawkins said. `He was a dedicated officer with no political prejudice who would serve any minister with imagination and loyalty.'
Mr Dawkins also indicated that it would be the duty of the Greiner Government to compensate Dr Ramsey, who lost out on a seven-year contract worth $83,000 a year.
Dr Ramsey was to become Director-General of Education . . . He was appointed late last year by the former Labor Minister for Education, Mr Cavalier.
The article continues:
Federal Government sources said Dr Ramsey met the New South Wales Minister for Education . . . where Dr Metherell told him he was ``looking forward to working with him''.

On the Friday he was sacked. I concur fully with the Dawkins review. I know Dr Ramsey to be a distinguished educationalist, a skilled administrator, a man of wide experience and a person of great vision. His appointment would have been excellent but he was guilty of two sins in the eyes of Dr Metherell: first, he was appointed by a Labor government; and, secondly, he was an outside appointment to that position-the first ever person to be appointed to that position from outside the Department. We may never know what happened between the Tuesday when the new Minister told Dr Ramsey that he was looking forward to working with him and the Friday when he was given his marching orders. But it is my firm belief that Dr Metherell was well and truly Yes Ministered over that period; in other words, he was got at by the mandarins of the New South Wales Education Department who simply would not tolerate an outside appointment.

Let me turn now to blunder No. 2: the Minister's attacks on the Chifley University college. I learnt yesterday that Chifley University college in my electorate, a college on which work is proceeding, is no longer to be Chifley college. Again I will quote from a newspaper report. In yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald it is stated:

The Minister for Education, Dr Metherell, said last night the western university would not be called Chifley for much longer. It was not appropriate for universities to be named after ``long-dead Labor politicians, especially those with no connection with western Sydney''.
He said Ben Chifley's only association with the university had been that he ``used to drive a steam train down the main western line past the Werrington site''.

That Minister clearly is not aware of Chifley's long association with the west and is ignorant of the fact that for some years Chifley represented in this Parliament part of that region. He is also ignorant of Chifley's achievements in education, of his work in expanding opportunities in education and training in the postwar years, of his work in establishing university scholarships and of his achievement in founding the Australian National University. It was those achievements, together with Chifley's lifelong belief of providing greater opportunities for underprivileged and disadvantaged people, that led to the original decision to honour his memory in this way. Chifley's crime, at least in Dr Metherell's eyes, is that he was a Labor politician.

In passing, I point out that with the establishment of the University of Technology in Sydney we now have 21 universities in Australia. Of those 21, 12 have geographical names and only nine are named after people. Of those nine people, two were explorers, two were colonial governors, one was a soldier, one was an academic and only three were politicians or statesmen. The difference, as someone suggested during the week, is that statesmen have the unanswerable advantage of being dead. However, of those 12 people only three were Australian born and of the three statesmen after whom universities are named-Deakin, Griffith and Curtin-only one came from the Labor side of politics. It is surely not unreasonable to expect, given those details, that the Chifley name should be retained for Australia's newest university.

But we learnt today that a further decision from Dr Metherell's office may place the entire future of the development of that university in doubt, because in a release which appeared in the newspaper this morning Dr Metherell said that development of the university is now all in the melting pot pending the release of the Commonwealth's White Paper. I regard this as part of a massive confidence trick on the part of the Minister because the concept of the university college is entirely consistent with the thrust of the Green Paper as the university was to commence as part of a larger institution and, in addition, its capacity to grow rapidly in its own right as well as the avenues for amalgamation in the future clearly made it an ideal candidate for development under the discussion papers in the Green Paper. So I consider his decision to place this project effectively on hold for four months and the reasons for doing that basically as a dishonest decision.

I will turn now to blunder No. 3: the introduction of standardised, multiple choice tests of basic skills at the end of years 3, 6 and 10 for all students in New South Wales state schools. The aim, according to the new Minister, is to test the system. The Minister, in making this decision, clearly ignored the fact that standardised tests were already in use in New South Wales public schools and they have been for many years. They have been used in a proper way to identify problems and to direct remedial assistance to the most important people in the system-the children. The idea of mass testing to monitor the system is both repugnant and wasteful. The New South Wales Teachers Federation has correctly pointed out that such tests could prove counterproductive by beginning and reinforcing a cycle of failure for those children who do not succeed.

Apparently, the mass testing campaign will not apply in the independent school sector. I wonder whether this decision is based on the assumption that standards are uniformly high across the entire spectrum of independent schools or on the belief that what happens in those schools is of no concern to the New South Wales Government. If the former is true, the assumption of a uniformly high standard across that spectrum is not necessarily true. If the latter is true, the New South Wales Government, both as the registering authority and as a major source of funds, has a responsibility to be interested in the performance of the independent school sector.

I turn now to Metherell blunder No. 4: the reintroduction of the School Certificate and the demolition of the new Certificate of Secondary Education in New South Wales. The old School Certificate, the end of year 10 award, has been tried for over 20 years and is found to be wanting. Students, teachers, parents and employers all wanted changes. The attitude of those working in schools is well illustrated by a letter to the Sydney Morning Herald of 8 April, written Sister Caroline Ryan of the Holy Cross College Woollahra. Sister Ryan says:
Some of the education commitments of the new Minister for Education . . . give cause for concern.

First, the education rationale for reintroducing the School Certificate seems neither convincing nor clear. It is assumed that the various factors contributing to the recent decision to abolish it are still operative. Why then this apparently politically opportunistic reaction?

This is not to imply that the Certificate of Secondary Education which was to have replaced the School Certificate is the best and most comprehensive means of recognising a student's attainment. No practical evaluation could be made in that regard as the CSE remains yet untried.

It seems obvious that the sundry and complex issues underlying the subject of credentialling students in such a way as to be congruent with their performance and also properly informative about an individual school's curriculum need more extensive exposure and discerning discussion. I believe such a need is urgent.
Such a need certainly is urgent but I doubt that that need will be satisfied under the current New South Wales Minister for Education.

TALK.START.PARA: —Be a bit generous; he has not been there for very long.

—He has not been there for very long but he has already made a number of major blunders. That new Certificate of Secondary Education to which I referred-that is, the one the Minister has just abolished-was designed to incorporate those positive features of the old School Certificate and designed after extensive consultation with parents, teachers and employers. That certificate would have provided a comprehensive profile of student achievement from year 9 through to year 12 and not just a basic grade in year 10, as provided by the School Certificate that the Minister is to bring back. That profile of achievement would have provided, as well as a certificate, school reports, references, records of work achievement, skills profiles, merit certificates and records of sporting achievements over the entire four years. That Certificate of Secondary Education was just what employers in New South Wales wanted. Let me quote briefly from a report entitled Documents for School Leavers: What Employers Want. This is a report of a joint research project conducted by the New South Wales Department of Education and the New South Wales Employers Education Consortium, published in December 1987. The summary and conclusions section of that report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The main message to emerge from the study is that employers are eager to have a great deal of detailed and comprehensive documentation to aid them in employment selection processes. School leavers may enhance their employment chances if they present a folio of documents which contains both external certificates and school reports and which includes a variety of other documents such as evidence of work experience, involvement in school life as well as in extra-curricular activities. A particularly useful folio would contain both school produced and student assembled materials.

That is from the report of the joint research project which consulted employers and asked them what they wanted in documents from schools to assist them in interviewing prospective employees. Given the dissatisfaction with the old School Certificate and the care and the effort which have gone into designing its replacement, one wonders exactly what motivation Dr Metherell has to turn the clock back at such huge public expense. Those are the four major blunders from the new New South Wales Minister for Education in his first 26 days in office; that is, blunders at a rate somewhat better than one a week since he has held office. There are others on the way to which I could refer in greater detail. The same Minister apparently proposes to re-introduce corporal punishment in New South Wales schools, and apparently plans to abolish school zoning and throw school organisation in that state into chaos. But as that Minister has not introduced those two matters, but has simply threatened to do so, I will leave debate on them until another time. I conclude by saying that on the record of his performance thus far, and on the record of the blunders that he has made to this point, it seems clear to me that Dr Metherell's career as a Minister will be even shorter and more inglorious than that of the Government of which he is a member.
Debate (on motion by Mr Adermann) adjourned.
