That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PUNCH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have recently returned from a short visit to Norfolk Island; my visit was for five days from Saturday 3 April to Thursday 7 April. Norfolk Island is a self-governing Commonwealth territory, situated 1,676 kilometres north-east of Sydney. The island is governed by an elected assembly of nine, the assembly having a range of legislative powers as specified in the Norfolk Island Act 1979. During my visit to the island I had detailed talks with the Norfolk Island Legislative Assembly on a number of important issues of concern to both the Commonwealth and the Norfolk Island Government. During these talks I signed three important memorandums of understanding with the Norfolk Island Government. The topics of the memorandums of understanding relate to education, the HMS Sirius artefacts, until recently a matter of some public dispute, and the island's water assurance scheme. The memorandum of understanding on education recognises the Norfolk Island Government's responsibility for education and records the intention to maintain educational standards comparable with those in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Following the signing of the memorandum of understanding by the two governments on the HMS Sirius artefacts, Norfolk Island will now remain the home of these artefacts. The significance of this memorandum of understanding should not be understated. There is no doubting the historical and cultural significance of HMS Sirius, the flagship of the first fleet, to all Australians. The focus of this memorandum of understanding is on a management plan, which both governments agree is essential to preserve and protect the relics. The memorandum of understanding is designed to set the parameters within which the management plan will be prepared. The matters dealt with by the management plan will include: resolution proposals to borrow items from the Sirius collection for display outside Norfolk Island; methods of storage, preservation and conservation of the artefacts; and access to the artefacts for research purposes.

The finalisation and signing of the memorandum of understanding on the Norfolk Island water assurance scheme will ensure the construction of a new sewerage scheme in the Burnt Pine-Middlegate area of the island. The importance of this scheme for the island's future is highlighted by the simple fact that there is no reticulated water on Norfolk Island. The island's population relies entirely on ground water and tank water. The building of the sewerage scheme will significantly help assure the quality of the island's groundwater. At the same time this will reduce any threat posed to health and the island's significant tourism industry. Under this memorandum of understanding the Commonwealth will provide a total of $2m, which will be in addition to approximately $1m to be contributed by the Norfolk Island Government. The Norfolk Island Government will bear the cost of all future stages of the water assurance scheme.

Talks were also held between myself and the Norfolk Island Government and officials of the Commonwealth who accompanied me to Norfolk Island about the further transfer of power from the Commonwealth to the island's elected Government. While the Commonwealth recognises the spirit of the arrangements made between it and the Norfolk Island community in 1979, the Commonwealth continues to have identifiable interests in Norfolk Island. It must be in this light that all further proposals for transfer of authority to the Norfolk Island Government be examined. My trip to Norfolk Island was my first as Minister responsible for the Commonwealth's external territories. I went to the island with an open mind, to listen to the concerns of the island's population and to learn about the unique problems that face the people of one of Australia's more remote external territories. I believe my talks with the Norfolk Island Government to have been both productive and worthwhile. I look forward to a continuing close working relationship with the Norfolk Island community and its elected representatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this report and also to the statement of the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch) I should say that within the time that he has entered into this portfolio he has certainly applied himself to many of the problems that were evident at the time that I first entered into my shadow responsibilities. Only as recently as last month, on another piece of legislation before this House on the transfer of power to appoint auditors, we had a discussion on what was then a most pressing problem, that is the relics from the flagship HMS Sirius. From reading what that memorandum of understanding applies itself to, if the Assembly itself has agreed to these terms I believe the memorandum lays down a reasonable working foundation. These relics are within their proper place in history, within the island itself, but they are also made available for purposes of research and viewing at other places by agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it was a shame that there was grave conflict and suspicions on all sides that those relics and artefacts may have been housed in Sydney and not on the island itself. It is important, particularly in our bicentennial year, that this matter has been straightened out because nobody should underestimate the importance of Norfolk Island to Australia and also the importance of the flagship HMS Sirius. I understand from listening to the Minister that his negotiations in every respect were taken at full and frank value. I feel sure he comes back with the good will of the Norfolk Islanders. That should be pleasing to all Australians. I have read the report tabled yesterday. It is not easy to compare the finances of a settlement or territory with fewer than 2,000 inhabitants who claim to be Norfolk Islanders with what we have here, but I think the goodwill that we have been able to extend has been justified in the manner in which they have been able to keep their accounts and in other aspects of management of the island. The Minister said that discussions were held about the transfer of some other powers. At some later time he might give me an indication of what these powers are and when the transfer might be proceeded with.

I welcome the visit to the island by the Minister. I suggest that he also has other external responsibilities. I suggest to him that it is important that he visit Christmas Island because, as he understands, the problems associated with Norfolk Island are insignificant compared with the problems on Christmas Island at the moment. I would welcome a fuller debate in this House following such a visit by the Minister, which I think is imperative, because that territory is sitting right at the crossroads at the moment. Its future depends so much on the goodwill of this Government and this Parliament. I understand that the Minister is looking at the projects of the tenderers for the reopening of the mine on Christmas Island. From the representations that have been made to me, I know how imperative it is that there be no delay in making a decision on that. We do not have any truck whatsoever with any particular tenderer but I think it is important for the future of the island and the maintenance of a little bit of stability for the work force that a decision be made. In the meantime I thank the Minister for the opportunity of speaking in this debate. I am sure that his visit to Norfolk Island was in the interests of not only his Government but also the Parliament and the people of Australia.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Territories)

DEBATE.TITLE: DEVELOPMENT OF NEW UTILITY HELICOPTER FACILITIES, QUEENSLAND

PROCTEXT.PARA: Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Development of new utility helicopter facilities, phase 2, at RAAF Base, Townsville and Oakey army airfield, Queensland.

The proposed work is for the provision of operational, support and administrative facilities at Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) Base Townsville and Oakey Army airfield in support of the second phase of delivery of the new Sikorsky Black Hawk helicopters. On 2 April 1987 the House approved the construction of new facilities at the RAAF base at Townsville to accommodate a squadron to be equipped with the first 14 of the Black Hawk helicopters. Since that time the purchase of 25 additional helicopters has been approved. These helicopters will be based at RAAF base Townsville and Oakey Army airfield. Over a five-year period the Army is to assume control of these battlefield helicopters. To this end the Army will raise a unit known as 5th Aviation Regiment at RAAF base Townsville which will provide tactical air support to combat elements of the operational deployment force. Once the Black Hawk helicopters become operational the Army proposes to conduct Black Hawk conversion training and Loadmaster courses at the School of Army Aviation at Oakey Army airfield 150 kilometres west of Brisbane.

At both bases there is a need to upgrade and extend existing operational, technical and administrative facilities to accommodate both new personnel and equipment, and the relocation of existing operational units. The proposed work at RAAF base Townsville includes site preparation and upgrading of engineering services; the extension and overlay on an existing aircraft apron and provision of a link to the existing taxiway; and works associated with the army's new 5th Aviation Regiment and with the relocation of the existing No. 35 Squadron consisting of the extension and upgrading of buildings for headquarters facilities, flightline facilities, technical support and store facilities and the extension of hangars to accommodate Black Hawk helicopters and relocated Caribou aircraft and workshop facilities. There will be new single living-in accommodation for 248 persons, an extension of existing medical-dental facility and associated security measures. In addition a total of 135 additional married quarters are required to house the increased married personnel associated with the basing of the 5th Aviation Regiment at RAAF base Townsville. Action is being taken separately by the Defence Housing Authority for the provision of these houses.

The estimated cost of the proposal at RAAF base Townsville is $19.2m at October 1987 prices. This cost is broken down into $13.1m for the operational facilities and $6.1m for the new live-in accommodation. No expenditure is anticipated this financial year. Subject to parliamentary approval, it is intended that construction commence in mid-1988 with a construction time of approximately 18 months. The proposed construction program is based on a completion date commensurate with the second phase of delivery of the Black Hawk helicopters, as advised by the Department of Defence.

The proposed work at Oakey Army airfield includes site preparation and upgrading of engineering services; extension of the aircraft apron and provision of a new link taxiway; extension and upgrading of buildings to provide maintenance, technical support and storage facilities; extensions of buildings for aircrew training facilities and maintenance training facilities; an enclosed parking shelter for six Black Hawk helicopters and associated security measures.

The existing living-in and married quarters accommodation at Oakey Army airfield is adequate for the increased personnel associated with the introduction of the Black Hawk helicopters. The estimated cost of the proposal at Oakey Army airfield is $5m at October 1987 prices. No expenditure is anticipated this financial year. Subject to parliamentary approval, we intend that construction commence in mid-1988 with a construction time of approximately 14 months. This will allow the transfer of Black Hawk conversion training to Oakey in early 1990. Design and documentation of the facilities at both bases will be undertaken by my Department's construction group, with some assistance from private consultants. Construction will be contracted to private enterprise. During construction the on-site work forces are expected to peak at 100 at Townsville and 40 at Oakey by the end of 1988. I table selected plans of the proposed work and I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes this reference to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works of the $24m work proposal for the upgrading of facilities at the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) base at Townsville and the Oakey Army airfield, both of which are located in Queensland. The works are required to provide accommodation and other facilities for the 39 Black Hawk helicopters which are in the process of being purchased by the Australian Government. These helicopters, which are troop carrying, will be a welcome addition to our Defence Force resources. Certainly, the Opposition agrees that there is a need at both bases to upgrade and extend the existing operational, technical and administrative facilities to accommodate both new personnel and equipment and for the relocation of existing operational units. The estimated cost of the proposal for the RAAF base at Townsville is, as the Minister outlined, $19.2m. It is work that is intended to be undertaken later this year. The proposed work at the Oakey Army airfield, which the Minister has outlined in detail, is estimated to cost about $5m and that work is proposed to start also later this year. It is intended that the construction phase will be completed in about 14 months.

SPEECH.PARA: We are delighted that this proposal has at long last come to fruition and is being referred to the Standing Committee on Public Works for its review and-we hope-approval. We are pleased that the construction will be contracted out to the private sector. We support the proposed reference as a much needed upgrading of Defence Force facilities.

We have seen a dramatic run-down in Defence Force personnel under this Government. The level of wastage is of very great concern, not only to the Opposition but also to the community. It is clear that more must be done to give our defence personnel appropriate facilities and equipment as one way of assisting in lifting morale. Defence as a portfolio has had a very low priority under this Government. The defence needs of this country are great and they have had a rough time under the Australian Labor Party. It is pleasing to see that, if only as a result of a few by-elections, at long last the Government has been shocked into taking action to provide decent facilities and resources for our Defence Force. It is action that should have been taken some time ago. We are pleased that at last it has been taken and we support this reference.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) on this reference to the Standing Committee on Public Works. This is an important reference which represents stage 2 of the redevelopment of the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) base Garbutt, costing in excess of $50m. The Government has now approved the purchase of 39 Black Hawk helicopters to be based at RAAF base Townsville and at Oakey Army airfield. I expect the Government to proceed with the purchase of a total fleet of 75 Black Hawk helicopters to provide tactical air support to certain combat elements of the Australian Army.

SPEECH.PARA: The requirement for tactical air support for the combat elements of the Operational Deployment Force (ODF) based at Lavarack Barracks at Townsville is fundamental to the fighting capacity. The Australian Army's Operational Deployment Force must have the capacity for rapid deployment of its combat elements and the acquisition of Black Hawk helicopters will ensure that the ODF in particular will have the capacity to deploy rapidly to areas where it may be required. That, in itself, is a major advance. That was not the case during the period of the Liberal-National Government from 1975 to March 1983. Also I recall that in the early 1970s the Commander of the First Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment, was almost obliged to walk his battalion to a deployed area. That was as a result of 23 years of Liberal-National Party rule. But times have changed. The Hawke Government has now ordered 39 Black Hawks, which are state of the art helicopters, to provide tactical air mobility for the combat element of the ODF. That is a most important advance in the effectiveness of the Operational Deployment Force. As I said previously, I hope the Government will proceed with the acquisition of a total fleet of 75 Black Hawk helicopters. I am sure that will be welcomed by every member of the Australian Defence Force.
Every time I stand in this place I join with other speakers on this side in announcing new Defence Force projects.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would want to!
—But there is no Defence Force left.

—Even now the Government is announcing a massive increase in new accommodation facilities at RAAF base Garbutt for 240 persons of all ranks. For the first time, these people will have air-conditioned, sound-proofed new accommodation facilities which they can enjoy. Enormous sums of money have already been spent at RAAF base Townsville for upgrading the existing accommodation facilities for ranks. In addition to the new single live-in accommodation for nearly 250 people of all ranks, the Minister has also announced that there will be 135 additional married quarters to provide accommodation for married personnel of the Fifth Aviation Regiment which is being raised to operate the Black Hawk helicopters at Townsville. Thirty-five homes are being purchased at present in Townsville and contracts will be let in the not too distant future for more than 60 homes. These works announced by the Minister-stage 1 and stage 2 of the redevelopment of RAAF base Garbutt-will have an important impact on the economy of Townsville and Thuringowa.

SPEECH.PARA: I record the appreciation of the building industry in my electorate for these initiatives announced by the Government. Even the works just announced by the Minister will provide job opportunities for at least 100 people. I see the upgrading of RAAF base Garbutt as just one step in the expansion of the Australian Defence Force so that it will be able to succeed in any battle it may have to undertake in the defence of Australia. For it to gain the capacity of self-reliance, money is required to be spent on capital equipment programs.

It is very disheartening to hear Opposition spokespersons criticise this Government for its policy of re-equipping the Australian Defence Force with modern weapon systems. The point was made earlier in interjections by the shadow Minister for Defence, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), and the shadow Minister for Housing and Public Administration, the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter), that there has been wastage from the Defence Force. That is a matter of concern to this Government and also to the Australian community. The Australian Government is doing something to arrest the high separation rates from the Australian Defence Force. That is in stark contrast to the total inactivity in this regard during the years of the Fraser Government when there was wastage of 10 to 12 per cent from the three Services in the Australian Defence Force. The interjections from the two shadow Ministers are at best playful humour and at worst smack of hypocrisy.

Finally, I assure the House and the people listening to my speech that this Government is determined to provide this country with the best possible Australian Defence Force, an Australian Defence Force that can fight and an Australian Defence Force that will win any battle it undertakes. The steps announced by the Minister are some of many to achieve that objective. I hope that the Opposition spokespersons will join with the Government and support the Australian defence forces and not try to demoralise them by putting them in the position of questioning the direction of our Defence Force policy, which is designed to protect Australia and its people. They should join with this Government in supporting the Australian Defence Force and supporting the expansion of our capacity to defend this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —A couple of the remarks made by the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) cannot pass unchallenged. Nobody is deploring the money that is being spent on capital works and in particular we support the motion before the House. But it is absolutely ridiculous to talk about Opposition spokesmen making casual remarks about defence wastage. The Government spends all this money on equipment, but what does it have at the end of the day when there are no experienced, trained and qualified men and women to man the equipment? That is the situation that the Government is facing now. Month by month there are record enormous wastage rates in the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF), the Royal Australian Navy (RAN) and the Army. Month by month we bring up this subject and month by month the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) entirely neglects to do anything about it at all.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Herbert raised the subject and I want to respond. The neglect of Defence Force personnel is of enormous concern to me and to all members on this side of the House. The honourable member, who takes a genuine interest in defence matters, would know better than anyone else what members of the defence forces think about what the Government is doing in relation to looking after personnel. The Government does not care. The Minister has never given any indication that he is concerned about their conditions, their pay or their life in the defence forces. He has shuffled these matters off to an assistant Minister, who has now gone back into her box, having tried to make a bit of a splash initially. She realises that she knows nothing about this subject, that she does not have any authority to do anything and that the Minister for Defence will not take an interest anyway.

Let us have no more criticism of the Opposition raising this subject. We will continue to raise the subject in this House until something is done about it. Honourable members opposite are in government and they are the ones who have to address the subject. Time and time again we have put forward things that have to be done but our suggestions have always been completely ignored. The Government will not have the problem in two years, but I would hope that in that two years the Government will go some way towards fixing it.

On a subject related to the facilities for the Black Hawk helicopters, I take the opportunity to remind the House that tomorrow sees the withdrawal of the Mirage squadron from Butterworth. The squadron has represented Australia in the most exemplary fashion during the 20 years that it has been at Butterworth. It was deployed under a previous Government's forward defence policy at a time when I served in Malaya during the emergency. It would appear that, under the present Government, that forward defence policy is now somewhat discredited.

The previous speaker, the honourable member for Herbert, mentioned that we now have Black Hawk helicopters, but the reality is they cannot be moved around the country. The Government has a defensive attitude to our defence posture. It says, `We will sit in Australia; we will let them come and get us if they want to; we will do nothing to develop a capacity to protect the offshore territories, to protect our sea routes or to assist our friends or allies, should the need arise'. Mr Deputy Speaker, you know very well, as do other members in the House, that last year we offered to assist if necessary in evacuating our nationals in Fiji. We could have put troops on some RAN frigates, we could have got them into the area, but we then had no capacity whatsoever to transport a reasonable number of troops or any helicopters to that area. So, while we agree that the Black Hawk helicopters--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—It has been a wide-ranging debate.
—I know it has been fairly wide ranging, but I would ask the honourable member for McPherson to get back to the subject matter quickly.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I bow to your decision. Nevertheless, I would like to finish the sentence. While we are very much in favour of the acquisition of the Black Hawk helicopters, the fact is that we still do not have any capacity to transport them or troops around this country or overseas if necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say something about Hawker de Havilland Ltd, the company that was given the job of assembling the Black Hawk helicopters. I visited the company the other day and I was very impressed with the job it was doing. It is true that the assembly program has fallen behind somewhat. The first helicopter is due off the assembly line about now. The problems have been mainly caused not by Hawker de Havilland but by the supply system from the United States of America. I just want to put on record my appreciation of the job it is doing, not only with the new Black Hawk helicopters but with the new PC9 training aircraft to be used in the RAAF. The project for this excellent aircraft is right on time and, again, Hawker de Havilland is doing a great job.

The problem with the PC9 is that it is not wanted by the RAAF. The aircraft was selected by the Minister against all professional advice. A third aircraft is now to be brought into the RAAF training system, and this complicates all of the problems that the RAAF has at present. So we have a third aircraft for which pilots will have to be trained. The RAAF will have all the problems of maintaining a third aircraft as well as eventually having to select an initial trainer at one end and a jet trainer at the other because it has a new aircraft in the middle. This was an appalling decision. We are now desperately trying to find out what to do with this excellent aircraft.

A lot of the facilities proposed will go to the Army Aviation Centre at Oakey. I was at the centre recently and I can only say, without apportioning any blame, that it is high time the centre had these facilities, not only for the Black Hawk helicopters but also to support its other operations. The centre has temporary buildings which, I presume, were moved to the base 20 years ago. The Army Aviation Corps has done a magnificent job at the centre, working under difficult conditions. I am delighted to see it has been given these extra facilities, which will give Army aviation an enormous boost.

The centre also has pilot problems-not so much in getting pilots to fly the Black Hawk helicopters but in trying to find qualified flying instructors for the whole range of programs that it runs. This is the same problem that is faced by the RAAF. The Defence Force cannot retain its pilots because, while conditions of service under this Government may not have deteriorated in comparison with civilian conditions, they have stayed still. As a result, the disparity between the two has increased. Until the Government addresses that fundamental problem and upgrades the conditions of service under which our service men and women operate, the record resignations will continue.

Some of the other facilities are going to Townsville where they are needed. The honourable member for Herbert said, with some degree of pride, that new houses were to be built in Townsville. Where would the honourable member expect those people to live? If the Government is to acquire new helicopters and new facilities, what does it expect to do with the people? It is essential that, when a new facility is put in place, people are given decent married quarters in which to live. It is not a matter of great pride to say, `The Government is building all these married quarters'. It is part and parcel of the deal.

Over recent years there has been some dispute as to whether these helicopters should remain with the RAAF. The decision was made to transfer them to the Army. I believe that that was the right decision. There are people who live in hope that when there is a change of government the decision will be reversed. I say now, as I have said before, that that decision will not be reversed by us and that the helicopters, when they are eventually transferred, will remain with the Army. I pay tribute to the RAAF for the job it is doing in handing over the helicopters to the Army in this long hand-over program. It places a strain on the RAAF at a time when it faces enormous personnel problems. It gets nothing out of it, so to speak, in the end for this service. But it has taken on that task and is doing it well and it should be complimented.

The honourable member for Herbert said that the measure will give the Australian Defence Force (ADF) increased mobility in Townsville. It will certainly give it increased mobility around Townsville. I do not think that anyone would seriously think that the ADF is likely to be deployed only around Townsville. I ask the honourable member for Herbert and other honourable members opposite: How are we to transport these helicopters to the places they are needed? The honourable member referred to the time when I commanded a battalion in Townsville. I have probably told him the story myself. We were short of transport in those days, but at least-if my memory serves me correctly-we still had the Sydney and the Melbourne. At least we had some capacity to project power into our region and the capacity to move helicopters and troops. Where is that capacity now? We have new helicopters, which are very welcome, but no ability whatsoever to move them. The Government has done only half the job.

Another matter which is relative to the motion moved by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) is the future of 7 Stores Depot in Toowoomba. 7 Stores Depot is a RAAF depot, but it provides a lot of the backup stores for the Aviation Centre at Oakey. There is some fear and trepidation in Toowoomba that that stores depot will be closed down. Of course, people would lose their jobs if that were to happen. I was there recently and I could see no reason at all why the stores depot should be closed down. It seems to be doing an excellent job. The introduction of these Black Hawk helicopters will add something like another 20,000 items to the inventory, many of which will be required to go to Oakey as well as Amberley. The Government is required to make a very early announcement on what is to happen to the 7 Stores Depot.

We on this side of the House wish this project well, and all the associated projects, such as the Black Hawk project, which is very necessary. We wish it much better luck than some of the recent projects undertaken by the Government. The Australian submarine construction program has struck a brick wall in Adelaide. One of the reasons is that Ministers in this place will not support the Australian Submarine Corporation agreement. In Question Time today the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) said that he would not support the three-union agreement; that it was a matter for the parties. Senator Button was not so equivocal. He knows where he stands. The Minister for Defence has had the guts to say that there is a three-union agreement and he stands by it. When real pressure is put on this project the Minister for Industrial Relations goes to water. He went to Adelaide yesterday and all he was required to say in answer to the question today was, `We stick by the agreement that we supported and helped to negotiate'. He did not do so. Again, the unions will probably win. Let us make no mistake about it; if the unions win, that project will go offshore because it will be the only way to get it done. We hope that the Black Hawk project will not go down the same track as the submarine project. Because the Government is trying to force consortiums to marry up with designs selected by the Government, the Anzac frigate project is falling apart. ANI pulled out of the AWS consortium the other day. At Williamstown, the AMEC consortium is struggling with the unions and trying to negotiate the same deal that was negotiated in Adelaide with three unions on site.

The proposals I have just tabled relate to a proposed alteration to the Excise Tariff Act 1921. Excise Tariff Proposals No. 3 (1988) formally place before Parliament, as required by law, a tariff alteration made by a notice published in the Gazette during the recent recess. PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Duncan, for Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUNCAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Education Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to provide, under an interim arrangement, lump sum superannuation benefits for Commonwealth civilian employees and employees of Commonwealth authorities and bodies who are eligible employees under the Superannuation Act 1976; and Commonwealth civilian employees and employees of certain Commonwealth authorities and bodies who have no employer sponsored superannuation. The major features of the interim arrangement are that it is an interim arrangement; it provides a benefit for those without any superannuation cover and an additional benefit for those with superannuation cover-existing superannuation arrangements are not affected by the interim arrangement; employees do not contribute; it is an `unfunded' arrangement-rather than pay contributions on an ongoing basis, employers will be required to pay benefits as they fall due; and the basis for calculation of the benefits simulates the benefits that would have accrued had the employer paid contributions to an invested accumulation fund earning interest. The rate of interest provided for in the calculation of the benefit is the long term bond rate at the start of each year.

The Conciliation and Arbitration Commission's June 1986 national wage case decision made provision for employers and unions to negotiate new and/or additional superannuation agreements costing up to 3 per cent of ordinary time wages. The Government agreed to a 3 per cent overall superannuation benefit for Commonwealth sector employees generally, with 1.5 per cent commencing on 1 January 1988 and the balance no later than 1 January 1989. This Bill gives effect to that agreement from 1 January 1988.

For the benefit of honourable members I highlight some of the major features of the arrangement. Time constraints and the Government's general review of superannuation precluded finalisation of the longer term form of the benefits for the 325,000 eligible employees under the Superannuation Act 1976 or the 75,000 Commonwealth sector employees with no superannuation cover. Accordingly, the Bill sets up an interim arrangement which can be operated without the need for a central administrator. The arrangement is a simple one because the administration of the arrangement, including record keeping and calculation of the benefit, has been devolved to each employer in respect of its employees. The simplicity of the arrangement and its factual nature have obviated the need for review powers. Longer term arrangements for the benefit will be negotiated in 1988. The Government has already announced a comprehensive review of the Commonwealth superannuation scheme later this year. The benefit under the interim arrangement may be subsumed within any revised scheme.

The Bill provides that certain regulations can be made with effect from 1 January 1988. One such power relates to the inclusion of certain groups of persons in the interim arrangement from 1 January 1988. This power has been provided so that authorities which provide superannuation benefits other than under the Commonwealth superannuation scheme can choose to cover their employees, particularly employees with no superannuation cover, under the interim arrangement until their separate longer term arrangements are finalised.

Another power is to exclude certain groups of persons from the interim arrangement with effect from 1 January 1988. This power has been provided so that, where longer term arrangements with effect from 1 January 1988 are put in place for certain groups of employees initially covered by the interim arrangement, those groups can be excluded from the interim arrangement so that they do not become entitled to double benefits. The Government recognised that a substantial number of employees in the Commonwealth sector have no superannuation cover. In the main, these workers are at the lower end of the income scale. The Government considered it appropriate to arrange the benefit in a way that would favour these employees. The arrangement provides proportionately higher benefits for lower income earners than for higher income earners. This arrangement is a major step in the provision of superannuation for all Commonwealth employees.

Lump sum benefits are payable on termination of employment with the Commonwealth or an authority that is an approved authority for the purpose of the Superannuation Act 1976. In accordance with the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner's requirements applicable to 3 per cent benefits provided under prescribed agreements or awards made by Commonwealth or State industrial authorities. Benefits of $500 or more are required to be preserved in the approved fund of the person's choice until genuine retirement from the work force. Honourable members will note that this Bill refers to, or uses, the provisions of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987 in several places. Where a benefit is less than $500, the benefit can be paid to the individual. The person has the option to roll over all or part of the benefit to an approved preservation fund.

There is a qualifying period of three months service, or its equivalent in part time service, for eligibility for the benefit. If employers had to process very small amounts, the costs of doing so could exceed the amount of the benefit. Continuous service prior to 1 January 1988 counts towards this qualifying period but not for benefits. Once eligibility for the benefit is established, the calculation of the benefit takes into account service from 1 January 1988 or the date of commencement of service, whichever is the later.

Finally, I would like to advise honourable members of the financial implications of the 3 per cent superannuation benefit. The Bill provides for regulations to specify the basis for calculation of the benefits in 1989 and later years. The rates of employer contribution used in the calculation will result in an overall cost of 3 per cent of salaries for superannuation purposes in those years. The interim arrangement implies an accruing financial commitment by employers of 1.5 per cent of the salaries for superannuation purposes of the persons covered in calendar year 1988 and 3 per cent in subsequent years. In 1987-88 prices. This accruing liability would be $130.5m in 1988 and $271m in later years. The benefits under the interim arrangement will not, however, be met by employers paying contributions to a fund or to a central body. Rather each employer will be required to finance only the benefits that become payable. This would be much less than the full accruing costs. Assuming the interim arrangement will continue unchanged. Costs, in 1987-88 prices, are estimated to be $1.6m in 1987-88, $14.4m in 1988-89, $37.5m in 1989-90 and $62.8m in 1990-91. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Braithwaite) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Duncan, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUNCAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Education Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The main purpose of this Bill is to establish the Civil Aviation Authority. The Government's decision to proceed with establishment of a Civil Aviation Authority was announced in a statement to the Parliament on 7 October 1987 by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans). Senator Evans indicated at that time that it was hoped to see the Authority operational within 12 months or so, after appropriate consultation on implementation details and parliamentary approval of the enabling legislation. A commencement date for the Authority of 1 July 1988 has been adopted for planning purposes.

The proposed Authority will have operational responsibility for air traffic control, flight advisory services, communications, navigation and surveillance systems, and rescue and fire fighting services at airports. The Authority will provide an aeronautical information service and will offer consultancy and management services in its fields of expertise. It will also be responsible for organising aviation search and rescue services. It is the Government's view, in the light of experience, that these functions would now be better performed through a statutory authority than by a department of state as in the past.

It has been the policy of successive governments that the costs of services provided in support of the conduct of civil aviation operations should be recovered from the aviation industry. Given this policy, the body providing these services should be so structured as to make it adequately responsive to the industry's requirements and to industry's capacity and willingness to meet associated costs. Growth in both the volume and complexity of air traffic in recent years places increased demand on the air traffic services system in Australia. At the same time there is a need to reduce national transport infrastructure costs through increased productivity. Advances in technology, particularly in the communications field, offer the potential to develop a more cost efficient air traffic services system, but this will entail a major program of investment in modernisation and upgrading of the present system. Planning and implementation of such a program can be better undertaken through a self-funding body which directly recovers the costs of services it provides than through a budget dependent department.

In the light of these considerations, it is proposed that the Civil Aviation Authority be established as a statutory body, under the control of a nine-member board appointed by the Minister. A group of this size will allow for an appropriate range and balance of expertise in the composition of the board's membership. There is provision for the board to establish advisory committees to assist it, which widens the scope to draw upon persons with experience in business, aviation operations, air safety regulation, trade unions, academia and other appropriate fields, for planning and conduct of the Authority's functions.

Close consideration has been given to whether safety standard setting and day to day regulatory control should become the responsibility of the Authority, or whether these functions should remain with a department. A wide range of interested parties has been consulted and views differ on this important question. As Senator Evans indicated in his statement of 7 October 1987, there is considered to be strong logic in the view that the task of regulating aviation safety must be regarded as an integrated system in which all elements are coordinated to achieve maximum reliability and effectiveness.

The operation of air traffic control and the flight advisory service is as much a part of safety regulation as the regulation of an aircraft and its crew. The two areas complement each other. Safety regulation has been successfully combined with the operation of the airways system for many years in Australia and in a number of other countries. In the United Kingdom, that country's Civil Aviation Authority has very successfully combined the two functions, although they were initially separated into two different agencies. The United Kingdom decision to bring the functions into a Civil Aviation Authority was taken after a formal review, and on the basis that the setting of standards, regulatory control and the day to day operation of the airways system should be under single control in the interests of efficiency and effectiveness, because of the close interrelationship involved.

A concern expressed from a number of quarters is that safety standards may become degraded if the body responsible for safety regulation is required to operate on a commercial basis and is therefore subject to cost pressures. The commercial nature of the Authority needs to be clearly understood. It will be the Government's requirement that the Authority adopt a businesslike approach to its affairs, including the ongoing pursuit of cost efficiency and productivity improvement. The Authority will operate commercially in this sense. However, it will not, because of the nature of its activities, be subject to the full range of pressures that apply to business enterprises operating in a free market situation. Whilst the legitimacy of the concern that safety considerations should not take second place to commercial aspects of the Authority's operations is accepted, the latter aspects should be kept in a proper perspective.

It also needs to be recognised that aviation safety is not solely dependent on regulation by Government authority. Australia's outstanding aviation safety record was not achieved, nor could it be maintained, by official fiat alone. Departmental officers have made a splendid contribution to our aviation safety in the context of integrated safety and operational functions, and the Government is confident they will continue to do so in the new Authority. Their past contribution was essential, but was not sufficient in itself.

Australia's airlines and other operators have made their own essential contribution to the safety record by their professionalism and concern for safety in air operations. This concern is deeply ingrained in our aviation industry and that situation would not be expected to change readily. Nonetheless, the Government recognises the concern that various parties have voiced and has decided to adopt a number of measures in recognition of this. It is the Government's intention that the Australian Civil Aviation Authority will be required to give primacy to safety considerations over commercial ones. The Bill reflects this intention and makes provision for the Minister to give broad directions in relation to the Authority's safety regulatory role to ensure that occurs.

As previously announced, the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation will remain in the Department of Transport and Communications, separate from the Civil Aviation Authority, and directly responsible to the Minister. This will ensure that the authority responsible for improving and enforcing safety standards will not be left to be the judge of its own performance. The Bureau's resources will be augmented to equip it to advise the Minister on safety trends and on any emerging issues on which the giving of directions to the Authority may be desirable. The Bureau will not duplicate the safety regulatory functions of the Authority, but will have the role of independently assessing and advising the Minister on trends and significant broad issues relating to maintenance of appropriate safety standards.

As a direct measure to meet concern about commercial influences adversely impacting on safety regulation, it is the Government's intention that costs of standard setting and ensuring compliance with standards be funded from the Budget and that the Authority perform these functions under contract. Finally, the legislative framework for safety regulation will remain under the control of the Minister.

It is considered that these various measures will provide adequate safeguards in relation to the concerns expressed about the possible adverse influence of commercial factors on the maintenance of our outstanding safety record. The function of aviation security also will remain with the Department of Transport and Communications. However, this Bill does provide for the Authority to participate in arrangements to prevent or deal with hijacking or other acts of unlawful interference with civil aviation.

Where appropriate, the Bill reflects the Government's announced guidelines in regard to legislation for statutory authorities. In broad terms these guidelines seek to provide a proper balance between the need to remove detailed controls over the operations of statutory authorities on the one hand, and accountability to the Government on the other. With this in mind the general thrust of this legislation is directed towards involving the Government in long term planning and strategic decisions of the Authority.

As previously mentioned, the operation of the Authority will be the responsibility of a nine-member board which includes a Chairperson, Deputy Chairperson and the Chief Executive Officer of the Authority. Staffing of the new Authority will involve transferring officers of the Department of Transport and Communications who currently carry out tasks associated with the functions being transferred. These officers, about 7,000 in number, will continue to be employed under the Public Service Act. Their terms and conditions of employment will therefore remain unchanged upon transfer. The headquarters of the Authority will be located in Canberra. As a significant number of officers who will be transferring to the Authority are already employed at this location there would be major costs entailed in locating the headquarters elsewhere in Australia. This is not considered to be justified.

Turning to the broad question of financial arrangements which will apply to the Authority: the Bill provides that the Authority will be required to draw up a corporate plan for a three-year period, defining its objectives and identifying its strategies and policies to achieve these objectives. The Authority will be required also to prepare a financial plan covering the same period. Both plans are to be submitted to the Minister. Provision is made in the Bill for the Minister to give directions to the Authority to vary certain parameters in the financial plan. In this event, the direction must be made public, in common with other directions given to the Authority under provisions of the Bill.

As already mentioned, costs of setting safety standards and ensuring compliance with those standards will be met from the Budget. Costs of implementing the standards are to be met by the aviation industry through charges levied by the Authority. However, full recovery of implementation costs is to be phased in over a period of seven years, and during that period the shortfall in revenue will also be met from the Budget. The Government will continue to meet the costs of search and rescue. So far as the airways system and the rescue and fire fighting service are concerned, the Authority will be expected to recover fully associated costs from the industry. Provision is made in the Bill for the Authority to determine charges for its services, but proposals for such determinations will be subject to disapproval by the Minister within 60 days of receipt.

Provision has been made in the Bill for the transfer of assets to enable the Authority to perform its functions. A valuation for these will be determined, together with the loan and capital components, by the Government. The Authority will be required to earn a reasonable return on its assets and to pay to the Commonwealth a reasonable dividend. It will be able to borrow to meet its capital requirements, if necessary with a Commonwealth guarantee. Subject to certain safeguards, the Authority will be able to participate in partnerships and companies and will be given freedom to provide consultancy and management services, particularly to overseas aeronautical bodies seeking to use the expertise or services of the Authority.

The legislation provides for regulations to be made, consistent with this Bill. The existing air Navigation Regulations will need to be divided into regulations under the Air Navigation Act, which has been amended to allow the transfer of functions to the new Authority, and into regulations under the Civil Aviation Bill. This is an interim step. As previously announced, the Government has established a task force to review the legislative framework for safety regulation. The outcome of this review may well have implications for the regulations under the Air Navigation Act, and, more importantly, for the regulations under this Bill. Steps can then be taken to revise the regulations to the extent necessary. However, this important revision should not be allowed to delay the establishment of the Civil Aviation Authority.
Financial Impact Statement

There are no implications in the Bill for additional costs in the public sector. To the extent that greater efficiency is achieved, costs can be expected to reduce in real terms over time. To the extent that the Authority funds its capital investment program from commercial borrowings rather than Budget appropriations, the financial impact of the Bill will be to reduce Commonwealth budgetary outlays.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Beale) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Duncan, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUNCAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Education Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Much of the Bill is devoted to improving the requirements of the taxation law that deal with the registration of tax agents. A substantial number of other matters are also dealt with. The income tax law will be amended as foreshadowed to restrict eligibility for the special depreciation allowance available for Australian trading ships.

Tax deductability is being extended to payments made under cash bidding systems for off-shore petroleum exploration permits and production licences. Practical aspects of application of the foreign tax credit system are being modified and some unintended consequences and technical deficiencies corrected.

Anti-avoidance provisions of the thin capitalisation rules are to be strengthened to ensure that foreign investments in Australia maintain an appropriate balance between debt and equity funding. The Bill also includes changes to the taxing arrangements for certain educational allowances and similar allowances and for the carer's pension.
Registration of Tax Agents

In the interests of both the revenue and the taxpayer, it is important that a person who charges a fee for conducting income tax business on behalf of a taxpayer has the appropriate knowledge of Australian income tax law and of accounting principles and is otherwise a fit and proper person to be entrusted with the responsibility of conducting a person's income tax business. The income tax law, therefore, prohibits a person, partnership or company from charging a fee for preparing an income tax return, or transacting any business relating to income tax matters unless registered as a tax agent, or exempted from registration, by a tax agents board. The provisions that deal with the registration of tax agents have remained relatively unchanged since they were first enacted in 1943.

The amendments being made by this Bill will substantially modernise and improve the provisions and give effect to a number of recommendations made by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Administrative Review Council, accounting firms and the boards themselves. Interested parties were consulted as part of the drafting process and have indicated general support for the proposed measures.

In response to criticisms of the existing provisions by the Administration Review Council and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Bill will extend the range of decisions of a tax agents board in respect of which a person may make application to the Tribunal for review. In order to achieve a desirable degree of uniformity between decisions of the six State boards and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Bill will provide a more objective test as to who is a suitable person to be registered as a tax agent or as a nominee, and will enable eligibility criteria to be prescribed.

Also in response to a recommendation of the Tribunal, the Bill will give the boards a general power to suspend the registration of a tax agent in addition to the power of cancellation. Under the existing law, company tax agents may register suitably qualified employees as nominees. Partnership tax agents, however, may only register partners as nominees while sole practitioners may not register nominees at all. Partnership and sole practitioner tax agents have expressed concern that the inability to register employees as nominees increases the workload of the principals and can impede the timely lodgment of returns. To overcome these concerns partnership and individual tax agents are to be permitted to register suitably qualified employees as nominees. The ability of a company to gain registration as a tax agent on the basis of the qualifications of an employee-who need not be a director, shareholder or even a full time employee of the company-has led to exploitation by some unqualified persons.

The Bill will therefore tighten the rules for registration as a company tax agent by requiring that shares carrying at least 25 per cent of the voting power in a company applying for registration be beneficially owned by a director or directors having the necessary qualifications to be registered as a tax agent. The $2 fee payable on lodgment of an application for registration as a tax agent or as a nominee of a registered tax agent has not changed since 1943 and is considerably less than those payable for broadly comparable professional registrations. The Bill will increase the fee to $80. The existing law requires tax agents to notify the Board by 1 April each year if they wish to remain registered.

The Bill replaces the annual notification requirement with a requirement to re-register each three years and introduce a re-registration fee of $40 plus $5 per nominee. The fees have been set at a level that will recover the costs of operating the tax agents boards and will be subject to regular review.

Other amendments will provide for continuation of a partnership registration following a change in constitution of the partnership, effect changes in the composition of the tax agents boards and make a number of minor technical and drafting amendments to the tax agents provisions.
Special Depreciation for Australian Trading Ships

As announced on 2 April 1987, the Government has decided to restrict eligibility for the special accelerated depreciation concession for Australian trading ships to new ships that qualify under the Federal Government's scheme of capital grants for such ships. Under the Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987 the Federal Government pays a taxable grant of 7 per cent of the purchase price of eligible Australian trading ships as an incentive to ship operators to purchase modern, efficient and technologically advanced ships.

The Bill will restrict eligibility for special depreciation, from 22 December 1986-the date from which the capital grants scheme applies-to new ships that both satisfy the present eligibility criteria in the income tax law and qualify for a capital grant. Ships which do not qualify for a grant but which, on 22 December 1986, had either been given a manning notice under section 57am of the Income Tax Assessment Act or were the subject of an application for such a notice, will continue to be eligible for special depreciation. The amendments will also disallow the special depreciation if a grant becomes repayable.
Cash Bids

As announced on 17 September 1986, the Bill will extend the scope of the income tax deductions allowable for cash bids paid for the grant of off-shore petroleum exploration permits. The income tax law was amended in 1987 to allow deductions for cash bids paid to the Commonwealth, under its cash bidding system introduced in 1985, for the grant of petroleum exploration permits in highly prospective areas. This ensured that Australian companies would not be disadvantaged in the bidding process in competing with foreign companies that could obtain deductions under their domestic law for their cash bids. When the amendments were introduced, the Government announced that it also proposed further amendments of the income tax law to allow deductions under other Commonwealth, State and Northern Territory cash bidding systems.

The amendments to be made by this Bill will allow deductions for cash bids paid for exploration permits and production licences under the Commonwealth's combined cash bidding and work program system which was included in the off-shore petroleum legislation in 1967. This combined cash bidding-work program system can apply only in circumstances where a previous production licence is discontinued or where a production licence application for a permit is not finalised and the relevant permit lapses.

Deductibility will also be extended to cash bids paid under State and Northern Territory cash bidding systems that are equivalent to the Commonwealth's systems. Consistent with the existing tax law, cash bid payments will be written off on a straight line basis over the lesser of 10 years or the life of the producing field to which the permit or licence relates.

Write-off for cash bids will commence in the income year in which a production licence is first acquired in respect of the relevant permit area or at the time cash bid payments are made, whichever is the later. This should not have any cost to revenue over the next three years and revenue effects beyond that are dependent on when production licences are granted under cash bidding arrangements. The amendments will apply in respect of cash bids paid on or after 15 January 1986, the date of the original announcement to allow tax deductibility for cash bids paid under the Commonwealth cash bidding system introduced in 1985.
Foreign Tax Credit System

Amendments are being made to the foreign tax credit provisions to modify the practical operation of the system in relation to creditable foreign taxes and the treatment of overseas employment income of Australian resident individuals.

The Bill will also correct some technical deficiencies in the law relating to the quarantining of foreign losses, the treatment of certain dividends as interest income as part of the interest quarantining measures, the amendment of credit determinations and the transfer of excess credits within wholly-owned company groups. Those amendments to the foreign tax credit system which are of a concessional nature are to apply from the commencement of the 1987-88 year of income. Other amendments will apply prospectively from the commencement of the 1988-89 year of income. The changes will have negligible effect on revenue in 1987-88 but may produce some unquantifiable revenue savings in subsequent years.
The Government has under consideration a number of other foreign tax credit matters which if requiring legislative action will be the subject of a further Bill.
Thin Capitalisation

The thin capitalisation rules applying to foreign investments in Australia are to be varied in two particular areas. An amendment to the definition of foreign debt in relation to partnerships and trusts will close off an avenue for avoidance otherwise available to overseas investors who are not themselves partners or beneficiaries. The amendment will ensure that these investors are subject to the rules.
The second amendment will modify the effect of an equity maintenance requirement that has a potentially broader application than intended.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —The redrafted provision will affect a much smaller group of investors than the present law.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the thin capitalisation rules the level of foreign equity in an Australian investment is generally measured annually. An equity maintenance requirement ensures that equity that is introduced in a year of income to comply with a debt-equity ratio rule is not removed in either of the two years of income following its introduction. Where the equity is prematurely removed the anti-avoidance measure treats that equity as if it had never been introduced. The present rule could apply wherever equity is removed, regardless of how long it has been in place.

For resident companies the modified rule will apply to shares introduced in a year of income to ensure that they are maintained for the two subsequent years of income. For other forms of foreign investment the equity maintenance rule will apply where the level of equity is increased in a year of income and will operate to ensure that that level is maintained for the two succeeding years of income. Where the newly introduced equity is not maintained for the required period a lower level of equity will be substituted in debt-equity ratio calculations and may be reflected in an adjustment to related deductions for interest payments. The amended provisions, which will operate from the commencement of the 1989 year of income, should have negligible impact on the revenue.
Educational Allowances

As part of the Government's strategy to increase young people's access to employment, education and training, the Government has made a number of changes over the past three years to rationalise and improve youth income support programs. One of the changes has been to the education assistance available under the Aboriginal secondary assistance scheme and the Aboriginal study assistance scheme to bring the assistance more into line with that provided under Austudy, the main Commonwealth scheme for community-wide educational assistance. Consistent with the taxation treatment of Austudy payments, this Bill will make taxable from 1 January 1988 payments for students aged 16 years or more under the Aboriginal secondary assistance scheme and payments under the Aboriginal study assistance scheme.

The Bill will also extend the availability of the beneficiary rebates to affected students for the 1988-89 and subsequent income years. The purpose of the beneficiary rebate is to ensure that persons wholly or mainly dependent on certain social security benefits or education allowances do not have to pay income tax. The availability of the beneficiary rebates is also being extended to formal training allowance recipients for the 1987-88 and subsequent income years. The changes relating to the Aboriginal study assistance scheme and the Aboriginal secondary assistance scheme are expected to result in a gain of $0.5m in a full year while the formal training allowance change is expected to cost $2.5m in 1988-89.
Carer's Pension

Before 1 February 1988 a carer's pension was payable to a relative of a severely handicapped age or invalid pensioner where the relative provided constant care and attention to the handicapped pensioner in the home of the relative and the pensioner. The pension was exempt from income tax where both the carer and the handicapped pensioner were below age pension age; if either were of age pension age, the carer's pension was taxable.

From 1 February, the carer's pension has also been available to a person caring for a severely handicapped age or invalid pensioner but who is not a relative. The effect has been to exempt the carer's pension from income tax where a person who is not a relative and is below age pension age cares for a handicapped pensioner of age pension age. As this is inconsistent with the treatment of the carer's pension when paid to a carer who is a relative, that particular exemption is to be removed, with effect from the date of enactment of the Bill. This will ensure that the tax treatment of the carer's pension is determined without regard to whether the carer is related to the person cared for. The revenue gain is expected to be negligible.
Technical Amendments

The Bill will also make a substantial number of minor technical amendments to the income tax law and certain other laws administered by the Commissioner of Taxation. These amendments will have no effect on revenue. An explanatory memorandum which comprehensively explains the measures contained in this Bill is being circulated for the information of honourable members. I present the explanatory memorandum and commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Ministers of State Amendment Bill 1988 is described in the explanatory memorandum in the following terms:

The memorandum goes on to say in the financial impact statement:
The combined effect of these changes is to increase the total sum paid in ministerial salaries by $65,000 this financial year.

Of course, Ministers are much more expensive to the Parliament than that. After a recent calculation, just taking account of their immediate office, not the services provided by the Department or even the cost of their travel, it is not unreasonable to say that the cost to the Parliament of a Minister is of the order of $500,000 per annum. Nevertheless, this in itself is not necessarily worthy of criticism.

I believe that the extra cost of Ministers is justified, provided of course that they are Ministers who are delivering on behalf of the community. I do not think that anybody in this place would deny that Ministers work hard. The main reason they are paid more than backbenchers is the responsibility they are given under the Westminster system. They have a responsibility for the activities of their department. When the Westminster system was operating correctly, many of them were called upon, or felt it incumbent upon them, to resign when departmental mess-ups occurred. They also swear to uphold the law and, in particular, the laws associated with their portfolio. They are expected at all times to inform the Parliament of activities within their department and to ensure that the information they give to the Parliament is truthful.

Yesterday I put two questions to one of these Ministers, the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), seeking information. The first question sought information as to his knowledge of the changed operating instructions of the Health Insurance Commission (HIC), better known as Medicare in common terminology. I asked him whether there was any inference or concern to him that the Health Insurance Commission, which was once known to be reasonably lax in the way it disseminated information regarding individuals associated with its operations, would have any effect on his future in this Parliament. I called upon him to restate his claimed innocence in regard to the matter of certain confidential information being published in certain newspapers on the advice to journalists from the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear).

The inference to which I was referring, the changed rules that now exist in the HIC, mean that doctors wishing to use the hot line and communicate with the HIC in a legal fashion, must now ring up, give their names and telephone numbers, provider numbers and any other identifying information that is requested, hang up the phone and wait to be rung back. The HIC now realises that its responsibilities are such that it must be able to establish beyond doubt that it is communicating with the person with whom the law allows it to communicate.

More importantly, of course, as my office discovered recently, when one phones Medicare on constituent matters asking any questions relating to the affairs of a constituent, the HIC will refuse to answer those questions. I give the example of what occurred in my office. We simply rang up on behalf of a constituent, to find out when the constituent might receive a cheque. We were told that under the new rules the HIC had decided it could not give us even that information. That is all, of course, because section 130 of the Act forbids the commission from providing anybody with information regarding the affairs of any individual. This is something that will no doubt be argued out in the near future when Mr Temby's report eventually arrives with the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). That was the second question I asked. I was pleased to receive, as he had promised, a phone call from the Attorney-General in which he advised me that the Director of Public Prosecutions has in fact received a report from the Federal Police, is processing it and proposes that next week he will be giving to the Attorney- General his advice on whether two members of this Parliament, namely the Minister and the honourable member for Canning have in fact breached the law in any way in regard to their responsibilities.

I want to recap quickly what that was all about. Back on 10 November 1987 articles appeared in a number of newspapers but particularly the Sydney Morning Herald. The information published had been provided by the honourable member for Canning in his role as Chairman of the national prices network. In fact that information included some of the following detail. It said that, for instance, a surgeon had conducted open heart surgery and charged $3,000 for that particular operation, when the Medicare fee was $1,050; that a dermatologist had charged $169 for a particular service, when the schedule fee was $22.50; and that an anaesthetist had charged $120 when in fact the schedule fee was $53.
