SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted that the division was resolved in such a sweeping manner, vindicating your ruling, Mr Deputy Speaker. I will do my best, in addressing the Ministers of State Amendment Bill, to remain relevant to the Bill at all stages. It is a most simple and logical piece of legislation which, notwithstanding the theatrics that have been displayed in this debate so far, actually has the support of both sides of the House. One of the most surprising elements to those who may be listening to this debate over the radio is that this debate is about a piece of legislation which is supported not merely by the Government but by the Opposition parties in this House. One would not think so from the way in which this debate has been conducted. It has been conducted in a way which can only bring some discredit on those of us who seek to place the proper running of this Parliament at the forefront of our thinking.

SPEECH.PARA: The provision which we are debating is a very simple one. It effects two things: firstly, it provides for the payment of salaries which follow the expansion of the Ministry from 27 to 30 members under the new organisational arrangements which were announced in the restructuring following the last Federal election and, secondly, it accommodates the Remuneration Tribunal's recommendations following recent adjustments through the remuneration process. Turning to the first point-that is, the accommodation of salaries for the expansion of the Ministry-the legislation is necessary because section 66 of the Constitution provides that ministerial salaries are to be provided by an Act of Parliament if they are to exceed the original provisions which were included in the constitutional framework in 1901. It is always the case now that arrangements to meet appropriations for ministerial salaries are so provided-that is, by specific statute.

When the Government was re-elected at the last general election, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) announced a very significant and sweeping reorganisation in ministerial responsibility. That arrangement made quite dramatic changes to the previous arrangement. In the past there was a large Ministry with each Minister conducting the administration of a specific and particular department. With the growth of administration and the increasing ambit of Commonwealth responsibilities over the years, it became clear to a number of governments, not merely the present Government, that there needed to be some mechanism for streamlining the process of government and making it more efficient. As a result, on the re-election of the Government, the Prime Minister put forward proposals, which have been accepted in the Parliament and implemented through an Act of Parliament, to restructure the arrangements.

Instead of having 27 separate portfolios there are now 16 portfolio areas which have been dubbed megaministries by the popular Press. Cabinet Ministers are responsible for one of 16 large portfolios. They are supported, in turn, by 14 non-Cabinet Ministers who are responsible for specific parts of the Cabinet Ministers' portfolios or assist in some part of their range of functions. That releases portfolio Ministers from detailed administrative work and permits them to focus on the strategic direction of the portfolio and its contribution to Government priorities. That is a very significant advance, particularly in areas where coordination at a macro-level is required. It permits greater efficiencies-not just in terms of cost saving, although cost savings which run in excess of $100m have been identified, but also in terms of simple decision making procedures.

A good area to instance in that respect would be the Department of Employment, Education and Training. In the past, the different functions of education, employment and training were held by different portfolio Ministers. Often that led to a lack of coordination in the design of programs. There was an overlapping of programs and a lack of sophistication in terms of response to the overall global difficulties which we as a government faced. Putting all those responsibilities under the one broad portfolio head, but giving assistance to the Cabinet Minister in his discharge of that responsibility by allowing him to draw on the support of another Minister-I suppose one could call him a junior Minister-has enabled there to be coordination, integration of planning and a sophistication of service delivery which has been undreamt of in the past. We are beginning to see the effectiveness of the process come through as the Government refines and streamlines its programs and develops a most sophisticated way of approaching the difficulties with which it has to cope. The arrangement removes overlap and duplication of functions and enhances ministerial control because it allows Ministers to deal with particular areas of their portfolio responsibility. Also, it gives the portfolio Minister, at the highest level, the time to look at the global priorities of his portfolio area.

It is true that, by increasing the number of Ministers from 27 to 30, there was a small increase in direct costs. It has been estimated that the figure for this financial year will be in the order of $1.1m. Two things need to be said about that. Indirect benefits are derived from that direct cost. In terms of indirect benefits, the estimated savings are about $105m in a full year. The evolution of this system will make for a more efficient, better coordinated and more streamlined administration. One might ask, if it has such obvious benefits, why it has not happened before. Perhaps the real reason is that in the past there has been a lack of courage in confronting what was thought to be a constitutional difficulty standing in the way of having junior Ministers and senior Ministers administering the same portfolio.

The uncertainty in that area arose because of an opinion given by Sir Garfield Barwick, QC, as he then was, in 1958 when he advised the then Government that `in the nature of things . . . the office of administering a Department is a single office', and concluded that it is `insusceptible'-a very difficult word even perhaps for a great judge-`of sub-division whether by joint occupancy or by way of appointment of Assistant Ministers'. That opinion of Sir Garfield Barwick, QC, was in the face of the majority opinion of lawyers and of those who have held the office of Solicitor-General, the second law office of this nation. For example, Sir Kenneth Bailey, the then Solicitor-General, said in his 1958 opinion:
. . . there seems to me nothing in the Constitution to prevent the appointment of Associate or Assistant Ministers in the Department of Defence.

He then proceeded to explain some qualifications to his opinion and the way in which departments would have to be administered. Similarly, academic commentators also held different views from those expressed by Barwick, QC. For example, Professor Sawer, in 1956, in Public Law at page 110 and in a passage at page 124, said of the constitutional provisions:
Even if interpreted with the greatest strictness, section 64 of the Constitution does not require that only one person be appointed to administer a Department of State . . .

Perhaps because of the eminence that is accorded the views of that strong-minded judge, Sir Garfield Barwick, it seems that conservative governments in the past have been rather reluctant to take the issue in hand and to proceed to do the logical thing, that is, to create the kind of structure that the Government has now created. The present Government's decision to proceed in the way it has was arrived at only after a very detailed opinion was sought and solicited from Dr Gavan Griffith, the Commonwealth Solicitor-General, who, after a review of the authorities, said at page 5 of his opinion, `I find myself in disagreement with Barwick's conclusion', and then set out the reasons. He found the opinion did not enjoy any textual support from the Constitution itself and that, secondly, looking beyond the textual context, it drew no support whatsoever from the practice of the Commonwealth parliaments, the British Parliament and other parliaments, prior to Federation, which would have been the models on which the Australian Constitution was drawn.

So we find that the only view which would stand in the way of the appointment of two or more Ministers to administer a department jointly is the view of Sir Garfield Barwick. Quite properly, the Government, after the opinions not only of past but also of present Solicitors-General, can clearly be confident that the balance of legal opinion is strongly in favour of the position it has adopted and that the present arrangements are perfectly proper and legitimate. It is some mark of the role of Sir Garfield Barwick, in perhaps yet another instance of his having stood in the way of rational decision making, that his influence lingered so long. It is perhaps one of the small tragedies of our public life that so great an intellect was put to such small purposes. I digress briefly to mention the book by David Marr on Barwick in which he says:

In 14 years on the bench, Barwick had managed to end Privy Council supervision of the High Court, but the London court remained entangled in the Australian court system. His work had had only a limited success.

Tax was Barwick's only triumph. The tax avoidance industry boomed in Australia in the 1970s as a direct result of the work of the Barwick High Court. Under Barwick's guidance the court approved tax schemes with great precision and learning, dissecting them and taking little interest in their overall shape and the purposes for which they were put into operation.

Sadly, that is Barwick's legacy-a great mind capable of great things but put to such little application. As with much of his legacy, his rather narrow and pedantic opinion has been overthrown and the Government has seen its way clear to implement a proposal which is rational and sensible and which successive governments had sought to implement before but had drawn back from because of the baneful influence of the lasting doctrine that Barwick had put forward.

The legal basis for the scheme is well established but, once we move along this course and appoint additional Ministers to implement the scheme, arrangements will clearly need to be made to pay those Ministers and to put the new operations into effect. The first part of this Bill provides for the appropriation of moneys to pay the additional three salaries, as I have indicated before, at a direct on-cost of some small sum but with the indirect saving of over $100m of Commonwealth funds through consequential savings. As well as the administrative efficiencies that derive from this streamlining of Commonwealth administration, ministerial salaries have had to be added to by an appropriation to accommodate the increased salary component which has flowed from the Remuneration Tribunal. The Remuneration Tribunal is the body which has been established to determine the salaries of members of parliament and Ministers. In 1987 it recommended that ministerial salaries be increased by 3.8 per cent with effect from 1 July as a first step towards the resolution of the agreed anomaly which the Tribunal found had existed since 1984. The Tribunal has also recommended that parliamentary salaries be increased by a further 2.2 per cent from 1 July 1988.

It may sound as if this is an instance of Ministers doing other than as they preach, but it should be pointed out clearly that this anomalous situation arose as a result of the Government's consistent demonstration of wage restraint. The legislation brings ministerial salaries back to where they would be if they had followed ordinary wage movements which have been granted to every other member of the working community in Australia. This measure does not include the 4 per cent claim currently under negotiation. It is merely an anomaly arrangement to bring salaries back to where they might otherwise be expected to be had the Government not, in an effort to lead by example, contained salaries way behind those of which other Australian workers have had the benefit. It is important to put that in context.

Again to put things in context, I draw very briefly on a paper prepared by the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) in which he compared wage movements for average weekly earnings, different price movements and salaries. The honourable member points out that for the years 1974 through to 1987 average weekly earnings increased by 278.6 per cent whereas the remuneration received by members of parliament increased by only 130 per cent for the same period. In other words, there has been a significant falling behind when one compares the remuneration paid to those who serve in the Parliament with that paid to the general community. I wish to place in context that this is not a wage grab by Ministers. It is simply the resolution of an anomaly, which is being properly addressed.

Finally, I do not wish to appear pious or canting, but it is sad that we should fall into the gutter in these types of debate. We are our own worst enemies if we take cheap shots at one another in the course of such deliberations. Euphemistically one might call a debate, such as we heard in this House earlier this evening, vigorous. Perhaps those listening on the radio might choose a less kind word. Those of us who do value and honour the privilege of serving in this Parliament do ourselves no great good by descending to the levels that were demonstrated earlier this evening.

Their pay, of course, is the subject of this legislation. No reasons were given at the time by the Prime Minister for an increase in the size of the Ministry and it became clear to the community that the action was taken to placate the warring factions within the Labor Party. It is now clear that that decision alone has cost the Australian community $1m in extra salaries and $1.4m for the extra accommodation that has to be provided in the new Parliament House. So we have an expanded Ministry and an extra three Ministers, at a cost this year to the Australian public of some $2.4m. No reason was given for the expansion other than to placate the warring factions within the Australian Labor Party. Again, the concern we have often expressed is that the Labor Party in government seems to forget its motto of `Power to the people', which is so often expressed on the way to government, and it soon becomes `Power to the Party'.

SPEECH.PARA: At the same time as the Prime Minister was trying to justify the increase in the size of his Ministry he was promoting new administrative arrangements which were supposed to save money and reduce the size of the Public Service. In September 1986 the Prime Minister promised to cut 6,000 from the Public Service by July 1988. Given that the Public Service has grown by 30,000 during the first four years of the Labor Government, which is four times the rate of growth during the last four years of the Fraser Government, the reversal of the previously irresponsible expansionary policy was not before time.

Last July the Prime Minister announced that further administrative changes would result in staff savings in a full year of some 3,000 positions, which the Government has directed should be achieved through a process of attrition or voluntary action on the part of employees. The Prime Minister's commitment to smaller government was soon swept away with the revelation in the Budget of the provision of 3,077 new positions: for example, in the Attorney-General's Department, 263; in the Department of Veterans' Affairs, 378; in the Department of Social Security, 1,000, and so on. These new positions wipe out the staff savings from the Prime Minister's new administrative arrangements. In the Budget, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) stated that the restructuring of Commonwealth departments was estimated to produce savings of $107m in a full year and to cut 3,100 off staffing levels by 1988-89. What he did not tell us was that at the same time they were going to make 3,077 new appointments.

Savings in staff from the amalgamations of departments should accrue through the elimination of the duplicated administrative functions such as personnel offices and payroll offices, as well as library and security services, and from efficiencies gained in the number of upper management staff. Instead of those affected by the amalgamation being retrained and redeployed or paid out as redundant so they can get on with their lives, we have seen the creation of a new class of public servant-the redeployed. They live in the twilight zone of the Public Service. These employees are kept on the Federal Government payroll but are shunted from position to position. They are never given any real job responsibility and they are unable to find other positions within the Public Service or move out to a new career in the private sector.

The Public Service claims that there are as many as 4,500 redeployees in the Australian Capital Territory alone. A recent Australian Broadcasting Corporation report claimed that there were up to 15,000 Public Service redeployees awaiting redeployment nationwide. Based on the average annual Public Service staffing costs, the 4,500 redeployees awaiting meaningful placement in the Australian Capital Territory are costing $180m annually, and nationally over $600m a year is being wasted. The spectre of the redeployed worker haunts the Prime Minister's much vaunted reform of the Public Service system. For two years now the Prime Minister has been promising cuts in the size of the Public Service, but department heads to whom the responsibility of reducing the Public Service has been devolved are finding out that it is less costly, in any given Budget year, to keep redundant employees on the payroll than to make redundancy payments under the redundancy awards.

Under normal circumstances the cost to the Government of a redundancy payment in a case of voluntary retrenchment reaches the cost of one year's salary of the retrenched employee after only five years of employment. No wonder the Government finds administrative excuses to keep shuffling these employees from department to department. In other words, looking only at annual expenditure, it is cheaper to keep employees who have served more than five years than to pay them out. Of course, in the longer term it is much cheaper to pay them out. At the end of last year there were 46,000 Public Service employees in the Australian Capital Territory. Only 38 of these had been given redundancy packages and all of them were in the Senior Executive Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Chair has offered a fair amount of latitude on that area. I suggest that the honourable member return to the Bill.

—Thank you, Madam Speaker. I am saying that the Prime Minister, in claiming that staff savings can be made from the new ministerial arrangements-an increase in the size of the ministry-is saying that amalgamations under these new ministerial arrangements will actually save money in the Public Service. What I am putting to the House is that no money has been saved because the commitment to reduce the Public Service has not been met. For two years the Prime Minister has promised staff cuts of 6,000 by 30 June this year and so far only 700 have been identified. The Prime Minister promised redeployment, yet some 15,000 are sitting around at an annual cost to the taxpayer of some $600m.

—Order! Does the honourable member for Barker intend to return to the Bill? The Bill has nothing in it about redeployment or the Public Service. It is a very narrow Bill. I have pointed that out on a number of occasions. I have given the honourable member a fair go. I suggest he returns to the Bill or resume his seat.

—Certainly, Madam Speaker. In relation to the Bill, as I said a moment ago, the Prime Minister has claimed that the reason the public should accept this legislation, accept the increased payment to an increased number of Ministers, is that staff savings will be made. I am putting to the House that that is not the case. One of the reasons we have expressed concern about the increase in the number of Ministers, which results in Bills such as this, is that staff savings will not be made. There are other concerns, of course, about substantial changes in administrative arrangements such as those which have been made subsequent to the appointment of these three Ministers. There is concern in the Public Service about its underhand politicisation. The concern is that the Government is using the change in administrative arrangements to install its own people instead of abiding by the provisions requiring appointment or promotion to be based on merit.

SPEECH.PARA: This Ministry, that we are going to pay more money to as a result of this legislation tonight, has a responsibility to abide by the provisions of the Public Service Act. The concern of the Public Service about politicisation is, I guess, highlighted by recent appointments in the Department of Aviation, for example, where new appointments have been made at the senior level of branch head-and three branch heads appointed over existing staff were all ex-Labor ministerial assistants.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Barker will resume his seat. He has no intention of heeding the Chair. I ask him to resume his seat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know the House is looking forward with anticipation to the next lot of legislation but the Ministers of State Amendment Bill, that is before the House, has this title:

SPEECH.PARA: An Act to amend section 5 of the Ministers of State Act 1952.

The Bill is consequential on the increase in the number of Ministers from 27 to 30 and the 3.8 per cent increase in salaries effective from 1 July, as recommended by the Remuneration Tribunal in report No. 3 of 1987. In the work practice area some sort of productivity claims ought to be entered into by Ministers and some sort of grading take place on the productive effort of Ministers. It would be possible in the time I have to go through the processes of nominating my appraisal of the productive effort of each of the Ministers.

I could start with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and see whether the 3.8 per cent claim that has been awarded by the Remuneration Tribunal in its report No. 3 of 1987 is justified in his case. All Prime Ministers work extremely hard. This one does. Whether he is effective in his work would be a matter for the Tribunal to judge. Scales could easily be established to see whether Ministers had a work practice that produced effective legislation that was conducive to the well-being of the community and whether their role and attitudes in the carrying out of their tasks were such that they would be eligible to receive the increase in salary. The task of being Deputy Prime Minister is far less demanding and one would have to ask whether in those circumstances the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) warranted the 3.8 per cent increase. Maybe if we see the advent of citizens initiative voting-referendums-we may see some change in the processes by which ministerial salaries are increased.

Ministers, after all, are like managers and directors of large organisations. It is on performance that they should achieve greater remuneration, rather than on the blanket class award that is typical of so much of the Public Service. The productivity claims of various Ministers in the Hawke Government will vary. The Treasurer (Mr Keating), the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) all could be claimants under productivity claims. It would be interesting to see Ministers go through the processes that those in the union movement or those on fixed incomes have to go through to see whether they deliver the management-type process that warrants salary increases.

The American system is one whereby Ministers are awarded a lump sum and they allocate totally those funds as they see fit-the number of officers, type of staff, hardware and office set up. The Australian approach is too restrictive and Ministers and members ought to be able to exercise more fully their managerial skills. This should be considered by the Remuneration Tribunal in assessing the needs of Ministers. If much of the allocation that Ministers currently receive in the form of salary and, linked with that, rent paid for offices and the assistance they receive in the form of postage, stationery and all the rest lumped in together were totalled, those Ministers could then make an assessment of their real needs.

It could well be that many Ministers would prefer to have additional personal staff. Others, on the other hand, may wish to go into a greater range of computer hardware and software, thereby increasing the output of a smaller staff. Ministers may wish to disperse their ministerial staff around the country. They may feel that that is a more effective way of servicing the community. Those factors are not open under the current arrangements. It would be good if members and Ministers were to go forward with the proposal that managerial skill be encouraged in the effective use of the funds currently allocated for their use.

Linked with that new approach we would see a diversity of service to the community. Madam Speaker, you and I have both served electorates that are demanding and we have often wished that we were not restricted in quite the way we are in the use of the attachments to our office and that the total sum provided by the community could be more effectively spent. The same thing applies even more significantly to Ministers. It is time that the Remuneration Tribunal broke away from such a structured approach to ministerial salaries. The 3.8 per cent increase across the board was negotiated with the Australian Council of Trade Unions in some long, complicated process to decide what were acceptable salary rises. That was completely inappropriate but maybe politically wise. However, if there were greater flexibility those increases would not be linked necessarily just to salary rises. They would also be linked to other costs such as rent and to other managerial costs such as wages of staff and so on. So the budget for the Minister, which would include his salary, would be liable to a more realistic fluctuation in line with costs and community standards.

The Minister has a right to take the total of his budget and put it in his own pocket and say, `That is mine. I am worth it and I will not have any staff'. The Minister could be as radical as that but no Minister would be so foolish. A Minister would have to make the judgment of whether he paid himself a little or a lot, whether he paid his staff highly or poorly and whether he had part time or full time employees. So instead of the processes that have been gone through and outlined in this legislation it is time for new and more imaginative thinking and a better opportunity for Ministers to make their decisions.

We have spoken about the prospect of making productivity awards for Ministers. That is frivolous and foolish but the prospect of greater flexibility and capacity for Ministers to ease their administrative loads by having greater flexibility in their decision-making would be to the benefit of Australia. The same thing should apply to members and senators. We are not debating that tonight; we are debating Ministers. Managerial expertise, expressed at that higher level, would show quickly which Ministers had ability and those that would fail. If they failed it would be by their own decisions, their own staff and their own support system. It is easy for a department to prop up a Minister, but a Minister's own decisions should be seen clearly by the community. I trust that the Ministers in the House and those in the extended Hawke Government will see that there is opportunity for them to show more imagination and flair than they are showing at the moment. The increase in the number of Ministers has not been beneficial to this Parliament or to Australia. It has caused great confusion, and conflict in some instances. The overlapping of responsibilities has been confusing for the whole community. There are too many people doing too few things. A Minister should be in charge and should have the staff to acquit himself well. With those remarks I draw my comments to a conclusion and trust that the Ministers can see their way clear to moderate the current restrictive and uniform way in which decisions are made at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I have listened to this debate, either in the House or in my office, for the past several hours and yesterday. Though I do not say I agree with him, the previous speaker, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), was the only member of the Opposition who made a sensible effort to address the concepts attached to ministerial responsibility and who did not adopt the hypocritical line that some others on the Opposition benches did. Their transgression of the rules of parliamentary debate was quite frivolous and surreptitious. The way in which dissent was moved against the Deputy Speaker's ruling by a front bench member on the Opposition side was quite scandalous. This has been a much wider ranging debate than the Ministers of State Amendment Bill was entitled to receive. The Bill is narrow. Basically, it seeks to allow appropriation of finances to accommodate the 3.8 per cent increase awarded to Ministers by the Remuneration Tribunal from 1 July 1987. That is in line with an increase already allowed to members of the House and to senators. The Bill also provides for the appropriation of a small amount of finance for the salaries of three extra Ministers and their staffs.

SPEECH.PARA: From what I have heard there has not been criticism of the first element of the Bill, so I pass that over. Not even members of the Opposition have attempted to argue that the appropriation of finance to cover the 3.8 per cent increase for Ministers granted by the Remuneration Tribunal as from July last, which I believe has been awarded to members of this House and senators, is not warranted. Basically, members of the Opposition centred their criticism on the decision of the Government under the machinery of government changes to increase the number of Ministers from 27 to 30. I want to answer some of those charges very briefly by examining what actually occurred and, I hope, showing very quickly that there have been efficiency gains through the reduction in the number of departments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Minister is seeking to discuss savings through administrative arrangements within the Public Service. I have been warned by Madam Speaker on three or four occasions that I was not allowed to do that within the context of this debate. I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to draw the Minister's attention to the title of the Bill and ensure that he remains relevant in order to maintain consistency in this debate, at least tonight, even if the debate has not been consistent throughout.
—I shall hear the Minister a little further on the point he wants to make. It would help the proceedings of the House if the Minister could draw his comments closer to the Bill.
—I find the point of order quite strange because the whole thrust of the contribution from virtually every speaker from the Opposition benches--
—Order! The Minister, who has an interest in getting the legislation through, is not really helping matters.
—With respect, I just want to point out--
—The Minister has done that.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I am supposed to be answering points that have been raised during the debate and which have been allowed by various occupants of the chair.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. This highlights the difficulty that this House now faces, because the Minister is seeking to respond to points made last night in this debate when the debate was wide ranging. Unfortunately, tonight the debate has not been allowed to be wide ranging and comments such as those in relation to the Public Service and ministerial performance have been ruled out of order. How on earth can the Minister respond to comments made on ministerial performance, the Public Service, and administrative arrangements if those matters have been declared out of order tonight by those who have held the position of Speaker and Deputy Speaker?
—I ask the Minister to make his comments on the matters he has been pursuing as quickly as possible and bring them to conclusion.

—As has been referred to in debate, the Bill provides for the salaries of an extra three Ministers and their staff. That is what I am addressing. The Ministry was increased by three to amalgamate certain Ministries and produce 16 super-Ministries covered by 16 Ministers and 14 assisting Ministers; and 16 and 14 makes 30, which is three more than the existing 27. The Government is seeking to legislate to provide salaries for the extra three Ministers and their staff. I am saying that it made perfectly good sense for the Government to make these machinery changes resulting in an extra three Ministers. From consideration of them, one sees that these are sensible decisions. Indeed, one of them affects my own Department.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Minister would be advised to read the Bill for he keeps referring to Ministers and their staff. One would think that as this is the Minister's Bill he would know what is in it. There is no reference in the legislation to staff. I repeat: if consistency is to be maintained, the Minister's attention should be drawn to relevance.
—Order! There is no point of order in respect of the most recent remarks made by the honourable member for Barker.

—Exactly, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I thank you for your ruling. I want to reiterate what has been said legitimately by speakers from the Government side, and that is that the decision to seek an appropriation to cover the three extra Ministers-much of which has been made by the shadow Minister in his contribution-has been good value. In a full year only $102,000 will be required to pay the salaries and allowances of the Ministers. In return, $105m in savings and 3,000 staff savings will have been achieved. In my Department alone, the Department of Administrative Services, there will be a saving of $23m for the appointment of one extra Minister.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. Normally, I would not be so pedantic but, given the firm rulings from the Chair tonight that discussions on the Public Service and savings will not be allowed because this Bill deals only with Ministers of State, I ask that you ask the Minister to be relevant.
—I listened carefully to Madam Speaker's rulings, and I do not uphold the point of order of the honourable member for Barker.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I have virtually made the points that I want to make. I thank you for your indulgence and your ruling. Obviously there is a connection between the savings and the efficiency achieved as a result of the increase in the Ministry from 27 to 30 and the outlays contained in the Bill. Surely even the honourable member for Barker should be able to understand that. I conclude my remarks by saying that the Australian public has had very good value indeed as a result of the ministerial arrangements effected by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) after the July election. As far as this Government is concerned, those changes and the appointment of three extra Ministers will effect a much more efficient and tighter organisation as Ministries have been reduced from 27 to 16.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr West) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1987-88[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1987-88APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1987-88]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1987-88 and cognate Bills afford us the opportunity to scrutinise the stewardship of the Government and the handling of the economy by the Government. The Bills enable us to assess the integrity of the Government's Budget and the reliability of its projections. They enable us to see how much it is in control of the management of the nation. These appropriation Bills are in themselves an indictment of the Government. When people vote for a government they look for leadership, but in this case they get vacillation. They look for decision making, but they get kite flying. This type of leadership and this type of positive decision making have not been the hallmark of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen a remarkable saga of quite amazing actions constantly undertaken in the guise of government. We see Ministers and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) talking about the privatisation of Qantas Airways Ltd, the Commonwealth Bank and Australian Airlines. We hear Ministers saying that this ought to be done because there needs to be an injection of capital. We read in the Press about proposals partly to privatise and merge Qantas, Air New Zealand Ltd and Australian. We think we hear responsible statements by Ministers of this Government. But then the waffle starts. We then have all sorts of statements from backbenchers, by the factional committees, by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and by everybody else associated with the Australian Labor Party. We then see some sort of reversal.

We are not seeing government. We are seeing manoeuvring for positions in the National Conference later in the year. There is never any debate in this Parliament on these very important issues. We have the spectacle of a government which cannot make decisions, let alone vital decisions, because it is divided, under threat from factionalisation and, from time to time, caves in to the most vociferous of the vocal groups. This can be very easily illustrated. We saw no less a person than the Prime Minister, who should be speaking for the Government, saying things such as there will be no capital gains tax, no assets test and no new tax on superannuation. Then the waffle starts and we get all of those taxes. We get all of those imposts.

I ask the question that the people of Australia are asking. How can this Government govern with such division and such indecision? How can it give attention to the vital tasks of cutting government expenditure when Caucus committees not only oppose those cuts but demand a substantial extension of a social welfare system which it is already beyond our capacity to pay for. We have people such as Senator Walsh and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) saying that the economy is extremely fragile. We even hear talk of progress to a banana republic. We hear Senator Button saying that there were threats of International Monetary Fund intervention in 1986. Yet the demands seem to come from the Caucus for more and more expenditure. The Government lurches from one crisis to another.

How can a government give attention to the reduction of our disgraceful and crippling indebtedness when it has these sorts of problems in its ranks? Our massive debt has already been alluded to in this debate. Of course, the problem is that we are borrowing, and have borrowed, not for expansion, not to attain any greater competitiveness, not to give industry an incentive to provide jobs but we are borrowing to pay our housekeeping bills. We are borrowing to pay for our social welfare program. There are cries for more and more increases. There is no way in the world we can attack our indebtedness with a system such as that. The Government talks about its record of taxation reduction. It talks about its nominal cuts in income tax. But every time Australia gets a tax cut under this Government the total tax revenue rises.

I refer to not only the Government's new exotic taxes but also the indexation of sales tax and excise which surreptitiously and substantially increases. With these sorts of increases in indirect tax we have an increased cost burden on industry and business. We have continued inflationary pressures. We have been provided with politics, not with government. The Prime Minister and the Government have one hand tied behind their backs because they are unable to make and sustain decisions. They are second guessed in all of their proposed programs by the left wing, by the factions, by the Caucus committees and by the ACTU. I ask: Is that not the worst of all worlds?

When we call on the Government to account for its stewardship-when it is questioned-we get no answers. It is a sad thing to say-I say it with 15 1/2 years experience in this House-that very often Question Time deteriorates into a comedy. We do not get answers, we get grandstanding and giggles about the Opposition. More and more the Prime Minister and Ministers seem to be inclined to act more as comics than as Ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not so much a comedy as a farce.

—Yes, a farce. Instead of answering questions, they make references to Mr Elliott, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and John Stone. They want to paint caricatures, not answer questions. Let the cartoonists stick to that-they get paid for it and they do it pretty well. What this Parliament wants is an account of the stewardship of the Government. The Government should govern. It should not be diagnosing and carping about everybody else's problems-not the Opposition's or anybody else's. Because the Government has no worthwhile policy we see Government asking the Opposition to chart out its policies. Perhaps it is looking for a sensible policy course along which to steer this nation. The Government is too busy playing politics and has neglected completely the task of responsible government.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the Government's plan for the taxation of superannuation funds? Plenty of kites have been flown. We have had statements from Ministers, backbenchers, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and everybody else about what might or might not be done about new taxation of superannuation funds. Nothing definitive, no answers, evasion. But there is a vague threat that something will be done. The Government tells us to wait until the May statement. That is fine, but the people of Australia cannot wait. There are people everywhere who are retiring prematurely in droves because they are concerned about the taxation of superannuation. People come to my office and, I guarantee, the offices of every member of this Parliament and they ask about superannuation. They ask me what the Government will do. What can I tell them? The Government has not made up its own mind and certainly it has not given any definitive statement on this matter. There is a state of desperation and panic out there among people who are worried about questions such as this.

What is the Government's plan for taxation review? It talks of tax cuts, but all the time we have the undertones of other tax increases and new taxes. The Government is in a dilemma about indirect tax. In that dilemma it is trying to point the finger at the Opposition about its policies on indirect taxation, what the Opposition is going to do about consumption tax and everything else. The Government will not resolve its own problems by speculating on what the Opposition might do. Remember, it was the Treasurer who first raised and promoted consumption tax at the Taxation Summit. He was forced to withdraw that option, but I believe it is still his favoured position. As a private member, I can give my comments and views on such matters as consumption tax and I intend to do so-for the Government and for anyone else who looks in this direction. My recommendation is that there be no forays into additional and new consumption taxes. Indirect taxes and taxes on consumption-and we have plenty now-are already too high. We want tax relief, but it is not tax relief to cut income tax and then bring in new taxes and increase indirect taxes-that is sleight of hand. Consumption tax would be a growth tax, insidious and feeding on itself. As we all know, sooner or later its tentacles would extend into food, clothing and essentials. In all these sorts of taxes, especially indirect taxes, the burden falls more heavily on those who can least bear it.

I would like to give the case of a member of my own family-my son. I am sure that other members can mirror this situation. My son is married and he has three children. He is totally deaf and therefore he has only a modest income. He is not able, because of his impediment, to have a very highly paid occupation. He is paying off his house. He buys shoes for the children for school. What is the price of them? It costs $40 or $50 for the cheapest pair of shoes and they last about five minutes. The cost of clothing is frightening. He wants to send another child to kindergarten, but the fees are $6 or $8 a day. How can he afford it? My son is worried about his job. With the Federal Government cutting State funds-he works for a State Government department-he knows that there will be retrenchments and he just hopes that it is not him because with his impediment it would be very difficult for him to find work in private enterprise or elsewhere. He goes to the supermarket and finds that the prices are up every week. There are people all over Australia just like my son. Add consumption tax to their burdens and these people will go to the wall. If they lost their job, their income is slashed. They do not get as much money, yet the cost of the things they buy keeps going up and up. Prices are escalated by all these indirect taxes such as consumption tax. Those facts should be contemplated when we think of this sleight of hand of shifting taxation around instead of cutting it.

There is another reason why I oppose such taxes as consumption tax. No government will give serious attention to cutting the size of government or government expenditure if it can simply bring in new taxes. If it can bring taxes in from somewhere it will not make any endeavour to cut taxation. Any intention of cutting taxation or of responsible economic management is diluted because there is an insurance policy there-the government can always get more and it has got something on which it can build, something which it can escalate. History of government-all governments-shows that while it can generate new tax revenue and increase existing tax revenue it is not interested in getting down to the job of cutting government size or expenditure. That is a cosmetic operation. Every government of every complexion that I have ever known fits that mould and earns that criticism. This Government, which talks about redistribution of incomes and boasts of tax cuts, has done no such thing. It has created the revenue grabbing monsters of fringe benefits, capital gains, the assets test, and automatic indexation of indirect tax. It has been completely diverted from a real attack on spending, on the deficit, on economic management. Why should it worry? Today the Prime Minister proudly announced the quite massive revenue that is generated by those very taxes. I stand to be corrected, but I think he was talking of the order of $1.5 billion without any reference at all to increases in sales tax and excise.

Unfortunately, the last conservative Government, with parity pricing, fuel taxes and other taxes, had the same effect. These were taxes which increased all the time. It was great revenue; it grew splendidly year by year. Thus government spending continued to escalate and the Public Service continued to grow. Government expansion was just as noticeable then as it is now. There were no real cuts of any magnitude or significance then either. That is why I am saying that we should not be looking at new taxes; we should be looking at cutting expenditure and the size of the government and really getting down to the business of cutting taxes. We must cut duplication and waste. This provides incentive, jobs, and the growth in national product. This restores competitiveness, revives exports, and brings us towards solvency. It also creates stable and permanent employment, helps to cut interest rates and gives a better standard of living. Is that not what we want? Is that not what we are all dedicated to doing? Our present course cannot support the standard of living that the people of this nation enjoy today. As a nation and a people we are living far beyond our means.

As we look at these appropriation Bills, we find a claim that there are great savings included in them. That escapes me. For instance, as I look at the savings, I find that $8.434m savings is claimed for expenditure under the Australia Card Act 1987. Savings! The Government did not even get the legislation through. It could not spend that money, it did not have it to spend because it did not get the legislation through. Yet it claims to have saved that money. That is how spurious this whole statement of savings is. It talks about savings made in transfers of services and payments to the States. I'll say! The States balance their budgets so the Federal Government offloads the problems to the States. It cuts their funds so that there must be new State taxes. It does absolutely nothing to cut its own prodigal spending so its whole boast on that count is hollow.

Let us have a look at what comes out of the May statement. Probably more of the same. Honourable members will remember the last May statement-more off the States, more off the roads and a garage sale! That is the way the Government was supposed to be cutting its expenditure. It did nothing about its own prodigality. It visited its problems on someone else. Hopefully this time we will see some real cuts and not a sleight of hand.

This Government talks about help for the disadvantaged, yet I have pensioners who come into my office every day of the week saying that they pay tax and provisional tax. This is because the threshold is so low. We have problems with the Department of Social Security. I do not say this as a criticism because the Department is generally helpful; but some of its officers are giving advice which they should not give. Pensioners go to the Department and say they are worried about their tax. The officers reply, `You do not have to worry about tax, you can earn $30 a week on top of your pension'. Of course they can earn $30 a week and it will not affect their pension, but they will pay tax. They will pay provisional tax. This is the sort of problem we have. These people are confused and suffering traumas. I hope the Government can get down to the business of doing something about provisional tax for pensioners. What is happening is a tragedy, it is sad, and is not right. These people have borne the heat of the day, they have built for us a nation, and I think we can treat them better than that.

Pensioners have also been affected by a problem in the Queensland branch of the Tax Office. Once again, my remarks are not by way of criticism. From time to time I have had plenty to say in this House about the Tax Office, and quite justifiably so. Because of a computer problem, assessments in which the age rebate was not allowed were sent to some pensioners who pay provisional tax. They were getting bills for $500 and $600 instead of about $100. I got in touch with the Tax Office, which quickly got onto this matter. They found out what had happened and tried to rectify the problem. I understand the situation, but this was just another trauma for pensioners. It was just another worry for people who ought not to be worried.

We on this side of the House are worried about the average working man. We care about the one-income family man with two or three children who is paying off a home. We are worried about the completely unacceptable tax burden he has to bear. This causes debt, marriage breakdown and mental and physical stress. The Government seems to want to go on avariciously reaping more and more. It is not using the money it reaps to help these people. The Waste Watch Committee came up with some quite horrifying and interesting examples of what the Government does with the revenue it collects. I will not go through the list at any length. We have heard before of the translation of the biography of the Prime Minister into Japanese and the murals that are commissioned by the trade unions-I do not know what they do with them. We see funding going to all sorts of off-beat organisations. That is reprehensible; it is not helping the people who need help.

Instead of helping people, the Government seems to be intent on destroying jobs. I will not go too far into this, but what about the way it is destroying responsible timber and logging industries? What about the way it is giving overseas aid to totalitarian regimes? The Government wonders why there is a backlash at the polls. It need not wonder very much longer. The reasons are very evident. These appropriation Bills, with their alleged savings and their camouflage and their smokescreen, are simply an alibi for incompetence and betrayal. I support the amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), who incisively and very accurately pinpointed the continuing failure of the Hawke socialist Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make it clear that I support Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1987-88, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1987-88 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1987-88 and reject the Opposition's amendment. Tonight I want to take the opportunity to bring to the attention of the House details of the clear breach of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Bill 1986 which is presently being undertaken by the nuclear industry in Europe with the active connivance of the European Atomic Energy Community (Euratom). One example of the breach has been revealed in recent reports in national newspapers and also in an Australian Broadcasting Corporation World Today program, which described how Australian uranium has been relabelled in West Germany and illegally enriched for nuclear weapons grade use in a research reactor in France.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, the Government so far does not appear to be taking the reports very seriously. Questions were asked in the Senate on 22 March about the original source of the reports in the German magazine Der Spiegel, but Senator Cook, the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, was rather dismissive of the report on the grounds that Der Spiegel was not necessarily a reputable magazine. Suspecting that the reports may not be treated with the seriousness they deserve and bearing in mind the devious and clever methods used by the nuclear industry to maximise its profits and hide the dangerous effect of nuclear products, I and two senators wrote to Der Spiegel and asked for copies of the source material upon which the reports were based. We now have the source documents comprising the written proceedings of two meeting of the Euratom supply agency and details of the actual case of flag swapping by Nukem, a West German nuclear company.

The case material is in the form of letters and telexes in German, but I also have a tape which translates the material into English. The important point I wish to make to the House is that previously we were dealing with secondhand reports, but now I have before me source documents which show conclusively that Euratom is, quite clearly, conniving with European nuclear companies to transgress Australia's nuclear safeguard provisions. Those safeguards were set out in detail by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) in his second reading speech on the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Bill on 4 June 1986. It states:

The Government permits exports of Australian uranium only to countries with which Australia has a bilateral nuclear safeguards agreement. These agreements provide a detailed set of safeguards arrangements designed to provide assurance that Australian origin nuclear material not only remains in the civil nuclear fuel cycle but that Australia can at all times account for it. This is achieved by ensuring that Australia's safeguards requirements apply to all transfers, processing and use of Australian uranium or derived material equivalent to the amount of uranium supplied by Australia.

On 27 and 28 April an official delegation from the European Parliament will be visiting Canberra and will have discussions with a number of Ministers, including the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin). One member of the delegation will be Mrs Undine von Blottnitz, a West German member of the European Parliament who will be drawing attention to the matters I am presently talking about. I note that a report in Melbourne's Herald newspaper of 12 April quotes the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy as denying that any breach of Australia's nuclear non-proliferation policy has occurred. I leave honourable members to draw their own conclusions from my speech. But I hope that the Minister will take account of my comments because I believe in particular that the involvement of Euratom needs serious investigation by our Government.

The first document I wish to refer to contains official notes of a meeting of the Euratom Supply Agency from 27 May 1986, which was called to discuss the single topic of international flag swaps. The notes described the existing situation regarding obligated material, and I quote:

Within Euratom the concept of a flag swap-namely, the exchange of safeguards obligations between two quantities of material in order to arrive at a situation which would otherwise be achieved by the physical transfer of those quantities-was understood and accepted, and the economic and safeguards advantages thereof were recognised. This concept when put to those supplier countries requiring obligations on material supplied by them had given rise to certain problems. These had included acceptance of the basic concept and difficulties concerning the validity of such an operation under the supplier state's agreement with Euratom. Particular concerns which have been expressed were:
to avoid publicly traceable `laundering' of material
to prevent down-grading either in form or quantity of obligated material
to foster NPT safeguards.
The current situation with Canada, the United States of America and Australia was detailed and a description of the situation in relation to Australia is worth quoting:

Three cases of flag swaps had been presented to Australia and on each occasion the Australian authorities had refused to take a decision. The concept of flag swaps had not yet been accepted; considerable education effort had been made by the Commission and the Supply Agency, as a result of which a policy decision by Ministers was pending and expected in the near future.
There was discussion about how some loosening of the stance of both Canada and the United States of America against certain types of flag swap might be achieved. Let me give another revealing quote:

Information on the international flag swaps which had already occurred was requested and brief details were given by the Commission and the Supply Agency. Additional information on one case involving Canadian origin material was given by the representative from Cogema. A request was made for other companies who had successfully undertaken international flag swaps to provide further details in due course.
It is very clear that these flag swaps are taking place. There is another quote I would like to give, too:

The prevailing sentiment was that in future cases of flag swaps requests by supplier states for disclosure or origin should be resisted, if possible, on the grounds that the essential feature of a flag swap is that it is an exchange of obligations, not an exchange of origin, and that in any case after processing uranium atoms are mixed together and their origin cannot be identified. Difficulties for industry to determine origin were pointed out. The suggestion was made that the term ``flag swap'' might have connotations of nationality and origin for outsiders, in which case the term ``exchange of obligations'' might be preferable.

It should be appreciated that, whilst the meeting notes basically dealt with problems with the Canadian flag swap, the general comments and conclusions were also relevant to Australia. The final conclusion of the meeting was:
The strong interest of Community industry in being able to exchange obligations between different quantities of material by means of flag swaps was confirmed.

The second document consists of notes of a meeting of the Euratom supply agency held in Brussels on 18 November 1987. So this is very much up to date. It amounts to a continuation of the discussion of at least 18 months previously. The introduction to the meeting stated:

During approximately the last two years increasing importance has been attached to the origin of nuclear material which is the subject of a supply contract or a physical transfer. The Supply Agency has seen the emergence of certain problems and the potential for others to arise. The purpose of this paper is to draw attention to these observations, to invite discussion within the Advisory Committee with a view to establishing, if possible, a common attitude within the Community.
The current situation in Canada, the United States, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and Australia was detailed. The Australian situation was noted as follows:

In discussions held so far between Euratom and Australia on international flag swaps, Australian officials made it clear that under present Australia policies towards South Africa international flag swaps (assuming agreement is reached on this question between Euratom and Australia) involving South African material would not be acceptable.
The notes then covered a detailed discussion on how to define the origin of uranium supplies, followed by the observation:
Many exchanges concerning nuclear material take place as ownership swaps and/or obligation swaps.
Ownership swaps provide two organisations with the opportunity to acquire, by means of exchange, title to a quantity of material, including the safeguards obligation (if applicable) and the origin.

Obligation swaps, whether as code swaps within the Community or as international flag swaps between the Community and another country, enable the owners of material to exchange the safeguards obligations attaching to the two different quantities of material.

The following final quote from the meeting notes makes it very clear that Euratom is not honouring the nuclear safeguards agreements which it has concluded with uranium suppliers, including Australia:

In the view of the Commission Services the concepts of obligation and origin should be kept separate, i.e. an exchange of a safeguarding obligation (intra-Community code swap or international flag swap) does not affect the origin of the material involved. This would mean the possibility of (1) the US obligation attaching to say South African material and (2) the US obligation disappearing entirely from material mined in that country. But this would be consistent with the concept that code and/or flag swaps are foremost a mechanism whereby changes of a supplier country's non-proliferation rights attaching to nuclear material are exchanged. It is for consideration whether holders and owners of nuclear material would wish, in addition to the exchange of safeguarding obligations (for which the mechanisms exist), to have mechanisms for the exchange of origin. It appears, though, that irrespective of the eventual attitudes of importing countries, the systematic tracing of the pedigree of nuclear material through the nuclear fuel cycle-in addition to that of safeguarding obligations-would require a considerable accounting effort by industry.

The third set of papers is one of many cases of how the actual breaches of the agreement are occurring. The papers comprise copies of letters and telexes between the West German nuclear company, Nukem, and Euratom. The background to the flag swapping operation was that Nukem contracted to supply 93 per cent enriched uranium 235 fuel rods for a research reactor in Grenoble, France. The resultant flag swapping operation is extremely complex. It is a pity that I do not have the time to detail the tortuous steps which Nukem underwent through two of its subsidiary companies-Nulux and RBU-and with the collaboration of GKT, an Austrian nuclear reactor company, and RWE, a West German energy company, to complete its contract with the French nuclear reactor company by the flag swapping process.

We now need to set out some facts. Fact one: RWE, the West German energy company, possessed in store with Nukem approximately 1.3 tonnes of Australian uranium, which must not be enriched to more than 20 per cent to ensure that it does not become weapons grade material in accordance with our nuclear safeguards requirements. Fact two: Nulux, a Nukem subsidiary, bought from GKT, the Austrian nuclear reactor company, four tonnes of undrilnitrate, a uranium by-product of fuel rods produced from American uranium actually produced by a Nukem subsidiary, RBU. The material was not in a physically transportable form. Nevertheless, it was listed, as recorded on the books of the Euratom supply agency, as American nuclear material.

Fact three: With the approval of Euratom Nukem exchanged the American nuclear material its subsidiary had purchased from GKT with the Australian uranium owned by RWE. At that stage Nukem owned the Australian uranium and RWE owned the American uranium by-products, so far everything is legal. But then Nukem sought approval of Euratom to also exchange the obligations. After a protracted communication by letter and telex Euratom agreed to the exchange of obligations and on its books the Australian uranium obtained by Nukem as a result of the obligations swap became American uranium without Australian safeguards and the RWE American uranium became Australian uranium with all the safeguards.

Why, honourable members ask, is the whole process so devious? Well may they ask, but as far as I can ascertain the operation is even more complicated than I have described because it involves swaps of varying grades of nuclear material. Suffice to say that Nukem ends up with Australian uranium which, contrary to our nuclear safeguards, is enriched to weapons grade material by the United States Department of Energy and finally delivered to the experimental research reactor in Grenoble, France. Nobody actually knows exactly what is produced at the Grenoble reactor, but there is a strong suspicion that, if not production, at least research into nuclear weapons is undertaken at the reactor. It is interesting to note that the case documents indicate that the Euratom safeguards inspectors were warned of the transaction in advance so that they would be alerted to the fact that the American uranium was not available for physical inspection as it was part of the manufacturing process.

How can the Euratom inspectors be trusted when they are alerted by a company which has deliberately broken the Australian nuclear safeguards agreement? The truth is that the European nuclear industry was deliberately transgressing the safeguard provisions of the Nuclear Non-proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1986. The Government must treat this matter with importance and investigate the serious breach of our nuclear safeguards which has been aided and encouraged by Euratom. These dishonest actions totally compromise Australia's uranium export program and should put its continuation into doubt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I know that the honourable member for Hindmarsh has the same concern that I have about these matters. I have just received a copy of the 1986-87 annual report of the Australian Safeguards Office (ASO) and, frankly, the documents that I have in my possession show that one of the main objectives of that office is being transgressed. I shall quote two of the objectives set out in the report of the Australian Safeguards Office:

SPEECH.PARA: To maintain inventories of and account for Australian origin nuclear material (AONM) and other nuclear items of Australian origin located in overseas countries and which are subject to the terms of Australia's bilateral safeguards agreements.

That is one of the objectives of ASO. The Australian Safeguards Office has obviously been kept in the dark about the clandestine operations of the European nuclear fuel industry. Another of the objectives of the ASO is this:

To keep the effectiveness of international safeguards under continuing review, in order to advise the Government on this matter, particularly with reference to AONM in the international nuclear fuel cycle.

I think at the very least that uranium exports to all of those European countries that have been involved in flag swapping should be immediately halted. Flag swapping is deliberately undertaken, in the case of Australia, to overcome our requirement that Australian uranium will not be enriched and used in the production of nuclear weapons or even in experimentation leading to the development of nuclear weapons. The report of the ASO sets out the responsibilities of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) in relation to the application of safeguards. One has to ask: Is the International Atomic Agency aware of the discussions by Euratom on flag swapping as a means of exchanging the safeguard obligations attaching to nuclear material? I find it difficult not to believe that the IAEA is aware of these activities. If so, the quotation in the ASO report from the IAEA 1986 report is misleading at the best and inaccurate at the worst.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Veterans Affairs-Chifley University-New Parliament House-Mr Clyde Cameron-Australian Defence Force-Medibank Private

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a number of matters related to the portfolio of Veterans' Affairs. I draw the attention of the House to the fact that on Monday week this nation will commemorate Anzac Day in our bicentennial year. In many ways it was the events of the landing at Gallipoli which did so much to create the spirit of Anzac and to create this nation as a whole. That contribution was further developed by the contributions made by so many Australians fighting for their country in conflicts after World War I. I believe that as all honourable members and honourable senators and the nation as a whole commemorate Anzac Day in various ways around Australia in our bicentennial year, we should acknowledge freely the massive contribution made by those who fought for their country in times of war.

SPEECH.PARA: In the light of that point I refer to the situation which is now unfolding with regard to our repatriation hospitals. There have been on again, off again threats of massive industrial disruption and resignations of key staff at the Repatriation General Hospital at Concord in Sydney. Should the ultimate resignations proceed, they will cause enormous disruptions and hardship from next Monday. The issue at Concord is the matter of parity with equivalent positions in the State public hospital system. It is a fairly clear-cut and straightforward issue. It has been before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission on more than one occasion, yet it is still unresolved. I put before the House and the Parliament a plea that the situation of our repatriation general hospitals, in particular Concord, be elevated in profile and addressed by those responsible for seeing that a proper solution is reached and reached rapidly.

The second and final area that I would like to deal with relates to a veteran from Balranald who is currently a patient in the Heidelberg Repatriation General Hospital in Melbourne. This man, whom I know well and who is a very dedicated and loyal Australian who served his country in a time of war, has been referred to the Peter MacCallum clinic on a daily basis for radium treatment. I welcome the fact that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) has come into the House. I am pleased to be able to say that this problem does not relate specifically to veterans' affairs but to some horrific ambulance arrangements which saw this Balranald veteran left on a stretcher at the Peter MacCallum clinic after receiving his treatment in some cases for hours on end before being taken back to the Heidelberg hospital. The reason I did not alert the Minister fully about my comments tonight was partly that I did not know that I would get the call. The problem is a very serious one. It relates to an area of ambulance administration, dispatch clerk administration. Somewhere in the Melbourne ambulance administration is a dispatch clerk or clerks who are simply not doing their job.

So it was that on 1 March my Balranald veteran had to wait 7 hours 25 minutes after the completion of his treatment at the Peter MacCallum clinic, which is in the central business district, before he could get back to the relative comfort of the Heidelberg Repatriation General Hospital. On another occasion he waited in excess of four hours and on another in excess of five hours. That is a disgraceful way to treat a cancer patient who is going through the suffering of special therapy, who is on a drip and who cannot be transferred by a vehicle other than an ambulance. He has hours upon hours of waiting time at the Peter MacCallum institute before being transferred back to the Heidelberg hospital. The matter has become to some extent a celebrated cause in the media in Melbourne, and the Melbourne Sun in particular, as well it might. I draw the attention of the House to this matter in the hope that the dispatch clerks and the others in authority who may well be responsible for this disgraceful situation might take action to eliminate the problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The decision of the incoming Greiner Liberal-National Party Government in New South Wales to scrub the name of Chifley from the new university in the western suburbs of Sydney is a very spiteful and churlish decision. I am amazed also, quite frankly, at the attitude of the new Liberal member for Bathurst in supporting the denigration of the Chifley memory and ideal in this very churlish way. I believe that the Liberal Government has shown its absolute contempt and disregard for the history of the area and the substantial reasons for the naming of the university in the first place.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Bury, the Liberal member for Bathurst, is absolutely wrong in his assertion in yesterday's local media that Ben Chifley is not associated with the western suburbs of Sydney. If Mr Bury had attempted in any way at all to research the matter he would have discovered that Ben Chifley's electorate of Macquarie, for all but three of the 14 years that he was the Federal member of parliament for that area, encompassed the area around Penrith where the university will be located. Mr Chifley, a great Australian, and Bathurst's most famous son, was the member for Macquarie from 1928 to 1931, and again from 1940 until his passing in 1951. Until the electoral redistribution of 1948, the Penrith and Windsor areas were part of the Macquarie electorate. That was obviously one substantial association that Mr Chifley had with the area. The whole idea of siting the university in the western suburbs of Sydney in the first place was to give the working class young Australians living in the area greater access to the advantages of higher education. What better example than Ben Chifley could there be for young, ordinary working Australians following a dream to make something great of themselves and others?

The New South Wales Liberal-National Party Government has chosen to ignore the many valuable contributions that Ben Chifley made to education. He helped found the Australian National University. He established training programs for returned servicemen and women after the war. In 1946 he began assisting civilian students at tertiary level. No-one could justly say that Ben Chifley did not make an outstanding contribution to education, not only in New South Wales but also, indeed, throughout Australia, both in deed and example. Although Ben Chifley did not have much of an opportunity for formal education in his younger days, he promoted the importance of education and himself spent some 15 years at night school after starting work. For the new Liberal Minister for Education in New South Wales, Dr Terry Metherell, to say that the only association that Ben Chifley had with the university was that he `used to drive a steam train down the main western line past the Werrington site' is not only a slight of a great man and of his works, but also an arrogant and shameful disregard of the facts.

I was pleased to read today in the Sydney media comments by my friend and colleague the honourable member for Lindsay (Mr Free), who has also joined in this condemnation of the blatant political act of the new Liberal-National Party Government in New South Wales of dropping the Chifley name. The honourable member for Lindsay, whose electorate now covers the area in which the proposed university is to be sited, along with some of his colleagues in the western suburbs of Sydney instigated efforts to have the university named in honour of Ben Chifley. The new New South Wales Government has not yet been in power for one month, but I believe people already are getting tired of its slash and burn mentality when it comes to anything done by the previous Government. The renaming of the Chifley University is just another example of this mindless practice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Few Australians could fail to feel a great sense of pride and achievement when they first see the amazing new edifice that is destined to be the landmark of this nation's capital. I refer, of course, to the new Parliament House, which is to be opened by Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth next month. I am only too aware of the enormous escalation in the cost of the project, and many honourable members have deplored the enormous blow-out in costs to a massive sum of $1.056 billion. I remind the House that in May 1978, when the project began, the original budget was $220m. Inflation, approved additions, industrial disputes and an increase in the size of Parliament, have all been responsible for the enormous increase in cost.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not defend the Parliament House Construction Authority for allowing this to happen, but I am assured that the new Parliament House has achieved world ranking in architectural design. In 200 years time these costs will be completely forgotten, but the craftsmanship and the quality of materials will endure.
