However, in spite of the massive burden such blow-outs have placed on the Australian taxpayer, I do not propose to dwell on that aspect of the project tonight. Like most, and I might even say all of my parliamentary colleagues, I am looking forward to the luxury of working in a space exceeding the nine square feet that I and my staff currently `enjoy' as an office. More important than my own relative comfort, however, is the fact that several of my constituents in the division of Corangamite have an opportunity to share in the nation's pride as the new Parliament House nears completion.

Mr Bruce Highett and his team of skilled craftsmen at Wycombe Industries Pty Ltd in Geelong will take their place in history when they deliver to Canberra this month furniture they have made specially for the new building. Wycombe Industries, an excellent example of a small business producing quality products, were awarded the contract to furnish the Prime Minister's Press conference table; the upholstered bench seating for the Parliamentary Library; eight Senate meeting tables; storage units for the Library; and various other items. Mr Highett gave the constituents of Corangamite and neighbouring Corio an opportunity to see their taxes at work before the furniture left Geelong. All items were placed on public display for a day, and many local residents took the opportunity to view their local craftsmen's skills. I commend Mr Highett and his team for their gesture.

From now on, the nearest most Australians will get to the Prime Minister's Press conference table is through their television sets as successive Prime Ministers face members of the Fourth Estate. Other items will be placed in restricted areas and will be rarely seen by the ordinary taxpayer, with the exception, of course, of those who successfully stand for Parliament. Wycombe Industries spent about a year developing an Australian standards level of competence with documentation, forms, and control systems, so that with a small grant from the Victorian State Government it was able to achieve the standard of workmanship required. The standard of manufacture is the highest ever demanded of the company. Its tradesmen and apprentices who have worked on the new Parliament House project, have shown great care and excellent craftsmanship, working to the finely detailed design drawing produced by the new Parliament House architects, Mitchell/Giurgola and Thorp. More than 100 pages of specifications were scrupulously followed. This meant procuring special hardware fittings, selecting timber in Western Australia and veneers in Queensland, and special brass finishes that can be produced only in Sydney.

I have had the privilege of examining the furniture and assure you, Madam Speaker, of its superb quality. Wycombe Industries is the classic example of a successful small business with good management-worker relationships. Mr Highett and his team at Wycombe Industries deserve the highest accolade for their excellent craftsmanship, and I applaud them for answering the challenge issued by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, Senator Button, to Australia's manufacturing sector, to upgrade its standards and quality. They have produced items of which not only they, but the whole country, can well be proud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Back in 1960 my young brother and I were involved in opening up the Nullarbor Plain for pastoral industry. It will be the last great pastoral development that Australia will ever see. In those days there was no television or radio on the Nullarbor and we had to entertain ourselves. Incidentally, television and radio broadcasts cannot be received there today either unless one has a satellite dish, which makes me very resentful of the extraordinary expenditure on the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) for the benefit of middle class Australian cities situated around the coast. Poetry has played a big part in my life and Peter Hogg, a colleague of mine, wrote a poem which goes:

SPEECH.PARA: Tho' I wondered as I listened
To the tales they told of yore,
Was it really any better than . . .
Did life give any more?
Or is it just an old man's way
Of polishing the truth
As with sadness in heart, he says,
`Farewell to parted youth'.

As I ponder on those words I feel that they are words that Clyde Cameron, the former member for Hindmarsh, ought to take to heart. Clyde Cameron was one of the first people to call for Bob Hawke to replace Bill Hayden as Leader of the Australian Labor Party. I remember challenging Clyde Cameron about this at the launching of his book Unions in Crisis at the National Press Club. But, of course, Clyde Cameron is a guru and deeply honoured in Labor Party circles and I but a mere backbencher holding a marginal seat. Clyde, it will be recalled, was the man who turned the Commonwealth Public Service into pacesetters in pay and conditions-a role usurped in recent times by Victorian governments of both parties. It is true that he realised what he had done and repented in later years, and even took to carte blanche bludgeoning of public servants.

A recent speech made by Mr Cameron and published widely in several union journals and in the Melbourne Age deserves comment, not for its content but for its omissions and lack of objectivity. His defence of the public ownership of Australian Airlines and Qantas Airways Ltd was predictable and calculated to appeal to knee-jerk Labor Party sentimentality. Yes, of course they could be funded by loans guaranteed by the Government. This begs the question. Why be in the airline business at all? Our voters seldom use planes, and when they do I can assure Mr Cameron that their part ownership is not recognised by the staff at the front counter who, like so many other large organisations in the private and public sector, believe that the organisation is run for the benefit of staff and management. He should also consider that if the original capital had been invested in Commonwealth bonds, we the owners would have got a better return on our money. If Mr Cameron really believes what he is saying, then I suggest he study the courteous service, punctuality, safety and comfort of Aeroflot as a model.

If we were genuinely concerned about our social objectives, we would be funding the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC). This people-owned merchant bank has probably the best record of any merchant bank in terms of return on capital, and while providing part ownership of many businesses from Australia it is simultaneously creating productive jobs at a rate which no other organisation can match for the dollar invested. The Government's response to capitalising the AIDC has been very tardy, something Mr Cameron could have usefully chided us for. Instead, he prefers to resort to the old sophist ploy of trotting out every cliche, shibboleth, myth and time-worn platitude of Labor folklore.

Mr Cameron talks of previous Labor governments-`real Labor governments', he calls them. Why, may we ask, did these heroes of yesteryear not introduce a capital gains tax, which is fundamental to tax equity? Why did they not act to close off the rorts in the tax system that were so detrimental to the interests of our pay as you earn taxpayers? Why did they not introduce substantiation and remove entertainment from tax deductibility? Unlike Mr Cameron, I did not support the Hawke ascendancy, but I am prepared to give credit where it is due. No government has ever given assistance to low income earners on the scale of the family assistance plan devised by this Government-a plan that increases the income of some workers with children by up to 40 per cent, an achievement that no union could ever hope to match. It is an initiative that completely overshadows the middle class welfare of the Whitlam era. The program has not been sold well and, as a consequence, the take-up is not as high as we would have liked. Mr Cameron would be serving the cause of Labor well if he had bothered to publicise this single initiative rather than pandering to perceptions. For politics is about perceptions. and fostering these perceptions is all too easy, and in doing so the truth is often the first casualty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak tonight following the excellent contribution made earlier by the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), our shadow spokesman on veterans affairs, who drew attention to the serious situation that faced a veteran living in his electorate. That stirred me to recall a letter I recently received from a veteran in my electorate of Gilmore, a man who resides in one of the loveliest parts of Australia, Kangaroo Valley. He wrote me a letter which, to his mind, explained the reasons why the Australian defence forces are currently suffering from what is now recognised as the most alarming resignation rate it has ever experienced. The record high resignation level in all three Services continues to rise and to disturb not only active service personnel and veterans but the broad cross-section of the Australian community who at varying stages in our history have depended, and will depend in future, on an effective defence force to protect the Australian nation. I would like to read some excerpts from the letter that this gentleman wrote to me as to why he believes we have a problem with our Defence Force today. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to inform you of some of the reasons responsible for the current manpower crisis in the Australian Defence Force (ADF). I am a returned serviceman now living on my DFRDB pension who is very much in touch with service organisations and still serving personnel.

First of all it is the Government's responsibility to protect the service conditions of members of the ADF. If the Government is seen to be hostile (and it is seen to be hostile) to the conditions of service then the only retaliation open to service members is to resign.
so far during the life of this Government the following attacks on the conditions of service have been made:
(1) the theft of 2 per cent of member-contributed pensions
(2) the taxing of lump sum superannuation payments
(3) changes to the Veterans Entitlement Act
(4) changes proposed to the Defence Home Loan (plenty of statements made but no one is sure what those changes will be)
(5) the promised two yearly pay review quietly forgotten
(6) loss of resettlement loans
and I could go on and on.

government as well as public attitude has contributed a great deal to the dissatisfaction of servicemen . . . No one wants to know a serviceman in peace-time but let the country be threatened and the screams will be deafening.

Many servicemen have vivid memories of a former Deputy Prime Minister kissing his North Vietnamese mates in Australia while Australian servicemen were still fighting in Vietnam. They remember the collection of money and medicines (by now prominent members of the Labor Party) being sent to North Vietnam. The famous draft dodgers, conscientious objectors and straight out traitors who have been promoted to top Government jobs, while the serviceman who was willing to give his life is struggling and still fighting for compensation for his war-caused injury. The stolen 2 per cent taken from his pension has not been forgotten either. Servicemen will only take so much.
You do not have to look very far to find other reasons for dissatisfaction:
the seemingly unlimited money spent on the Reserve at the expense of permanently serving personnel
Reserves actively being encouraged to come back in on full pay plus pension preventing regulars from being promoted.
the loss of the Fleet Air Arm to enable a private firm to engage in surveillance
the complete mishandling of the disposal of fixed wing aircraft
incompetence in handling last wage case
and the continuing interference, job stealing and general running of the Services by civilian personnel (public servants) who are not required to risk their lives.

Also of significance: a serviceman with two children is only about $2 better off per week than his counterpart (also with two children) living on social services and obtaining all the free benefits. For this $2 the serviceman is required to work more than 50 hours per week and risk his life if called upon to do so.

Loyalty is very much a two-way thing and a country has to be worth fighting for in order that men and women are willing to sacrifice their lives. Knowing the way servicemen are regarded by this Government and having witnessed the continual attacks being made on service conditions I sometimes wonder if this country is worth it.

Do not dismiss these reasons as being unrelated to the personnel wastage in the ADF. We are rapidly approaching a part-time Defence Force and until proper recognition is given to the contribution made by servicemen who may be called upon to risk their lives for their country, morale will continue to be a problem. Unless promises are kept by each and every Government (now and in the future) wastage (resignations) will accelerate.

That, I think, expresses the genuine concerns of active personnel as well as those ex-servicemen and veterans that our nation has, a concern which is, as I said earlier, expressed right across this country. This Government, this Parliament, has a responsibility of ensuring that we have an effective Defence Force. If we boil it down, the most responsible task this Government has is to defend the nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —In recent weeks several Opposition members have taken the opportunity in the adjournment debate to attack Medibank Private. They have called upon a study done on Medibank Private. The Voluntary Health Insurance Association of Australia commissioned a firm called Touche Ross and Co. to carry out the study. I recall that the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) quoted the Touche Ross report, which argues that Medibank Private `does enjoy a very substantial advantage' over the other private health funds, mainly because of the fact that it is a conjoint operation with the much larger Medicare operation, which bears the major share of the infrastructure costs necessary to operate a health insurance organisation. It is odd to recall also that the very object of that study's destructive remarks, Medibank Private, was a child of the Fraser Government. Perhaps that shows further strains in coalition thinking.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the Health Insurance Commission quite rightly responded in kind by approaching another company to carry out a survey of the industry and Medibank. That study, carried out by Price Waterhouse, said that Medibank is gaining a bigger share of the health insurance market because it performs better than other private health funds. While one may be a bit sceptical about consultants' reports, the terms of reference for which are written to give the answers one wants, one can at least compare those two consultants' reports before one accepts one and rejects the so-called advantages of Medibank Private as outlined in the other. But Touche Ross wanted to equalise the two bit competitors. It wanted to have an even playing field. It recommended that Medibank Private should be required to pay to Consolidated Revenue the accumulated advantage in respect of the establishment loan-$25.9m at June 1986-and the accumulated advantage in respect of the capital grant-$18.8m-and that it charge and be charged with asset utilisation charges calculated on a commercial basis with Medicare.

I suspect that the motive of the Opposition's attack on Medibank Private is simply that it wants it to be totally private, it wants it left to the longer serving private funds and because it says that competition is good for competition's sake, without really examining the extra benefits given to the subscribers, of which I admit to the House I am one, by Medibank Private at lower premiums. In fact it is a market leader, as it should be, as it has a social role as well as a commercial, competitive role. Price Waterhouse examined what Touche Ross demanded it examine, to give some equality of competition, and its report said that, on the basis of its study, the advantages perceived for Medibank Private did not appear to exist. The study stated:
The disadvantaged perceived for Medibank Private as a result of its association with Medicare may offset any perceived advantages.

Medibank Private contribution rates are lower than the majority of private funds because of its investment performance, low claims member profile, pricing policy, aggressive marketing strategy and effective management infrastructure. Price Waterhouse expressed its satisfaction at the apportionment of operating costs between Medibank Private and Medicare. The Price Waterhouse report said:
Apart from the $10 million provided in 1976, which was repaid in 1984, Medibank Private has not received public funds in any form.
Federal guarantees that additional funds would be made available if they are needed were withdrawn in November 1978. These guarantees were never exercised.

I point out that we have seen the advantages of the child of the Fraser Government and have maintained Medibank Private, and in association with Medicare, a child of the Hawke Government, we have now made sure that all people in Australia are covered by medical insurance whereas when the previous Government left office it left two million people in the community without health insurance and subject to the vagaries of misfortune that afflict ordinary people.

(d) one four star military position of Chief of the Defence Force.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 16 February 1988:

(4) Do pages 60-62 of the volume identify a series of projects under the heading ``Various Upgrade Army living accommodation'' and indicate in each case that no funds are to be spent on these items in 1987-88; if not, what is the position with the projects.

(5) Did the $50m project referred to in the press release result in any expenditure being appropriated in 1987-88; if not, will she give an assurance that funds will be appropriated in 1988-89 for the Army live-in upgrade project.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1a) The press release refers to ``the purchase and building of 378 new and replacement houses''. The location numbers of houses referred to in the question are included in that program.

(2) Yes. The information the honourable member has quoted concerning 18 houses to be built at Liverpool relates only to the new construction element of the Defence housing program. This qualification appears at page 34 of the volume from which the quote was extracted. It is planned that the remainder be purchased from the private housing market.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 24 February 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he issue a directive prohibiting military bands from playing in RSL clubs, or on any commercial premises.
(2) Did this directive follow a direct request to him from the Musicians' Trade Union of Australia; if so, what was the rationale behind this decisions.
(3) Has his attention been drawn to one of the clubs which wanted to have a military band playing on its premises which had offered to donate $1500 to any Army-associated charity, including legacy.
(4) Will he reconsider his directive and revoke his decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. A directive was issued in May 1986 to restrict the performance of military bands on commercial premises to occasional circumstances which do not interfere with Service commitments and which are suitable occasions for their performance.

(2) The Musicians' Trade Union of Australia, among others, made representations in March 1986 concerning Service Bands participating at performances, at which an admission was charged, to the potential detriment of employment opportunities of other musicians.
I did not believe it appropriate for regular performances to be arranged for Defence Force bands, or, except in occasional circumstances, military bands to perform on commercial premises.

(3) My attention was drawn to the $1500 performance fee offer to an Army-associated charity by the Secretary/Manager of the Kingsgrove RSL Club in his letter dated 7 August 1987. He was seeking a reversal of my decision of 20 July 1987 which denied the performance of a 2MD band at a concert being held on 12 September 1987.

(4) The Defence Force policy on the participation of Service bands has not changed since May 1986. All requests for Service bands are considered on their merits consistent with the guidelines. In reaching a decision on each request, account is taken of both Service and non-Service factors. Bands may continue to perform at RSL clubs on special and ceremonial occasions such as Anzac Day.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 25 February 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why was Westfarmers Pty Ltd awarded a public interest grant to develop a natural food colouring agent betacarotene.
(2) What decision was reached in an out-of-court settlement between Westfarmers Pty Ltd and the Commonwealth as to who owned the intellectual property.
(3) What provisions were in the contract with Westfarmers Pty Ltd to prevent the company and the intellectual property being sold to other interests.
(4) What were the findings of the Bureau of Industry Economics evaluation of the original grant.
(5) Who signed, on behalf of the Government, the agreement between the Government and Westfarmers.
(6) What were the terms of the agreement.
(7) Have the terms of this agreement been fully met; if not, what matters have not been satisfied.
(8) What are the arrangements between the Commonwealth and Western Biotechnology Pty Ltd for the payment of plant, office and laboratory equipment due to the Commonwealth.
(9) Have all payments been made; if not, what steps is the Commonwealth taking to obtain full and complete payment.

(10) What arrangements have been made between the Commonwealth and Hoffman La Roche Ltd consequent upon the take-over by Western Biotechnology Pty Ltd to ensure the Commonwealth has control of the intellectual property.
(11) Was advice received from the Attorney-General's Department on the agreement between Western Biotechnology Pty Ltd and Westfarmers Ltd; if so, what was that advice.
(12) What are the terms of the deed signed between the Commonwealth and Hoffman La Roche concerning the intellectual property.
(13) What undertakings were given to the Commonwealth by Hoffman La Roche in connection with the subsequent take-over of Western Biotechnology Pty Ltd.
(14) Is the Minister able to say when the results of the research by Westfarmers Pty Ltd will be made available to Australian industry.
(15) What is the estimated benefit to Australian industry of the $4.6m invested in the betacarotene research of Westfarmers Pty Ltd.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: 1. Westfarmers (sic) Pty Ltd was not awarded a public interest grant to perform research into algal products. In 1983 research staff employed by Roche Products Pty Ltd at their Hutt Lagoon, Western Australia, research facility applied for public interest project funding under the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Scheme administered by the then Department of Science and Technology. They sought on-going funding following the Roche decision to retain their traditional chemical synthetic process in factories in Europe, rather than develop the natural method of producing beta-carotene.

The location of the facility and the research personnel required that a prime contractor would need significant infrastructure support in Western Australia, be operating in a related area of activity or be a future user of the products.
Only the Westfarmers organisation met these criteria and indicated interest in becoming prime contractor. One of its subsidiaries,

Westralian Farmers Cooperative Ltd, submitted in December 1983 an application to the Department. After consideration, the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Advisory Committee, an independent committee of experts, recommended to the then Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Jones) that the proposal be supported under Section 39 of the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act 1976. Mr Jones approved the proposal on 27 February 1984. The form of the funding was by contract to perform the research on behalf of the Commonwealth. The contract specified that the ownership of any developed intellectual property would be the property of the Commonwealth.
(2) The question of ownership of the intellectual property has never been in dispute.

However, CSBP (a Westfarmers associated company appointed to handle staffing and sub-contractual matters), obtained an injunction against T. D. Meagher and Associates (a sub-contractor) to prevent the transfer of patents to the Commonwealth. CSBP withdrew from the case before the hearing and offered $5000 as costs. As T. D. Meagher and Associates' legal costs associated with the court action were being met by the Commonwealth, the offer was referred to the Australian Government Solicitor for advice. The Commonwealth accepted its recommendation to accept the $5,000.

3. There was no specific provision in the contract between the Commonwealth and Westralian Farmers Cooperative Limited to prevent sale of the company. However, a confidentiality clause prevented the contractor or any sub-contractor from disclosing any information arising from the project to third parties other than as required by the agreement.

The contract also provided that the ``Agreement shall not be assigned nor sub-contracted in whole or in part by the Contractor otherwise than to Westfarmers Algal Biotechnology Pty Ltd without prior written explicit consent of the Board.'' The Board (Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board) was the Commonwealth contractual authority established to administer the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act 1976.
The intellectual property remained the Commonwealth's.

4. The Bureau of Industry Economics did not evaluate the original proposal, this having been done by the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Advisory Committee. The BIE, however, in a later review of the Section 39 Public Interest Program of the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Scheme, commented on the early stages of the Algal project. A copy of the report is available from the office of the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business.

5. The contract with Westralian Farmers Cooperative Limited (later assigned to Westfarmers Algal Biotechnology Pty Ltd) was signed by the then Executive Member of the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board for and on behalf of the Commonwealth.

6. The first contract contains a number of clauses. In essence it includes two research phases. A third phase required a second contract. Pending negotiation of a second contract a letter of intent was forwarded to the company and it was agreed that the terms of the first contract would apply in the interim. Copies of the relevant documents are available from the office of the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business.
7. Westfarmers Algal Biotechnology Pty Ltd satisfied the terms of the first contract. Satisfactory terms could not be negotiated for a second contract.
8. The arrangement between the Commonwealth and Western Biotechnology Pty Ltd for the payment for physical assets was by way of payments by instalments.
9. All payments have now been made.
10. The Commonwealth has been and will continue to remain owner of the intellectual property.
12. There is no deed signed between the Commonwealth and Hoffman La Roche (or Roche Products Pty Ltd) concerning the intellectual property.

13. In the context of the takeover of Western Biotechnology Pty Ltd by Roche Products Pty Ltd, I am advised that Roche gave an undertaking to pay any outstanding amounts for the physical assets (see 8. above) and to cause Western Biotechnology to release the Commonwealth from an obligation to first offer use of the intellectual property for commercial development to the company before it could be offered to other companies.
14. A call to Australian industry for expressions on interest in being licensed to use the results of the project is expected in the near future.
15. It is not possible at this stage to estimate the benefit of the project to Australian industry, especially in the light of 14. above.
